article_title: The Aesthetics of Poverty: a Rationale in Designing for Philippine Theater
text:
Published, n.d. Author, Brenda V. Fajardo. Quezon City: Documentation, Research and Publication Division, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA).

According to Brenda V. Fajardo, visual artist and production designer of PETA, the “aesthetics of poverty implies that there is a sense of beauty which belongs to people who live in a condition of material deprivation” and that their perception and artistic expression are strongly influenced by the reality of their particular environments.

Fajardo clarifies that PETA had always come up with creative production designs even under severe financial constraints. However, it was under the training and influence of visiting artist Fritz Bennewitz, who directed PETA productions in the 1980s, that the principle of the “aesthetics of poverty” was consciously developed, and the so-called PETA style evolved. She identifies the characteristics of this design process: always the collective work of a production team; the result of extensive collaboration between the director and the design team, who undergo a workshop to produce a design that is appropriate, imaginative, and economical; and the result of research on aspects of Filipino culture that can be integrated into the elements of design.

Fajardo provides examples of PETA designs in 1973-84, accompanied by some of her sketches. In these designs, the traditional telon (painted backdrop depicting a “realistic” scene) was replaced by a sepia mural of historical documents and photographs in Kabesang Tales (Cabeza Tales), 1975; a three-dimensional backdrop of rubber tires, metal sheets, and wood pieces in Ang Hatol ng Guhit na Bilog (The Caucasian Chalk Circle), 1977; a reversible backdrop of buho (species of bamboo), sawali (woven bamboo splits), and papier-mâché in May-I, May-I, 1979; and an assemblage of art images, news photos, and quoted text in Ang Buhay ni Galileo (The Life of Galileo Galilei), 1980. Both Si Tatang Atbp. mga Tauhan ng Aming Dula (Tatang and Other Characters in Our Play), 1975, and Langit-langitang Kumunoy (Heavenly Quicksand), 1978, used bamboo sets and props, and katsa (cheesecloth) costumes. Macbeth, 1984, relied on ordinary hemp rope, burlap, and barbed wire. Folk art forms and indigenous elements were adapted to contemporary needs, such as the taka (papier-mâché animals of Paete) carried overhead in Sa Tabi ng Pasig (Beside the Pasig), 1973, reminiscent of the bunraku of Japan; and the parol (lantern) as puppet-head symbol in Hobe, 1974. Ethnic instruments, stones, and crackling paper produced the sounds in Dupluhang Bayan (National Joust), 1975. Settings could also be suggested or symbolized by everyday objects, such as a banig (sleeping mat) and a duyan (bamboo hammock) to identify a poor man’s hut, and a malong (tube skirt) to provide a generic Southeast Asian setting in Hatol. An arrangement of “found objects,” such as canned goods, clotheslines, plastic pails and curtains, rubber tires, and metal scraps, conveyed the atmosphere of an urban-poor community in Juan Tamban, 1979.

The effectiveness of such designs is Fajardo’s proof that budget limitations are no hindrance to the imagination, that sets can be evocative instead of literal, that resourcefulness and expressive use of Asian materials are to be favored over mere imitation of Western designs, and that such a design perspective can contribute to PETA’s vision of a national theater reflecting a people’s culture, responsive to current social conditions, and resulting in social change.  Written by Pacita C. Gavino

article_title: Ang Aklat Likhaan Ng Dula 1997-2003: Kapangahasan Bilang Kaligtasan
text:
(The Likhaan Book of Plays 1997-2003: Boldness as Redemption). Published 2006. Editors, Rene O. Villanueva and Victor Emmanuel Carmelo D. Nadera Jr. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press and Likhaan: The UP Institute of Creative Writing.

The second collection of contemporary plays in a series of literary anthologies by the UP Institute of Creative Writing and the UP Press includes not only scripts of stage plays but also scripts for electronic media such as television and radio. In the introduction, Villanueva sets the primary criterion for the selection of these 15 entries—kapangahasan (boldness), not only in the themes but also in the style of the works. Citing the examples of Jose Rizal’s prose, Francisco Balagtas’s poetry, the “seditious plays” from 1898 to the early 1900s, and the patriotic works during the martial law period, Villanueva underscores the virtue of kapangahasan or the ability to speak the truth in times of disquiet. However, he also stresses the need for this virtue in times of peace, when playwrights should resist dominant forms and themes. It is kapangahasan that can push the Philippine Theater from its far-from-ideal state toward kaligtasan (salvation).

The work comprises three parts. The first part is devoted to works of students and new playwrights, most of which were written as exercises for theater classes. It contains, under the subtitle “Pag-ibig,” Allan Lopez’s Anatomiya (Anatomy), Chris Martinez’s Baclofen, Nicolas Pichay’s Ang Henerala (The Woman General), Rody Vera’s Luna: Isang Romansang Aswang (Luna: An Aswang Romance), and Rene Villanueva’s The Bomb!.

The second part features the more established writers who are not necessarily playwrights. It consists of Salvador T. Biglaen’s Ang Bayani ng Hannaga (The Hero of Hannaga), U. Z. Eliserio’s Muli, Si Maynard (Again, Maynard), Par Patacsil’s Cassandra, and April Tong’s Nang Mawala ang Junior ni Junior (When Junior’s Junior Got Lost) under the subtitle “Estudyante” (Student), and Liza C. Magtoto’s Agnoia, an adaptation.

Included in the third part are Elmer Gatchalian’s Laro sa Panganib, a translation of Christopher Hampton’s Dangerous Liaisons; and scripts for television, radio, and film—namely, Allan Alberto N. Derain’s Demonyo sa Bakuran (Demon in the Yard); Jun Lana’s Sa Pusod ng Dagat/Mga Bangka sa Tag-araw (In the Navel of the Sea/Summer Boats); Vim Nadera’s Trihedya (Three Tragedies), three poetry performances; and Edward Perez, Alfred Valenzona, and Arnel Mardoquio’s Dalit sa mga Hanas (Hymn to the Master), a multipart drama production featuring the balagtasan of Teo Antonio, Michael Coroza, and Vim Nadera.

The anthology is a record of some of the most daring works of the time. It verifies the Filipino playwright’s aspiration to contribute to what Villanueva calls “the Redemption of Philippine Theater."  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: Aurelio Tolentino: Selected Writings
text:
Published 1975. Editor, Edna Zapanta-Manlapaz. Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Library.

This book contains a foreword by Marina Dayrit, UP librarian; a preface by editor Edna Zapanta-Manlapaz; Manlapaz’s introduction on Aurelio Tolentino’s life and writings; eight selected works; and a bibliography of Tolentino’s 33 extant pieces.

The anthology highlights Tolentino’s most important and representative works. His best-known piece, Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), 1903, labeled the most seditious of his plays, caused his arrest during its staging at the Teatro Libertad in Manila. Other works in the collection are Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, 1913, a narrative in verse allegorizing the nation’s struggle against, but eventual submission to, the new colonizer; Bagong Cristo (New Christ), 1907, a three-act prose drama depicting the plight of the Filipino laboring class; and La Rosa (The Rose), 1908, a sarsuwela about two men trying to deceive another man into selling his tobacco factory, La Rosa. It also includes Pampango pieces such as Damayan (Mutual Aid), 1911, a one-act sarsuwela; Ing Poeta (The Poet), undated, a one-act drama; and ¡Hilat! ¡Aray! (Ouch!), 1908, a one-act sarsuwela; as well as a Spanish one-act lyric drama, Boda Maldita (Damn Wedding), 1908.

The selections were culled from the manuscripts, typescripts, holographs, and other materials donated by Tolentino’s daughters Corazon Tolentino and Raquel Tolentino-Victoria to the UP Library in 1973. The anthology’s purpose is to provide the text of Tolentino’s works to theater and literature students and researchers. However, space limitations allowed the publication of only eight works. All the texts are printed in their entirety except for Bagong Cristo and Ing Poeta, which have several missing pages. Manlapaz assures readers, however, that the works remain sufficiently intact.

In the introduction, Manlapaz presents a tally of the playwright’s total works, numbering 67 and distributed as follows: 33 Tagalog works, 21 Pampango, and 13 Spanish, as derived from E. Arsenio Manuel’s appendix to his own biography of the dramatist. Of these, only 33 are extant, listed in Manlapaz’s bibliography.

“Tolentino had the peculiar practice of reworking the same material into different genres and into different languages,” Manlapaz points out, explaining that the 67 titles represent only about 40 basic works. She also presents Salvador Lopez’s thesis that Tolentino’s aim was to reach the widest possible audience, thus the translation into different languages.

Manlapaz also briefly discussed significant works that, due to length, were not included in the selections, such as Ang Buhok ni Ester (Ester’s Hair), 1914 and 1915, a three-volume crime novel; Maring, 1913, a novel Tolentino dedicated to Filipino women; Buhay (Life), 1909, another novel featuring women as main characters; Filipinas at España (Filipinas and España), 1901, whose title bears the name of the two main characters; and Daclat Cayanacan (A Guide for the Youth), a work in quatrains that proved so immensely popular it went through three editions, 1911, 1921, and 1926, the last two posthumous.

Tolentino’s works are rich in symbolism, a device he mastered to get the patriotic message across to the Filipino audience and launch an attack against colonial rule. In fact, in Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas, 1903, he explicitly identifies characters as representations of specific nations/characters/groups—thus Ynangbayan, meaning Motherland (Filipinas); and Bagongsibol, meaning Newly Sprung (America). With the wordplay in names and the use of symbolic events, most of his works become political allegories.

The book is a testament to Tolentino’s consistent nationalism. Manlapaz underscores this by again quoting Lopez who stated that Tolentino, from the start, held the answer to the question “For whom do we write?” and that he knew the mission of his writing was to help liberate his country. The selections in this book sufficiently support that.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: Balagtasan: Kasaysayan at Antolohiya
text:
(Balagtasan: History and Anthology). Published 1999. Author, Galileo S. Zafra. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The book is a condensed version of the author’s masteral thesis, “Kasaysayan at Retorika ng Balagtasan, 1924-1941” (History and Rhetoric of the Balagtasan, 1924-1941), presented to the College of Arts and Letters of the University of the Philippines Diliman in 1995. It centers on the origin and the golden age of development of the balagtasan, a debate in verse performed on stage so named to honor Francisco Balagtas, the “Prince of Tagalog Poets” who penned the highly popular metrical romance Florante at Laura, 1838. With a brief introduction by Bienvenido Lumbera and a preface by the author, the book has two main parts: “Ang Kasaysayan” (The History), an essay discussing the politics behind the transformation of the older satirical form, duplo, into the balagtasan, which engaged the public in a critical analysis of sociopolitical issues of the day; and “Ang Antolohiya” (The Anthology), a compilation of 19 balagtasan scripts written by Patricio Dionisio, Jose Corazon de Jesus, Florentino Collantes, Lope K. Santos, Pedro Gatmaitan, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Benigno Ramos, and Nemesio Caravana, which the author gathered from published sources like Bagong Lipang Kalabaw, Liwayway, Sampagita, and Alitaptap, as well as from personal archives such as the Florentino Collantes Collection at the UP Main Library.

The book disproves some misconceptions about the balagtasan, such as the impromptu character of the performance. Though the mambabalagtas (poet performers) displayed proficiency in spontaneous versification—as exemplified by Jose Corazon de Jesus and Florentino Collantes, rivals for the title “Hari ng Balagtasan” (King of Balagtasan)—they wrote scripts that worked as outlines of their performance. The more a script was staged, the easier it became for the mambabalagtas to improvise arguments and punch lines in rhyme and meter, to the amusement of the audience. Another example is the false impression that the balagtasan was confined to the Tagalog-speaking region. Due to the form’s massive appeal to the public, poets in other Philippine languages, particularly Pampango, Ilocano, and Cebuano, as well as Spanish and English, devised their own poetic jousts similar to the balagtasan.

Zafra narrates that the form also became popular in print and broadcast media. The first balagtasan script by Patricio A. Dionisio came out in Bagong Lipang Kalabaw on 5 Apr 1924 and served as the prototype for the three pairs of poets who joined the first balagtasan contest held at the Instituto de Mujeres on 6 Apr 1924. Balagtasan scripts published in magazines were well received, proven by a lively voting system of readers asked to choose among competing poets who argued on a national issue, by sending in coupons found on the page their preferred script appeared. For instance, in the “balagtasan sa pahina” (balagtasan on page) about Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) that came out in the weekly magazine Sampagita from Aug to Dec 1926, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, who stood for “Bukas,” received 14,337 votes; Ramos, who sided with “Ngayon,” received 8,168 votes; and Regalado, who defended “Kahapon,” received 7,612 votes. Following the same pattern, when the balagtasan was brought to the radio, listeners cast their votes via phone calls or mail sent through the postal service.

The 19 scripts collected in the book cover the wide range of topics or themes discussed in the balagtasan. The author categorized three prevalent general themes in the period covered by his study: pampolitika at panlipunan (political and social), pag-ibig at iba pang birtud (love and other virtues), and pangkaraniwang bagay (conventional matters). All three, however, revolve around the central ideas of deliverance from colonial rule, espousing Filipino heroism, recovering the glorious past, and asserting native identity and culture. These scripts prove that the balagtasan is a literary form that affirms the keen relationship between art and life. Specifically, it manifests how art can be of service to people by treating its audience not as mere spectators but as jurors who have the power to decide the winning argument. Finally, since the balagtasan uses the common language of the people, it is a critical exercise that enlightens about the deceptions of political domination and is a means to ward off such an imperialist act.

The book won the Gawad Chanselor for Best Published Research, University of the Philippines Diliman, in 2002, and the Gintong Aklat Award for literature from the Book Development Association of the Philippines in 2000.  Written by Michael M. Coroza

article_title: Bangon: Antolohiya Ng Mga Dulang Mapanghimagsik
text:
(Revolt: Anthology of Revolutionary Plays). Published 1998. Editors, Glecy C. Atienza, Bienvenido L. Lumbera, and Galileo S. Zafra. Quezon City: Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research and Development, University of the Philippines.

Published in celebration of the centennial of the 1896 Revolution, this book is an anthology of 35 political plays written from 1967 to 1996, culled from the different Philippine regions, within three years of research. The plays were chosen to represent the different periods of revolutionary struggle in Philippine history—namely, the First Quarter Storm, 1967-72; the Marcos Dictatorship and Martial Law, 1972-86; the Aquino Regime–Low Intensity Conflict and Total War Policy, 1986-92; the Ramos Regime and the Philippines 2000, 1992-96; and the Underground Movement, 1968-96. Plays from the underground movement were difficult to date and document in terms of their time of writing and production, so they are given a section separate from the chronological listing of plays.

The plays are described as mapanghimagsik (revolutionary) as they embody the people’s revolutionary struggle against all forms of oppression and exploitation. Set in context of different periods and regions, they highlight the strength of mass and revolutionary movements and the correctness of the armed revolution. Themes center on the plight of workers, peasants, and the ordinary Filipino, and how these people act against their abject conditions.

The anthology journeys through the development of revolutionary plays from one period to another, explaining changes in the plays brought about by historical and sociopolitical contexts and the processes that theater collectives underwent to write scripts and stage them. Through summaries and annotations, the anthology covers revisions and the enactment of multiple versions that clarify the genealogy of some plays.

The plays range from the serious, comedic, realistic, expressionistic, to the musical in form. Some adopt traditional Filipino theater forms such as the sinakulo (passion play) or dupluhan (poetic joust). The influence of Chinese stances, such as in the tableaux, thrust positions, and waving of red flags, is also evident in some plays. Minimalist and experimental pieces also have a place on the progressive and revolutionary stage.

Most of the plays included in the anthology are unpublished, available only as encoded, typewritten, or handwritten manuscripts. Some plays from the underground movement are not inscribed for security reasons. Some of the more familiar pieces are from theater groups like the Philippine Educational Theater Association and the University of the Philippines Repertory Company, and from published books.

Most productions survived on the principle of the “aesthetics of poverty” to manage the meager resources of theater groups. Some of the plays were staged in traditional venues such as university theaters, but many were performed in nontraditional venues—streets, picket lines, school corridors, open areas of communities, and even far-flung villages, as in the case of the plays of the New People’s Army. Some plays engaged the audience to interact with the actors.

The plays were chosen to represent the different periods of revolutionary struggle in Philippine history—namely, the First Quarter Storm, 1967-72; the Marcos Dictatorship and Martial Law, 1972-86; the Aquino Regime–Low Intensity Conflict and Total War Policy, 1986-92; the Ramos Regime and the Philippines 2000, 1992-96; and the Underground Movement, 1968-96. article_title: Basic Integrated Theater Arts Workshop (bitaw)
text:
Published 1989. Principal authors, Brenda Fajardo and Socrates Topacio, with contributions from Lutgardo L. Labad, Cecilia B. Garrucho, Jovenal Velasco, and Mel Bernardo. Quezon City: Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA).

This is the first work to be published in the PETA Theater Workshop Manual series meant to document the first 20 years of the development of the PETA curriculum. The book “discusses the philosophy and training methodology of the Integrated Theater Arts Workshop and highlights the features of a model syllabus for a 5-day Basic Integrated Theater Arts Workshop.”

The introduction gives an overview of the development of BITAW, from a methodology that utilizes the arts for individual and group growth to a curriculum that gives importance as well to the ideological, formal, and personal aspects of the syllabus, thus the orientation-artistry-organization framework of the PETA curriculum.

The book has two parts. Part 1 contains two concept papers on the integrated arts workshop that comprise the first two chapters; a third chapter deals with how to prepare for a BITAW.

Chapter 1, “An Invitational to Growth,” consists of a concept paper originally written by Labad and Garrucho for the first integrated arts workshop held in 1973 for high school teachers and students. The objectives of the workshop are personal growth, the improvement of the teaching learning process in the classroom, and the discovery of Filipino cultural roots. Chapter 2, “Towards a Curriculum for a People’s Theater,” also by Labad, elaborates on the orientation, artistic and organizational components of a curriculum for a people’s theater in the context of a national theater movement. These two chapters prepare the users of the manual to utilize the contents of the workshop syllabus in the most purposive combination of elements—namely, the subject areas, games, exercises, and the theoretical components that build up to a particular module which serves a specific purpose or objective. Chapter 3 of part 1 gives pointers on how to prepare for a BITAW, and covers topics such as the host, venue, workshop, area, participants, facilitator, and the syllabus.

Part 2, the bulk of the book, is the model syllabus of a five-day Basic Integrated Theater Arts Workshop. It focuses on three theater modules: “Dula-Tula” (Staged Poetry), “Dulang Realistiko” (Realistic Drama), and “Dulang Alegorikal” (Allegorical Play). Showcased are plays that tackle issues and problems of the community where the participants come from.

The manual provides a detailed syllabus, complete with objectives, procedures, notes on facilitation, and synthesis. It is complemented by illustrations (e.g., of mask-making for an allegorical play); photographs showing a game or a body movement stance in the warm-up exercise; and musical notation for an action song, such as “Ang Giyera ni Lapu-Lapu” (The War of Lapu-Lapu). A very helpful feature is the diagrammatic flow of the theater module under study. Pre-exercises, input on the module, subject areas needed for writing and improvisation, and designing sets, costumes, props, sound effects, and music are identified as important processes that lead up to the showcase. The manual also provides a bibliography of references as well as of suggested further readings; appendices that consist of a proposed vocabulary in Filipino for terms used in the BITAW; and guidelines for the evaluation of the workshop and the curriculum as a whole. An index is also provided to facilitate the search for games, exercises, and unit lessons.

The last chapter reports on the evaluation of the impact of BITAW on its users and beneficiaries in various regions of the country, as discussed in the national conference convened by PETA in 1988. The BITAW has been found effective in the release of creative potentials of people steeped in a culture of silence, the exploration of various forms of theatrical expression, the discovery of cultural roots, consciousness-raising, and entry point for organizing communities and cultural groups. It has been successful in creating a theater arts workshop movement and has served as a catalyst for the development of people’s theater throughout the country. Its limitations, however, stem from its very nature as a theater arts workshop—it cannot go beyond that, despite its flexibility and adaptability. The further exploration of more indigenous forms also remains a foremost recommendation. The manual as published hopes to be a catalyst as well.  Written by Manuel D. Pambid

article_title: Bayang Panitikan: Ang Pagtatanghal Ng Kabanalan Sa Pakil, Laguna
text:
(Town as Literature: Performing Religiosity in Pakil, Laguna). 2007. PhD diss. Author, Jerry C. Respeto. Department of Filipino and Philippine Literature, University of the Philippines Diliman.

This study follows the “construction” of the town of Pakil through its literary texts, performances, and religious practices. Observing the well-known rituals for the Virgin of Turumba, the author asserts that a town’s identity is built on narratives culled from its literature and performances. His concept of “bayang panitikan” (town as literature/literature as town) regards the panitikang namamayani (dominant literature) as open literary texts that embody a critical “kamalayan” (consciousness). These become the town’s literature through ritualization and the people’s practice of the pag-ako (taking on), reflecting its geography and economy, translated and constantly validated through the performance of the religious rituals. These give rise to a constant redefinition of the bayan not only in terms of territoriality, politics, or class but also in terms of the town’s consciousness and identity.

Chapter 1 tackles the complex interweaving of local rituals as historical and spiritual narratives that translate to new narratives as they are performed. Drawing from previous studies by anthropologists and performance theorists, the author asserts that local literature represents the town’s ethos, and its expressions are evolved by the people, further validated as ritualized and performed. The author’s research methodology comprises pakikipamuhay (living in the community), pakikipanayam (interview), attendance of the holy rituals, dokumentasyon (note-taking and photo documentation), paggalugad sa mga lugar (searching the locale), and doing research in local libraries and university libraries in the Philippines and abroad.

Chapter 2 explores the relevant demographic information of Pakil, Laguna—such as its geography, land use, population distribution among its 12 barangays, infrastructure and urban development, major calamities, uprisings and social upheavals, political and socioeconomic profile, local artistic expressions such as the komedya and prusisyon ng Turumba (procession of Turumba), and places of interest—providing a backdrop for discussion on the religious narrative.

In chapter 3, Respeto argues that the narratives, stored in the people’s memory, are the foundation of spirituality in Pakil, popularized by word of mouth since Spanish colonization, and rationalize Pakil’s origins, the power of nature, the miracles of saints, and the potency of the sacramental. Dances and dramatic scripts draw inspiration from the miraculous episodes attributed to the Virgin and to Jesus Christ. The spaces where these supposed miracles occur become spaces for the performance of rituals related to the Virgin of Turumba.

Chapter 4 describes the rituals associated with the Virgin of Turumba as performance and as a continuing process of meaning formation—putting up the main procession, its conduct, and narratives interwoven into song, dance, costumes, and visual design; the reenactment of finding the miraculous image of the Virgin of Sorrows in the shoreline of Laguna Lake; the pag-ahon sa Ping-as (climbing in Ping-as), which pertains to the reenactment of the Daan ng Krus (Way of the Cross) on the path leading to the top of the Ping-as mountain; and the Pagsusuob sa Senyor (burning incense under the body of the dead Christ). The author posits that the kamalayang pandula (theater consciousness) can be gleaned from these various dramatic elements and processes.

Chapter 5 discusses common local areas, such as the church, plazas, streets, mountains, and lakeshore, as spaces for the performance of the rituals. Such spaces are also transformed into little stores for local products such as the pamaypay (fans), taka (papier-mâché), and food products. The rituals create opportunities for social collaboration in support of the town’s livelihood and unique beliefs, deeply ingrained as they are in the people’s consciousness. Specific schedules and spaces are allotted for the integration of people from the neighboring towns of Laguna; the yearlong calendar lists a number of activities devoted to the Virgin, a celebration that sets the people of Pakil apart from other towns. The ritual, as performed, is a holistic expression of the bayan, its evolving concept of territory and people’s participation determined by their level of engagement.

Chapter 6, a synthesis, illustrates the various religious processions in the town’s local topography. The author argues that these religious rituals, their narratives and performances, provide the materials for the production of literary texts, which encapsulate the town’s religiosity. These rituals are lived activities that through time have transformed everyday spaces into performative areas and have provided opportunities for community collaboration.

Ultimately, through the practice of the pag-ako, the rituals are performed repeatedly and thus bring to life expressions of faith, gratitude, and sacrifice for the Virgin of the Turumba. The pag-ako has led to the creation of texts and the performance of the ritual as part of the continuing creation and redefinition of Pakil’s identity.

Included in the dissertation are pictures of the Turumba, Flores, Panghulo Swimming Pool, Reenactment, Senyor, and Pag-ahon sa Ping-as, as well as narratives on the history of Pakil and the Turumba, religious songs and prayers, and documents and laws from Pakil.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

article_title: The Bicol Dotoc: Performance,postcoloniality, and Pilgrimage
text:
2009. PhD diss. Author, Jazmin Llana. University of Wales, Aberystwyth.

The 422-page manuscript is a study of the dotoc (pilgrimage), the religious devotion of the Bikolnons to the Holy Cross. It focuses on the dotoc as currently practiced in three Camarines Sur towns (namely, Baao, Nabua, and Canaman) and one Albay town (namely, Tinago, Bigaa). The dotoc, an exclusively Catholic devotion enacting the journey of pilgrims to the Holy Land to visit the Holy Cross, or Santa Elena’s search for and eventual location of the cross, is undeniably a colonial and thus a non-Filipino/Bikolnon text. Llana examines the dotoc as a problem of representation, weaving through questions of subjectivity and agency as contextualized specifically in coloniality.

The study is marked by a “grappling,” to use Llana’s word, with questions that beset an academic not just from a former colony but a former member of the underground movement whose politics and ethics explicitly ground the research. With Baao as her own hometown, Llana interrogates the double position (subject/object) she occupies in her research, as well as the propriety of ethnography itself as a discipline and methodology.

Llana finds that the researcher is “caught between two opposing positions”—an endless multiplicity or fluidity against absolute totality. Dialoguing with various postcolonial scholars, Llana eventually discovers, or more precisely rediscovers, the Bikolnon word anduyog (co-performance) as a possible methodological route. Anduyog allows the researcher to simultaneously take the position of subject/object as it gathers in a word the six principles that guided the research: presence, paying attention, participation, visibility, reflexivity, and activism. Llana, a Filipino, a Bikolnon from Baao, and a theater person, actually sang and participated in the dotoc, thereby taking the position of object as well.

The study begins with the question of form, tracing the different positions taken by earlier scholars, and eventually taking the dotoc as theater. This allows Llana to underline the performance of the devotees. The notion of performance brings Llana to the question of the “meaning” of the dotoc. By looking at dotoc as performance, Llana is able to demonstrate the iterability of the dotoc; in each performance of the dotoc by the community, it is not the Roman Catholic alone who speaks but the Bikolnon as well. Llana asserts that rather than the story itself, the Bikolnon are drawn to the act of storytelling. Each telling of the story, therefore, is simultaneously a retelling of the Catholic story and a telling of the community’s current aspirations. As a symbolic act of a community, performed annually by the community as a community, Llana nevertheless finds the dotoc as multiple in its very singularity. The multiplicity is such that Llana asserts she can only present the dotoc in its very multiplicity, studying the different texts and their structures as used in the four towns. The multiplicity, however, is held together by the fidelity to the performance each year by the community.

Although Llana’s work on the dotoc takes the postcolonial methodological route of assuming and locating Filipino agency in a text, its significant contribution to Philippine literary history is its refusal to reduce the multiplicities and fluidity in several aspects of her research: the double position of subject/object of the researcher, the continuous movement of the text as always already several texts at once, the performers/people as simultaneously taking the position as subjects and subjected and thus the performance as both obedience and disobedience. The manuscript includes pictures of the different performances.  Written by Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza

article_title: The Comedia (moro-moro) Re-discovered
text:
Published 1976. Author, Felicidad M. Mendoza. Makati City: Society of St. Paul.

The book summarizes Mendoza’s years of involvement in the production and popularization of the comedia. Published for students, teachers, and professors-researchers of drama and theater, both local and foreign, the book is one of the first references on comedia as an indigenous art form. The book has an introduction by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, a foreword by Alejandro R. Roces, and four parts.

Part 1 offers a background of the comedia. Chapter 1 of part 1 is a historical overview of the comedia as an art form, the Philippine comedia, and comedia as a national art form. Mendoza starts from the Western concept of comedy as a dramatic form that arouses laughter. She compares this with the batalla, a display of martial art or movement, which projects a comic rather than tragic tone. This chapter further investigates the origin of the moro-moro, ending with the popularization phase of the comedia, which has since gained a following in the provinces despite the influences of the zarzuela, movies, and television. Mentioned are comedia performances in Parañaque, Quezon, Laguna, La Union, Pangasinan, Pampanga, Naga City, Ilocos, Bicol region, and Cebu, as well as the Kudyapi Community Theater (later called Kudyapi, Philippines), founded by Mendoza herself. Mendoza concludes that the popularization of the comedia affords it a place as a national art.

Chapter 2 details the dramatic and stage elements of the Philippine comedia. Used as a medium for religious propaganda, the comedia—as a verse drama, a dance drama, a religious play, a stylized drama, and melodrama—follows a similar plot. Mendoza describes the process of designing the stage, costumes, music, and sound, as well as the skills and movement for handling weapons for battle scenes. She compares stage movement patterns among the comedia performances in Marinduque, Ilocos, and Laguna. She also elaborates on arnis or kali as an art or technique of defense, which is incorporated into the comedia.

In chapters 3 and 4, artistic and sociocultural processes in the Philippine comedia are presented. Mendoza frames the comedia as a folk enterprise because of the participation of community members. In chapter 5, the comedia is compared to its European versions: the morisca (dance showing Moors in battle), moros y cristianos of Spain, juegos de moros y christianos (outdoor mock battles between Moors and Christians), and versions of Santiagos and Negritos (of Mexico). She also enumerates local parallels in the sinulog, sayaw, sugayon, and maglalatik. The chapter ends by introducing Arsenio Rodriguez, one of the pioneer members of Kudyapi Community Theater, who wrote and directed new comedia such as Prinsipe Divino (Divine Prince).

Mendoza chronicles her encounters with comedia practitioners in the provinces in part 2. She documents her interview with Mr Cesario Gamboa, who spoke proudly of his acting career as Lizardo, a legendary hero of Pampanga. She describes other comedia like Aklan’s sayaw; the comedia in Cuyo, Palawan; and that in Currimao, Ilocos Norte. In the last section, Mendoza gives a brief autobiographical account of how she discovered the comedia, an experience that motivated her to form the Kudyapi Dulaang Munti ng Comedia.

In part 3, Mendoza suggests the development of comedia as an Asian traditional drama. She identifies various strategies for consideration: videotape or film documentation of comedia performances; film versions; a comedia library and “museum town”; an agency devoted to information dissemination about the comedia; comedia translations in English; the inclusion of the comedia in the college curriculum; a comedia center; and most importantly, joint efforts by the community members.

Kasilag’s music for the comedia Prinscipe Baldovino (Prince Baldovino), comedia steps posed by comediantes of Parañaque, and production photos are published in the book.  Written by Bryan L. Viray

article.value: The book summarizes Mendoza’s years of involvement in the production and popularization of the comedia. Published for students, teachers, and professors-researchers of drama and theater, both local and foreign, the book is one of the first references on comedia as an indigenous art form. The book has an introduction by Lucrecia R. Kasilag, a foreword by Alejandro R. Roces, and four parts.

Part 1 offers a background of the comedia. Chapter 1 of part 1 is a historical overview of the comedia as an art form, the Philippine comedia, and comedia as a national art form. Mendoza starts from the Western concept of comedy as a dramatic form that arouses laughter. She compares this with the batalla, a display of martial art or movement, which projects a comic rather than tragic tone. This chapter further investigates the origin of the moro-moro, ending with the popularization phase of the comedia, which has since gained a following in the provinces despite the influences of the zarzuela, movies, and television. Mentioned are comedia performances in Parañaque, Quezon, Laguna, La Union, Pangasinan, Pampanga, Naga City, Ilocos, Bicol region, and Cebu, as well as the Kudyapi Community Theater (later called Kudyapi, Philippines), founded by Mendoza herself. Mendoza concludes that the popularization of the comedia affords it a place as a national art.

Used as a medium for religious propaganda, the comedia—as a verse drama, a dance drama, a religious play, a stylized drama, and melodrama—follows a similar plot. She compares stage movement patterns among the comedia performances in Marinduque, Ilocos, and Laguna. article_title: Ang Comediang Tagalog
text:
(The Tagalog Comedy). Published 1904. Author, Isabelo de los Reyes. (No publisher and place of publication indicated.)

Written in Tagalog, the author calls his work “liham,” a treatise, which serves as a defense of the turn of the 20th century komedya. A first draft appeared in a daily, El Defensor de los Obreros (The Defender of the Workers), on 9 Aug 1904, eventually printed in folio edition. One dilapidated copy of the folio edition is in the National Library. Commonly circulated is a typewritten copy “with the original pagination preserved,” as marked in the E. Arsenio Manuel Collection.

Ilustrado (educated) Isabelo de los Reyes (1864-1938) was inspired by theater productions in Paris and Madrid, as well as in Japan, Macau, and Hong Kong. At the time of composition, he covered a number of komedya theater productions in Teatro Rizal, mentioning titles like Don Juan Tiñoso, Jason at Medea (Jason and Medea), Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), and Amazonas. Others subsequently mentioned were Doce Pares de Francia (Twelve Peers of France), Bernardo del Carpio, Rodrigo de Vivar de España, and Florante.

The work comprises 14 short sections. Section 1 reveals context of Severino Reyes’s dismissal of some members of his sarsuwela theater company because they appeared in komedya productions. De los Reyes granted Reyes the right to dismiss disloyal company members, but said that if this was done against belief in the komedya as genre, then he would register his objections. To de los Reyes, although the komedya had been introduced by the Spaniards, its character had become markedly different and truly Filipino—ang tunay na (the true) Tagalog theater—not to be abolished, but bolstered. In section 2, he argued the rootedness of the komedya to the indigenous, citing the similarities of the komedya to Japanese and Chinese theater.

Beyond the komedya, sections 3 and 4 highlight other genres of the period, particularly the sarsuwela. In both the komedya and sarsuwela, de los Reyes underscored the originality and unique Tagalog sensibility of the artists. While acknowledging shortcomings on the dramaturgical and staging aspects, he asserted that Filipinos did not simply imitate but improved on the original Spanish models. In section 5, de los Reyes posited this metaphor of the komedya: “para sa isang castilang gumuhit sa papel ng isang sasacyan at tayong mga tagalog ang gumawa sa sasacyan sa ating sariling dunong, at ugali at atin ding lahat ang ginamit, cahoy, bacal, tali, atbp” (it is as if a Spaniard sketched on paper a vehicle, and we Tagalog constructed the vehicle with our own wisdom and ways, and using our own wood, steel, ropes, etc.).

On the komedya’s weak points, de los Reyes blamed empresarios (producers) for neglecting to provide adequate training for the artists and foregrounding profit. He pointed out the need for masters of the art as trainers, those up-to-date on the theater of Europe and elsewhere. In section 6, he listed aspects of the komedya to be retained and developed: the mythical and magical mode, the choreographed marches and battles, and the tono or stylized delivery of lines. A longer list of aspects for improvement cited better conduct for the pusong (trickster), faster costume changes, finer writing and acting skills, better musical accompaniment, and professionalism and discipline for artists. In section 7, de los Reyes pushed for the use of “comedia” as opposed to the more popular “ moro-moro.” He mentioned as exemplary the actors, writer, director, and impresario of Teatro Rizal. Sections 8-10 and 12 present the arguments of Patricio Mariano, Dominador Gomez, and Lope K. Santos on the debate. Sections 11, 13, and 14 document the legal battle in Malabon town, where licenses were granted to komedya groups cada funcion (per show) for 27.50 pesos as opposed to only 2.50 pesos for the sarsuwela. With the help of government officials and de los Reyes himself, the komedyante (komedya players) won favor; the authorities ruled there was no basis for the marked difference in fees.

De los Reyes stood for the continued patronage and development of the komedya; like his other interest, folklore, he defended the genre’s merits and great creative potential. This commitment inspired a great literary debate, and is a testament to the originality and creativity of artists from the lower strands of society.  Written by Apolonio B. Chua

article_title: The Complete Poems and Plays of Jose Rizal
text:
Published 1976. Translated, with foreword and annotations by Nick Joaquin. Manila: Far Eastern University.

The book is a collection of all 39 poems of Jose Rizal—from his preadolescent “Sa Aking mga Kabata” (To My Childhood Companions) to the poem presumably written on the eve of his execution, “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell)—and his three plays. The poems, arranged in chronological order, are presented with the English translations facing the original texts, which, with the exception of two, were written in Spanish. The plays appear in their English translations only.

The plays are San Eustaquio, Martir (Saint Eustachius, Martyr), a tragedy in five acts about the martyrdom of a Roman general; El Consejo de los Dioses (The Council of the Gods), an allegory in one act and a glorification of Cervantes; and Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), a zarzuela with the themes of Christianity versus paganism and innocence against evil.

All of Rizal’s plays were authored before he turned 20. At 14, he had written San Eustaquio. His professor Fr Francisco Sanchez, who had translated it from the original Italian to Spanish prose, encouraged him to write it in Spanish verse. At the beginning of the manuscript is Rizal’s note to readers, where he humbly apologizes for what he claims as a poor translation of this play.

The two other plays were written when Rizal was a 19-year-old student at the University of Santo Tomas. El Consejo was his winning entry in the annual literary contest of the Liceo Artistico Literario de Manila. Joaquin declares this the most sensuous of Rizal’s writings. Junto was written for a performance during the feast of the Immaculate Conception in Ateneo de Manila University. With the native scene of a fluvial procession of the Virgin of Antipolo, it reflects the Tagalog side of Rizal. Joaquin claims it as the crowning achievement of Rizal’s early period.

In his signature style, Joaquin is able to provide in his foreword, “Rizal the Bard,” the pictures of Rizal as a boy in love with poetry, consumed by ambition, and changed by events in his environment. He suggests that Rizal’s literature is an unconscious depiction of his dreams and prophecies. One such prophecy is that of his own death, a fate he assigned to Elias and Simoun, his characters in the novels Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion).

Joaquin also produces an evaluation of Rizal’s works. He divides into periods Rizal’s production age. The early period, notably Rizal’s most productive, covers the bard’s youthful writing before he moved to Spain. The plays San Eustaquio and Junto are among the jewels of this period, Joaquin notes. The middle period includes Rizal’s writings during his stay in Europe; Joaquin observes changes in the poet’s style as he embraces the looser, less traditional forms of poetry in the continent. The final period includes work that ultimately locates Rizal’s role in the making of the revolution. It is also said to have been the period that Rizal retreated to mellower scenes.

Joaquin provides notes on his translations as well as other pertinent information, in the form of guides and references for the readers.

While Jose Rizal is among the most documented writers in Philippine literature, Joaquin’s rendering distinguishes this book from others. He provides superb translations for Rizal’s works, and interprets them in a manner that reveals the bard’s own psyche, dilemma, and manifesto.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: Curtain Call: Selected Reviews, 1957-2000
text:
Published 2001. Author, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The book is a collection of 125 reviews written by National Artist for dance Leonor Orosa-Goquingco for the Manila Bulletin, Bulletin Today, Philippine Star, Times Journal, and other magazines from 1957 to 2000.

Arranged in reverse chronological order, the book opens with a review of Eve Ensler’s Vagina Monologues as staged by New Voice Company in 2000 and closes with a review of an Estanislao Lozada Concert in 1957.

The collection reflects four decades of performing arts in the Philippines as staged in humble and grand theaters. It has documented the best performances and thus records the high points in theater, dance, and music. Among the performances reviewed are plays, dramatic readings, musicals, instrumental and dance recitals, and concerts by Filipino and visiting artists from Europe, Asia, and the Americas. The book allows readers to meet the playwrights, directors, and performers, living and dead.

The first few reviews from 1957 to 1969 cover music and dance performances. As the decades advanced, Orosa-Goquingco reviewed more theater performances, drawing attention to bolder plays and productions. The reviews from the 1980s and 1990s, while showing a broad variety of performances, reveal the theater as a venue for experimentation and platform of social commentaries.

Orosa-Goquingco, herself a performer, writes from the perspective of an educated audience. Her reviews reveal the spectrum of her knowledge and authority in the arts. The reviews, though limited to one or two pages each, are infused with observations on every aspect of the production along with brief synopses of the plot or quick backgrounders for the readers’ easy grasp. Orosa-Goquingco’s sharp analyses help audiences identify key elements and issues embedded in the shows.

In his foreword, critic Isagani Cruz praises Orosa-Goquingco’s quick writing, declaring “a review written in a hurry is worth a hundred reviews written at leisure.” The prompt review’s intention is to help improve the next staging and guide the audience on their choice. One can see that the author considers all performances works-in-progress.

In her reviews, Orosa-Goquingco provides pointers for the performers and the entire production crew, identifying details, may they be dialogue, movement, character, costume, lighting, or sound, that need either improvement or complete omission. She generously praises the outstanding performers and geniuses behind the productions.

The reviews may have been written for publication on a single day, but their charm carries over to the present. The collection, therefore, acts as a historical document, with contents in their most candid form—an essential reference for companies who intend to repeat the performances herein reviewed or for researchers who survey the development of Philippine performing arts and foreign productions that took place in Manila theaters.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: Ang Dinamiko Ng Improbisasyon Sa Dulang Pulitikal Sa Pilipinas 1970-1992
text:
(The Dynamics of Improvisation in Philippine Political Plays 1970-1992). 2001. PhD diss. Author, Glecy C. Atienza. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

This dissertation argues for improbisasyon (improvisation) as an important aspect of Philippine political theater. Written by Glecy C. Atienza for her doctoral degree in Filipino (Panitikan [Literature]), the study implies that improbisasyon is an unrecognized but important element in dula (Philippine drama). The arguments are based on Atienza’s active participation in and observation of the different improvisational performances between 1970 and 1992. Atienza notes the significance of the period, as the concept and practice of improvisation became widely popular in the archipelago at this time, particularly in the political theater scene of Manila, the capital of the Philippines.

Atienza documents how improbisasyon became a central force in Philippine theater, noting its power to mirror Philippine society. The theoretical argument of the dissertation segues into an analysis of the textual implication of improbisasyon in the completion of drama. As Atienza posits, there is a persistency of text in improbisasyon despite the absence of an actual literary form (drama). In this regard, the dissertation is also a critique of the canonization of the written drama as the end-all of theater. Atienza celebrates the absence of text in improbisasyon as a manifestation of an active presence. Hence, she argues for what she calls kontra estado (against the status quo) of the canon through a proposal of the spontaneous creations of events, buffoonery, satire, and talinghaga (figurative expressions) as the foundation of a Philippine dramatic aesthetics and politics.

Atienza’s study comprises three chapters. The first chapter maps the theoretical and analytical lens of the study, anchored on the question “Saan ilulugar ang improbisasyon sa karanasang pandula?” (Where is improvisation in the theatrical experience?). Chapter 1 links the teksto (text), pagsasadula (staging), and proseso (rehearsal) as central idioms in the construction of ganap (event), the motif of improbisasyon. This juxtaposition emphasizes the continuous change and the persistency of experimentation in political theater making, which are asserted as the tanging tiyak (constant) in improbisasyon. Here, Atienza also illustrates her criticism against the persistency of the written text in the theater. To celebrate the power of improbisasyon as the persistent absent-present, she looks back to the oral tradition of the Philippines and the tradition of improvisation in some theater forms introduced in the colonial periods, such as the komedya. In doing so, Atienza implies that the bias toward the written text as the end-all of theater springs from the legacy of colonialism.

Chapter 2 is an in-depth analysis and a close reading of different improbisasyon performances from 1970 to 1992. In chapter 3, the final chapter, Atienza frames improvisation as a political tool for the foundation of aesthetics in Philippine drama. She highlights improbisasyon as a key feature toward the identification of Philippine theater ontology via a discussion of how improbisasyon is constantly used by Filipino artists in the writing of drama and the staging of plays, and how the sanctity or sacredness of the written text disappears in the history of Philippine theater.  Written by Sir Anril P. Tiatco

To celebrate the power of improbisasyon as the persistent absent-present, she looks back to the oral tradition of the Philippines and the tradition of improvisation in some theater forms introduced in the colonial periods, such as the komedya. In doing so, Atienza implies that the bias toward the written text as the end-all of theater springs from the legacy of colonialism.

Chapter 2 is an in-depth analysis and a close reading of different improbisasyon performances from 1970 to 1992. In chapter 3, the final chapter, Atienza frames improvisation as a political tool for the foundation of aesthetics in Philippine drama. She highlights improbisasyon as a key feature toward the identification of Philippine theater ontology via a discussion of how improbisasyon is constantly used by Filipino artists in the writing of drama and the staging of plays, and how the sanctity or sacredness of the written text disappears in the history of Philippine theater.
Written by Sir Anril P. Tiatco

article_title: The Drama of It: a Life on Film and Theater
text:
Published 2009. Author, Daisy Hontiveros Avellana. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing Inc.

In this autobiography, Daisy Hontiveros Avellana writes about her husband, Lamberto Avellana, as well as about early Philippine theater and film. The two have been recognized as National Artists for committing their lives to the development of Philippine theater and film from the 1930s to the 1990s.

In 1938, the Avellanas and 50 friends founded the Barangay Theater Guild (BTG) because they believed in “the great art of theatre” and “the Filipino artistic heritage.” During the Japanese occupation, BTG produced legitimate three-act plays in Filipino in movie houses emptied by the Japanese ban on films. After the war, BTG provided quality programming on radio through weekly readings of local and foreign plays. Daisy Avellana’s grief over her father’s death became the creative wellspring for her movie script of Nick Joaquin’s A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, the Avellanas’ “legacy to Philippine theater.”

The seven chapters of this autobiography are supported by folios on her early writing as well as by photographs on theater, film, and family. In the early writing folio, Daisy Avellana, also an award-winning short story writer, narrates how her family survived the Japanese occupation. She recalls the continuous evacuation of parents and children from one house to another, taking refuge in a church or a burnt home, the hazardous birth of her child, the scarcity of food, the near execution of her husband, the insane and the upright among the enemy. She is awed by the courage and greatness of Filipino guerrillas. The film folio shows the multi-awarded Bert Avellana passionately at work in theater and film and appealing for support of quality films and the creation of a genuine Philippine cinema. In the 67 films he directed, Bert Avellana tried to eschew vacuous popular melodrama and introduce national issues. He pioneered realistic Philippine cinema, beginning with Sakay, 1939, then moving on to the internationally acclaimed Kandelerong Pilak (Silver Candlesticks), 1954, Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, and Badjao, 1957, and culminating with A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, 1965. The theater folio displays photos of the actress in a wide range of major roles, including her stellar role as the famous Candida in A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino. The family folio reveals four generations of fulfilling family life of the Avellanas.

The engaging memoir of an actress married to a director documents the early movement from amateur to professional Philippine theater in Manila. As such, it serves as an inspiration and an invitation to the younger generation of theater artists to continue the Avellanas’ early endeavors toward a Philippine national theater.   Written by Maria Teresa Martinez Sicat

article_title: Ang Dramang Tagalog, 1899-1944: Isang Pag-aaral Sa Mga Anyo at Paksa
text:
(The Tagalog Drama, 1899-1944: A Study of Forms and Themes). 1995. MA thesis. Author, Jerry C. Respeto. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman. 2 volumes.

The first of Respeto’s two volumes serves as the main study, analyzing the drama, a genre of Philippine theater that flourished alongside the sarsuwela in the early decades of American colonialism. This covers the dramang Tagalog (Tagalog drama) from its rise in 1899 to its decline in 1944. The second volume anthologizes 56 drama synopses and 10 drama texts.

Following the first volume’s introductory chapter, chapter 2 traces the urbanization of Manila by the American colonial government and its attendant social programs. Colonial influence permeated the public school system, in the use of English as medium of instruction; was the foundation of new sets of values and moral standards for men and women; and shaped economic orientations and political policies like the system of free enterprise, which led to the rise of labor unions, and the continuing persecution of revolutionaries, labeled “brigands.”

Chapter 3 discusses popular theater forms during the late Spanish and early American periods: the komedya, the Spanish zarzuela and European opera, and the dulang panrelihiyon (religious plays) like the sinakulo.

Within chapter 4 are the biographies and works of 17 drama playwrights, among them Tomas Remigio, Severino Reyes, Hermogenes Ilagan, Aurelio Tolentino, Jose Ma. Rivera, Florentino Ballecer, and Julian Cruz Balmaseda. Because these dramatists witnessed the same crucial events in Philippine history and shared a common social and cultural milieu, their plays exhibit similarities in subject matter (relationships of parents and children, of husbands and wives; romantic love; abuses during the Spanish period; the Philippine revolution; American exploitation of the Philippine economy; politics under American occupation), as well as theme (parental love, unity in the family, love of country, search for freedom).

Chapter 5 defines the “drama” as the genre of Tagalog theater written in prose and/or verse, which tackles everyday lives and social issues. The drama’s dialogue is spoken, differing from the music of the sarsuwela and the opera. Antecedents of the drama comprise the Spanish dramas of the 19th century, such as Manuel Lorenzo D’Ayot’s El Poder de Una Pasion (The Power of Passion), 1886, as well as the opera, sainete, entremes, and komedya.

Chapter 6 differentiates two types of the dramang Tagalog, the drama alegoriko (allegorical drama) and the drama historikal (historical drama). As the former, Juan Abad’s Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), 1902, used symbols to expose the colonial intentions of the Americans in the Philippines. As the latter, Simplicio Flores’s Bayan Muna Bago ang Lahat (The Country Before Anything Else), 1907, depicted a soldier’s sacrifice during the Philippine revolution against Spain.

Chapter 7 examines the melodramang Tagalog (Tagalog melodrama), with the example of Cirio Panganiban’s Veronidia, 1919, illustrating the tragic consequences of a woman’s divorce; and the dulang katatawanan (comic dramas), encompassing Patricio Mariano’s Yayang, 1904, where, in a plot of mistaken identity, Yayang works as a maid to spy on her philandering husband.

Chapter 8 likens the drama to a pulpit from which playwrights preached about the importance of family and marriage, the evil of gambling and other vices, the plague of new American liberalism, and the value of patriotism.

Chapter 9 lists the uri (types) of dramang Tagalog, using anyo (form) and paksain (content) as bases for categorizing the plays under study. Based on form, three types of dramang Tagalog are identified: drama alegoriko, melodrama, and dramang katatawanan. Following these themes are sample works on domestic issues, morality and women’s issues, cultural issues such as language and colonial mentality, and politics and labor issues. The study then maps out the development of the three types, linking the rise and fall of each to the larger historical transformations of Philippine society, as well as to the introduction of other forms of Philippine theater and cinema.

Volume 2 of Respeto’s work is divided into two parts: a compilation of summaries for 56 rare manuscripts of original drama gathered from different public and private collections; and an anthology of 10 works representing the various forms and subject matter of the genre.

The thesis is the first comprehensive study of the dramang Tagalog as a significant dramatic genre, a full narrative of the development of Philippine theater during the turn of the century and the early American period.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Dulaan [ccp Tuklas Sining Documentaries on Philippine Theater]
text:
Dulaan: A Documentary on Philippine Theater. 1989. Direction and script, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines. Run time: 40 mins.

Dulaan: A Documentary on Ethnic Theater. 1992. Direction, Ramon A. Obusan; script, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1992. Run time: 39 mins.

Dulaan: A Documentary on the Spanish Influence on Philippine Theater. 1996. Direction, Jaime del Mundo and Dennis Marasigan; script, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines. Run time: 43 mins.

Dulaan: A Video Documentary on the American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Theater. 1996. Direction, Johven Velasco; script, Doreen G. Fernandez. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines. Run time: 46 mins.

This series of video documentaries is part of the larger Tuklas Sining (Discovering Art) series of 28 monographs and videos on the seven arts, each focusing on a particular theater form or forms, era of theater production, and historical and social epochs in the Philippines.

The first video documentary, Dulaan: A Documentary on Philippine Theater, 1989, is an overview of the cultural traditions that continue to shape Philippine contemporary theater production and practices. The documentary mentions the main dramatic forms during the four periods in the development of theater. These are the rituals, mimetic dances, and customs of the indigenous period; the komedya, sinakulo, and religious playlets of the Spanish period; the sarsuwela, drama, bodabil, and English plays of the American period; and the realistic and nonrealistic plays of the contemporary period.

The second part, Dulaan: A Documentary on Ethnic Theater, 1992, attempts to describe the indigenous theater forms that continue to exist among the ethnolinguistic groups of the Philippines today. These include rituals like the atang-atang in Isabela; mimetic dances like the kadal blilah of the Tboli of South Cotabato and bumbuwak of the Gaddang; mimetic customs like the sinuhon no bata in Kitataw, Bukidnon; and short mimetic narratives like the binabayani in Pampanga and the panonoroon of the Maranao.

The third documentary, Dulaan: A Documentary on the Spanish Influence on Philippine Theater, 1996, highlights the theater forms introduced to and assimilated by Filipinos during the Spanish period. The documentary focuses on five theater forms: the komedya, religious playlets, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama. The komedya featured are the Komedya de San Miguel (The Play of San Miguel) in Iligan and Komedya sa Quezon (Play in Quezon). Playlets shown in the documentary include the palo-palo in Ivana, Batanes; kinabayo in Zamboanga del Norte; sayaw in Aklan; and Christmas kagharong in Baao, Camarines Sur. Examples of lenten playlets are the osana in Plaridel, Bulacan; salubong or via crucis in Paete, Laguna; paghuhugas ng paa in Gasan, Marinduque; soledad in Manaoag, Pangasinan; araquio in Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija; pagsunog kay Hudas in Mexico, Pampanga; and moriones in Gasan, Boac, and Mogpog, Marinduque. The long and short sinakulo is exemplified in several Luzon provinces. Sarsuwela include Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds), 1902, and the contemporary sarsuwela in Bantay, Ilocos Sur. Drama or prose plays featured in the documentary are Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s comic Sino Ba Kayo? (Who Are You All?), 1943, and Cirio Panganiban’s tragic Veronidia , 1919. Al Santos’s Kalbaryo ng Maralitang Tagalungsod (Suffering), 1989, which highlights the plight of the masses, is a modern-day rendition of the sinakulo.

The last documentary, Dulaan: A Video Documentary on the American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Theater, focuses on the dramatic forms influenced by American popular culture and the public school system as well as the original plays written by Filipinos after World War II. Some of the theater forms discussed in the film are the bodabil and the prose drama, or plays without music. Of the prose dramas, the documentary identifies two traditions that continue to shape contemporary theater practices in the country: the seditious plays of Aurelio Tolentino and the modern drama brought here by educated playwrights like Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Alberto Florentino, and Severino Montano. Some of the seditious plays mentioned in the documentary are Juan Abad’s Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), 1902, and Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), 1903. On the other hand, modern plays featured in the documentary include Guerrero’s Three Rats, 1952, and Florentino’s The World Is an Apple, 1959.

The video monograph series on Philippine theater is the first of its kind, created especially for students, scholars, and all theater aficionados.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Dulaang Cebuano
text:
(Cebuano Theater). Published 1997. Editors, Erlinda K. Alburo and Resil B. Mojares. Translations by Don Pagusara, Erlinda K. Alburo, and Resil B. Mojares. Introduction by Resil B. Mojares. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The book is part of the Panitikan series, a project involving the translation of various Philippine regional literatures into the national language with the aim of broadening the scope of Philippine literature.

In his introduction to the book, Mojares locates the birth of modern Cebuano theater within its origins from the Spanish period up to the early decades of the American period. Mojares begins his narrative with the performance of religious rituals that bore the essential elements of theater upon the arrival of Magellan in 1521 and Legaspi in 1565, and the staging of a comedia Castellana (Castilian comedy) written by the Jesuit Francisco Vicente Puche, coinciding with the inauguration of a grammar school. Mojares notes the dearth of information about the development of Cebu theater in the next two and a half centuries. He surmises nevertheless that there were performances of religious plays in the more affluent towns of the province, while traditional forms of theater, such as the indigenous kolasisi and balitaw, persisted in homes and in peripheral communities. The latter part of the 19th century saw a more dynamic theater scene as a result of the economic progress from the opening of the Cebu port to foreign traders in 1869. This was followed by the introduction of the zarzuelang Espanyol (Spanish zarzuela) and the establishment of the Teatro Junquera, which became the main venue of many Spanish zarzuelas and, later, modern plays in Cebuano.

A vibrant theater form that emerged in areas outside the city was the linambay or moro-moro. One community that nurtured this tradition was Valladolid. Mojares traces the development of the form in Valladolid to the transformation of a Spanish narrative titled “Alimpatar” into a linambay. The staging required 100 characters, various halimaw (monsters) and mythical creatures, colorful costumes, an orchestra, and nine nights of presentation. The scope of the production was such that the entire community had to participate in the mounting of the play—a communal work of theater that consolidated the community. The linambay flourished in various parts of Cebu up to the 1930s. Mojares asserts that as a vehicle of moral and social consciousness, the linambay was limited since the situations it presented were foreign and unrealistic.

Mojares continues that it is within this context that the modern Cebuano theater emerged. Vicente Sotto was at the forefront of this new development, criticizing the religious plays and the linambay. He wrote Ang Paghigugma sa Yuta nga Nataohon (Love for the Native Land) in 1902, which, according to Mojares, launched the Cebuano realistic drama. He founded the Compania de Aficionados, which aimed to create an alternative theater to the Spanish zarzuela and the linambay.

The four plays anthologized by Alburo and Mojares offer a glimpse of the features of Cebuano modern theater, which thrived in the early decades of the 20th century. The play Ang Paghigugma sa Yuta nga Nataohan by Sotto parallels the anticlerical Rizal novels. Asawa sa Usa ka Sugarol (The Gambler’s Wife), 1914, by Ismael Paras criticizes vices, particularly cockfighting. Mini (The Fake), 1925, by Buenaventura Rodriguez adheres to the romantic notion that love overcomes class differences. Rajah Hamabar, 1960, by Potenciano Canizares Jr dramatizes the history of Cebu before the Spanish colonization. These plays highlight a key element of modern Cebuano theater—the relevance of the content and theme of the plays to the lives of the Cebuano people.

The source texts and the target texts in Filipino and English are all published in this collection. The musical notation of “Himig ng Isang Awit sa Mini ” (Melody of a Song in The Fake) is included as an appendix.

This anthology is a succinct, yet extensive account of the development of Cebuano theater up to the early decades of the 20th century, and provides examples of plays whose characteristics are distinctly Cebuano.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

Rajah Hamabar, 1960, by Potenciano Canizares Jr dramatizes the history of Cebu before the Spanish colonization. These plays highlight a key element of modern Cebuano theater—the relevance of the content and theme of the plays to the lives of the Cebuano people.

The source texts and the target texts in Filipino and English are all published in this collection. The musical notation of “Himig ng Isang Awit sa Mini ” (Melody of a Song in The Fake) is included as an appendix.

This anthology is a succinct, yet extensive account of the development of Cebuano theater up to the early decades of the 20th century, and provides examples of plays whose characteristics are distinctly Cebuano.
Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Dulaang Hiligaynon
text:
(Hiligaynon Theater) Published 1996. Editor, Rosario Cruz-Lucero. Translations by Ricardo Oebanda Jr and Rosario Cruz-Lucero. Introduction by Doreen G. Fernandez; translation by D.M. Reyes. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The introduction by Doreen G. Fernandez presents a historical overview of Hiligaynon drama from the indigenous rituals of the precolonial past to the more consciously“artful” forms of the present. Thebody consists of an anthology of four Hiligaynon plays, each with a translation into Filipino.

The first, Tanikala (Chains) by Serapion C. Torre, is a domestic drama. Soledad is unhappily married to a feckless, violent, and perennially inebriated husband, ironically named Graciano. Herwell-meaningbut uninformed friend Rosario suggests divorce, while Gaudencio, a childhood friend, confesses hislong-withheldlove for her, despite his marriage to a Pampango woman.

Cusug sang Imul (Strength of the Poor)by Miguela Montelibano and Bunal nga Ualay Labud (Blows without Bruises) by Leopoldo Alerta are sarsuwela tackling social issues. The first affirms that with diligence, study, and collective action, the poor can prosper. Jose is a young man who dreams of higher education. With financial help from the samahan (collective), Jose leaves for the city and returns to the town six years later a lawyer.

Bunal is a satire on the ways of the avaricious. Gerundio returns from Havana an inept lawyer and a snob, a stranger to the native language, and an ignoramus in any form of employment. Felicuda is his equally indolent and haughty sister who abuses the helpers. Intermittently out of work, Gerundio wastes his father’s wealth, amassed through theft and usury. Ranged against them is the family of Pacifico Prudente, an honest workman, an affectionate father, and a kind master, whosefortunes—despitethe odds—turnout rather well.

Balay ni Bilay Hilay (Bilay’s House is Tottery) by Joel R. Arbolario is a comico-allegorical piece of street theater criticizing Philippine-American relations. The wobbly house stands for the Philippines; ’Nyora Inday Luisita vda de Mia stands for the local leadership conniving with the guwapong Kano (handsome American) and the Heneral (literally, the general; allegorically, the military). Lalaki (Man) and Babae (Woman), representing the common Filipino, at one point called “the shits of oursociety,” areforcibly driven out of their barangay for a factory, because as ’Nyora Inday’s servant Menggay says: “We need more dollar money, money /So that our utang [debt] we can pay.” In theend, the play exhorts everyone to join hands and rebuild the house.

Though written between 1916 and 1988, theplays anthologized and translated raise issues as relevant and contemporary as any dramatic piece being staged today. They are a testament to the vigor of Hiligaynon literature.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Ang Dulang Pilipino
text:
(The Filipino Theater). Published 1943. Author, Julian Cruz Balmaseda. Manila: Institute of National Language.

The essay, originally a lecture delivered by Balmaseda on 8 Sep 1943, follows the theme of Severino Reyes’s earlier discourse, Dulang Tagalog (Tagalog Theater), which asserts that an indigenous and distinct Filipino theater existed before the arrival of the Spaniards. Building on Reyes’s arguments, Balmaseda enumerates local terms representing native theater forms like the karagatan, papuri, sabalan, pananapatan, tibaw, and tagayan, proof of a flourishing pre-Hispanic theater tradition.

Balmaseda points to the propagation of Christianity as context for the development of Tagalog theater during the Spanish period. From the colonizer’s goal of spreading a new faith emerged a new theater form, the dulang pampananampalataya (religious theater). The first example of such a play, Pagpapakasakit kay Santa Barbara (Sacrifice for Saint Barbara), was presented in Bohol in 1609 by the Jesuits. Soon after Filipinos underwent various rituals and received lessons in Christianity, they created their own religious plays. Among them were Pagpugot kay Longinos (Beheading of Longinus) in Bulacan, which mentioned Jesus’s crucifixion, and the tibag, or the dramatization of the tearing down of Mount Calvary to search for the cross on which Christ died. Balmaseda also notes the popularity of the comedia de capa y espada in Spain during the time. These plays were models for Filipino dramatists. Due to the intervention of the Spanish friars, they always concluded with the Christians winning over the Moors.

Balmaseda highlights the criticism from some Filipino writers of the komedya. One of the earliest was Francisco Balagtas’s La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante (The Elegant Indian Woman and the Negrito Suitor), his effort to introduce a new kind of play. Even in Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), the local leaders, in their meeting at the town hall of San Diego, denounced the komedya because there was nothing to learn from it, and instead suggested the mounting of plays that depicted Filipino customs. Nevertheless, Balmaseda acknowledges the signature of plays written by Balagtas, such as Orosman at Zafira (Orosman and Zafira), Abdal at Miserena (Abdal and Miserena), Bayaceto at Darlisca (Bayaceto and Darlisca), and Almansor at Rosalina (Almansor and Rosalina), in which the moral ascendancy of the non-Christians are implied.

In the breakout of the Philippine-American War, there was a short hiatus for Tagalog theater. Then a new kind of theater emerged during the American period—plays that embodied the “diwang mapanghimagsik” (revolutionary spirit). Dramatists who wrote such plays were Pascual Poblete, Manuel Burgos, Gabriel Beato Francisco, Tomas Remigio, Juan Matapang Cruz, Juan Abad, Aurelio Tolentino, Patricio Mariano, and Severino Reyes. Some were threatened by the authorities, as the sedition law was enforced by the American colonial government. Such was the case of Tolentino who wrote Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), which contained anticolonial and anti-American sentiments. What resulted from this was a number of plays that Balmaseda calls dulang pangkaugalian, or plays that focused on the theme of love and depicted the customs and inclinations of the people, but did not necessarily allude directly to political issues. Meanwhile, the moro-moro or komedya’s popularity waned when theater groups shifted to new forms such as the drama and sarsuwela.

Tagalog theater suffered another period of decline, which Balmaseda attributes to economic issues. New writers, for example, worried that their plays would not be staged because of lack of funds, resorting instead to writing novels. The 1920s saw several unsuccessful attempts at reviving Tagalog theater. Plays with music did not last long because of the high cost of production. Translations of Spanish opera into Tagalog did not resonate with audiences so removed from those realities. Dramatists adapted Spanish plays to the Philippine context, but these, too, failed to prosper, unable to escape a perceived foreign sensibility and outlook.

Balmaseda’s work ultimately highlights the importance of creating theater that is relevant to the lives of the Filipino people.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra
