article_title: Dulang Tagalog
text:
(Tagalog Theater). Published 1938. Author, Severino Reyes. Manila: Institute of National Language.

Originally a lecture delivered in Jul 1938, this essay claims that a distinct Philippine theater existed before the arrival of the Spaniards. As in other cultures, Philippine theater is rooted in indigenous songs and dances, which evolved from mimicking the sounds and movements of nature.

These early mimetic art forms further developed into full-blown theater forms as a result of the people’s practice of various social activities. First, rituals performed by native priests called alagar and katalonan featured songs, dances, and exchanges between the priests and the community. Second, the community welcomed warriors returning from battles with the playing of various musical instruments, and performed songs and dances in open spaces or in front of the house of their raha (ruler). Third, early Filipinos created presentations about the lives of their heroes to raise awareness about their heroic deeds and acts of bravery for the younger generation to emulate, and thus mold future heroes in their community. Based on these contexts, Reyes affirmed the originality of early Tagalog theater.

The arrival of the Spaniards introduced new forms to Tagalog theater. One of these was the moro-moro, which depicted battles between the Christians and the Moors, the former always emerging the victor. The Spaniards also introduced the opera, drama, and zarzuela. Reyes points to the gradual changes made by the Filipino mandudula (dramatist) to these forms to engage the audience and to respond to the call of the times. After some time, the moro-moro experienced a short period of decline but reemerged after the Philippine Revolution. Its rebirth was due to the integration of new elements, such as magic and the sarutso or payaso (clown). On the other hand, other forms like the sarsuwela did not take off because there were no theater companies to stage it other than that of Hermogenes Ilagan.

For Reyes, what was needed were “dulang makabago ang uri at nakapagtuturo nang malaki” (plays that are new in form and can educate meaningfully)—plays that depicted the realities of the Filipino people. Reyes then higlighted two of his prominent plays: RIP, a comical play on the moro-moro in question, and Walang Sugat (No Wounds), a sarsuwela depicting the revolution and presented by his then newly formed theater group. For Reyes, the successful mounting of these plays signaled a rising interest from the public in this new form and the further decline of the moro-moro. In narrating the fate of the moro-moro, Reyes underscored the need to constantly create theater and literature relevant to the lives of the people.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: The Filipino Drama (1905)
text:
Published 1981. Author, Arthur Stanley Riggs. Manila: Intramuros Administration.

This book is written by a former American naval commander who participated in the colonization of the islands. It belongs to the tradition of colonialist criticism of Philippine literature, which denigrates native writings to prove that the Filipino “belongs to the lower class of humanity,” thus making him fit for nothing but subjugation.

The book comprises 11 chapters. Chapter 1 describes the “literary characteristics” of the “Filipino tribes” and concludes that “there is no Filipino literature.” Chapter 2 identifies the mythological images and figures used in the Filipino drama, the “only department of literature in which the Filipino has done anything worthy of mention,” and evidence of the superstitious nature of the “tribesmen.” Chapter 3 traces the development of the genre from the pre-Hispanic to the American period and divides the subject into four subgenres: the prehistoric, the religious, the moro-moro, and the seditious or revolutionary drama. Chapters 4 and 5 discuss the evolution of the seditious drama, which the author considers “interesting and instructive.” Riggs argues that the moro-moro, which features the Christian and Muslim conflict, was the model of the seditious play, as both plays show the efforts of the “aborigine to throw off the yoke of the invader, who seemed to his distorted imagination to be a most grievous oppressor.” Chapters 6-11 showcase five of the so-called seditious plays— Luhang Tagalog (Tagalog Tears) by Aurelio Tolentino, Malaya (Free) by Tomas Remigio, Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain) by Juan Abad, Hindi Aco Patay (I Am Not Dead) by Juan Matapang Cruz, and Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow) by Aurelio Tolentino—and an opera, Magdapio, by Pedro Paterno. Each chapter is divided into two parts: an introduction written by Riggs and a complete English translation of the play.

The published edition of The Filipino Drama includes a foreword by Jaime C. Laya; a historical introduction by Doreen G. Fernandez; the original Tagalog versions of Malaya, Tanikalang Guinto, and Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas; Roman Reyes’s Tagalog verse translation of Magdapio; and Bonifacio Ilagan’s retranslations into Filipino of two rediscovered plays, Luhang Tagalog and Hindi Aco Patay —thus making it a thick edition of 700 pages.

The value of the book lies not in the author’s calumnies but in its incidental preservation of the two lost plays— Luhang Tagalog and Hindi Aco Patay. The book is also a concrete example of how the Filipinos and their culture were seen from the perspective of the colonizers. Riggs’s point of view is opposite that of the freedom-loving Filipinos, such that what is seditious to him is revolutionary to the Filipinos.  Written by Jose Duke Bagulaya

article_title: From War Dance to Theatre of War: Moro-moro Performances in the Philippines
text:
PhD diss. Author, Nikki Seranilla Briones. Department of Southeast Asian Studies, National University of Singapore.

This dissertation analyzes the development of the moro-moro or the komedya, a traditional Philippine theater form revolving around the religious conflicts between Christians (particularly Catholics) and Muslims, usually performed in rural areas in the archipelago. The focus of the dissertation is the batalla, or the dance element of the theater form.

Briones proposes “choreographic logic” as a useful idiom for the understanding of the batalla in the moro-moro. Close attention is paid to the structure, composition, production, and consumption of the batalla. Using this idiom, Briones links the present performances of the komedya to the performances during the Spanish colonial era in the Philippines. Choreographic logic is also Briones’s strategy to illustrate the affinity of the moro-moro to Southeast Asian theater traditions and its rootedness to what she calls “indigenous aesthetic sensibilities.” The study asserts that the moro-moro is not only a mimicry and an import of the Spanish comedia but an authentic Filipino theater tradition.

The dissertation comprises seven chapters and a conclusion. Chapter 1 is a general introduction, which includes a historical overview of the theater form and a glimpse of academic literature covering the subject. In chapter 2, Briones explains why she uses “moro-moro” as opposed to “komedya” in exclusively referring to this theater form. She expounds that the moro-moro is rooted in the indigenous, covering a variety of native war dances in the archipelago, and has a direct link to other performance genres in Southeast Asia. Chapters 3-5 elaborate her arguments on the authenticity of the moro-moro as a Filipino performance form. Briones illustrates how modes of composition, delivery, and consumption of the moro-moro follow the “choreographic logic,” which she uses to highlight this sense of the “authentic” in the moro-moro. One particular example is the character of repetition and the monotonous delivery of lines, which are asserted to possess affinity with the chanting traditions of Philippine epics. Another example in the dissertation is the presence of the dictador or the prompter-playwright, who, in Briones’s arguments, acts as a bricoleur —an expert in collating available stock imagery and scenarios during an actual performance of the moro-moro. The heart of this section is Briones’s emphasis on the batalla, which is based on native conceptions of power and the efficaciousness of dance as offering, locally known as panata.

Chapters 6 and 7 focus on the contemporary performances of the moro-moro. Briones presents innovations of contemporary troupes in popularizing the form to younger audiences. This is followed by a reimagination of the moro-moro as the national theater form of the Philippines following the logic of early local theater scholars, such as Doreen Fernandez and Nicanor G. Tiongson. Briones concludes with the affirmation that the use of “choreographic logic” as a method of analysis enables us to look at the moro-moro as a part of the national heritage in the Philippines despite the fact that it was once a symbol of colonial baggage.

Written by Briones for her doctoral degree in Southeast Asian Studies at the National University of Singapore (NUS), the dissertation received the NUS Wang Gungwu Medal and Prize in 2011.  Written by Sir Anril P. Tiatco

Written by Briones for her doctoral degree in Southeast Asian Studies at the National University of Singapore (NUS), the dissertation received the NUS Wang Gungwu Medal and Prize in 2011.
Written by Sir Anril P. Tiatco

article_title: Hermogenes Ilagan: Father of Tagalog Zarzuela
text:
Published 2000. Author, Rustica C. Carpio. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

The book gives paean to Hermogenes Ilagan, foremost writer of the Tagalog zarzuela, now usually referred to as sarsuwela, for four decades until 1940, the last year of performance of Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), his most famous work before World War II. “Zarzuela” is the Spanish term for drama with spoken dialogue and songs interspersed with dialogue. Carpio uses the imported term even as she refers to the Philippine version of the play.

Carpio divides the book into four chapters. Chapter 1 traces the early life of Ilagan, from his birth in Bigaa (now Balagtas), Bulacan; his exposure to the music of the church choir in Santa Cruz, Manila, as he was growing up; his theater tours in the provinces; up to the organization of his own sarsuwela troupe, Compania Ilagan, in 1902. Carpio uses interviews with Ilagan’s brother, Angel, and writers like Pedrito Reyes and Engracio Valmonte to gather anecdotes about the playwright.

Chapter 2 comprises the major part of the study, where the author looks into Ilagan’s plays in terms of action, characterization, theme, and style. Thirteen plays are examined here: Bahay ng Himala’t Kababalaghan (House of Miracles and Mysteries), Dalawang Hangal (Two Fools), Bill de Divorcio (Divorce Bill), Despues de Dios … El Dinero! (After God … Money!), Ang Sundalong Kapitan (The Soldier Captain), Venus: Ang Operang Putol (Venus: The Unfinished Opera), Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), Ang Buhay Nga Naman (Such is Life), Ilaw ng Katotohanan (Light of Truth), Ang Sigaw ng Bayan (The Cry of the People), Wagas na Pag-irog (Pure Love), and Panarak ni Rosa (Dagger of Rosa).

Chapter 3 looks into the stagecraft and production techniques of Ilagan’s sarsuwela. Carpio presents Ilagan as a director who was hands-on from the casting of characters to the rehearsals (perhaps the equivalent of present-day workshops), where he would teach voice projection and mastery of dialogue, breathing techniques, the blending of thought and emotion in interpreting roles, the creation of sets, and the use of music.

Chapter 4 summarizes the contribution of Ilagan’s sarsuwela to Philippine drama and theater. Carpio regards him as the total showman, having written more than a hundred sarsuwela, which were regarded as both artistic and commercial successes on stage. Carpio reiterates Ilagan’s boldness and vision as an artist who explored subjects such as homosexuality, divorce, capitalism, hypocrisy, and even the idea of what a play should be when it veers away from the traditional happy endings for the characters. Carpio cites the sarsuwela Panarak ni Rosa as the most accomplished of all his plays, even if it is not the most popular.

The book ends with a short conclusion on Ilagan as an artist whose plays are unmistakably marked by social values. Whether in the mold of comedy or melodrama, his art derives from people and communicates back to them. The book lists 35 extant dramas in the appendix, one adaptation, and one translation.  Written by Rebecca T. Añonuevo

article_title: A History of Scene Design for Philippine Theater (1846-1969)
text:
PhD diss. Author, Pacita C. Gavino. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

This study traces the development of scene design in Philippine theater within its sociocultural context—from the productions of the Spanish period in Manila, through its modernization under the American period, to the search for a national identity and the rise of the theater institutions in the late 1960s, as represented by Repertory Philippines, the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

The study covers scene design, as well as costumes and makeup, lights and the lighting effects of selected productions, the milieu of the theater in which these productions were done, and the overall audience effect of each of these elements. Included are information on scene designers, their influences and style, and their roles in production, as well as discussion on the conventions and innovations of specific periods.

Data were sourced from available photographs, playbills, articles, reviews, or press releases of productions; interviews of theater artists and members of the audience; and archival materials.

Chapter 1 presents the objectives, scope, methodology, conceptual framework and approach, and the significance of the study.

Chapter 2 introduces theater design in the Spanish period with the Teatro de Binondo of 1846, the first formal theater in Manila at that time and a venue for the Spanish zarzuela and drama, as well as European opera. In the teatro, the scenes were framed by the proscenium, and had several telones painted in perspective, with the last separating the backstage areas from the action on stage. The chapter also discusses design for Philippine theater forms such as the komedya, sinakulo, and drama simboliko. The sets for the komedya had fixed entrances and exits for opposing camps and stage space could change to accommodate the action, while the sinakulo allowed for overhead stage riggings and trapdoors for effects. Drama simboliko had stage machinery and effects and accepted simplified sets and anachronistic props and costumes.

Chapter 3 discusses theater productions in the American colonial period, as represented by productions in two theater buildings: the Manila Grand Opera House and the Metropolitan Theater. Drama in English prospered through the productions of the University of the Philippines, Ateneo de Manila University, Silliman University, and the Manila Theater Guild. Realism was highlighted, with the proscenium serving as the fourth wall, although telones were still used for operas, musicals, bodabil, and stage shows. Developments in stage lighting enhanced productions.

Tracing the start of contemporary Philippine theater in the 1950s, with the growing consciousness of Filipino identity, chapter 4 outlines alternative staging styles; visual metaphors and motifs in design; and the translation, transplantation, and reinterpretation of foreign works, which required the rethinking of design concepts in an Asian or Filipino framework. These included the initiatives of Severino Montano and the Arena Theater Guild; Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero and the UP Mobile Theater; and productions involving Rodrigo Perez III, Onofre Pagsanghan, Dulaang Sibol, and later, Rolando Tinio and the Ateneo Experimental Theater. The study caps off in the 1960s, exploring the efforts of groups like Repertory Philippines, PETA, and CCP to forward theater design from the 1970s onward.

This is the first study that offers an expansive view of theater design in its various forms, through different periods in the history of Philippine theater.  Written by Ludendorffo T. Decenteceo

article_title: The Iloilo Zarzuela: 1903-1930
text:
Published 1978. Author, Doreen G. Fernandez. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This book documents the brief life of the sarsuwela in Iloilo—its birth, growth, and demise. It is thus “a close look at one form, one period and one locale in Philippine dramatic history.”

The author begins by setting the socioeconomic context for the sarsuwela. The prosperity that made Iloilo a center for exports, imports, and support institutions such as banks, warehouses, printing presses, and information, through newspapers and education, also made it a center for social and cultural life—not only for Iloilo and Panay but also for Negros Occidental across the strait.

In this setting developed a theater world, peopled by writers involved in the city life as journalists, labor leaders, city councilors, traders, and housewives; by actors untrained but gifted with natural talent; by self-taught artists and designers. The writers were often directors and producers, even prompters. Their plays were staged at town fiestas, religious celebrations, and carnivals, and were reviewed in the newspapers. Their audiences—the landed elite, professionals, the salaried, and workers who loaded ships on the dock—looked to it not only for entertainment but for “lessons to be learned and for a reflection of life as they knew it.”

These plays had moved away from the European kingdoms of the comedia, which had preceded them, and instead derived their form from the Spanish zarzuela brought in by visiting troupes—enacted stories punctuated by songs that functioned as part of dialogue. Their content came from the life around them: the lives of farmers, gamblers, carpenters, servants, parents and children; love, trouble, and betrayal between men and women; and their reactions to education, crisis, domestic strife, good fortune. The lyrics of songs provided information or expressed feelings and were set to music by composers from the community, who often conducted the small orchestras at performances.

The Iloilo sarsuwela reigned as the region’s most popular entertainment form for about three decades. However, when the sugar industry changed to centrifugal sugar production, there came a change in labor conditions, and Iloilo ceased to be the entrepôt for the sugar trade. The changed economy caused a decline in the city’s resources for entertainment. The competition from two new forms of entertainment—vaudeville and the movies—sealed the fate of the sarsuwela. Alongside these factors, the sarsuwela’s formulaic plots lost their appeal. By the 1930s few new plays were being written or presented and, by the mid-20th century, the Iloilo sarsuwela was gone.

The book documents a vanished theater form through the retrieval and examination of surviving plays—synopses, two scripts, and music are provided in an appendix—through interviews with participants and eyewitnesses, and through research in newspapers and programs. It rebuilds the world with historical and critical tools in order to set the sarsuwela in a social and dramatic context, thereby contributing toward “documenting our identity as a people.  Written by Alicia Gamboa

article_title: Juan Tamban (peta Kalinangan Ensemble Script Series 1)
text:
Published 1984. Author, Malou Leviste Jacob; editor, Apolonio Bayani Chua. Quezon City: Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA).

Juan Tamban is the printed version of the play first staged by PETA in 1979. The play is considered one of the most successful plays produced by the company’s performance arm, Kalinangan Ensemble (KE), performed throughout the country for more than four decades since its initial staging. The publication aims to make the manuscript of the play and the details of its creation available to scholars, students, and general readers.

The book comprises four main parts: “Juan Tamban: Ang Iskrip” (Juan Tamban: The Script), “Isang Dula” (A Play), “Anotasyon I” (Annotation I), and “Anotasyon II” (Annotation II).

“Juan Tamban: Ang Iskrip” presents the playwright’s final version of the script, retaining the play’s overall essence after certain modifications during the rehearsals and the production phase. The play focuses on a child, Juan, who falls ill from eating roaches and lizards. He becomes the subject of a thesis by an upper middle-class social worker, Marina. As Marina spends time with Juan, she becomes immersed in the issue of child neglect in society.

“Isang Dula” narrates the conception of the play. The play traces its roots to Lutgardo “Gardy” Labad who, upon reading an article about a child who eats cockroaches, lizards, rats, and frogs, suggested that the company produce a play on the plight of children. Jacob recounts that it was also Labad, then the chair of the artistic committee of PETA-KE, who spearheaded lectures, meetings, and discussions leading up to the production of the play.

“Anotasyon I” documents the writing process of the play, from sequencing to its final publication. It includes “Senaryong Davao” (Davao Scene), “Unang Rihersal Iskrip” (First Rehearsal Script), “Pangalawang Rihersal Iskrip” (Second Rehearsal Script), and the “Writer’s Final Version.” In “Senaryong Davao,” Chua presents an 18-page photocopy of a long-sized bond paper manuscript handwritten by Jacob while in Davao. The document is a sequencing of 24 scenes divided into two acts. “Unang Rihersal Iskrip” presents the first version of the script used during the play’s early rehearsals in Oct-Nov 1978. The “Unang Rihersal Iskrip,” a 52-page long-sized bond paper mimeograph copy, is one scene less compared to the “Senaryong Davao” script because of the integration of two scenes. “Pangalawang Rihersal Iskrip” presents the 58-page long-sized bond paper script used during the rehearsals in the final week of Nov-Dec 1978. This part also details the scene-per-scene dialogue changes made from the first rehearsal script, as well as the reorganization of the scenes in the production. The finer points of the transformations from the early sequencing to the second rehearsal script are summarized in a matrix. “The Writer’s Final Copy” discusses the process of selecting the manuscript for publication, as well as the final notations by the playwright before its publication.

“Anotasyon II” presents notes on PETA’s experience in staging the play. It discusses the concepts that guided PETA-KE in staging the play, processes in the production, changes in the script made by the director during the rehearsals, and characteristics of the production design and music used in the play.

The book is the first of a series of publications to make PETA scripts more accessible to the public. Aside from presenting the play in its written form, the book offers a glimpse into the collective process of developing a script, as well as the collaborative process of mounting it on a stage. The book won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for drama in 1984.  Written by Erick Dasig Aguilar

article_title: Kamao: Panitikan Ng Protesta 1970-1986, Dula
text:
(Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986, Play). Published 1987. Editors, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Reuel Molina Aguila, and Hermino S. Beltran Jr. Manila: Center for Literature, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP).

This anthology of protest plays in Filipino is part of the three-volume Kamao, which includes poems, stories, and plays written before, during, and after the declaration of martial law in 1972. The eight plays in this collection cover three periods: the First Quarter Storm up to the declaration of martial law from 1970 to 1972; martial law period until the assassination of Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr, 1972-83; and the events leading up to the EDSA Revolt in 1986.

The two plays in the first section deal with injustice, abuse of power, and workers’ unrest. Moses, Moses by Rogelio Sikat tells the story of widow Regina Calderon and her children Tony, Ben, and Aida, the latter of whom was raped by the town mayor’s son. In revenge, Tony kills the mayor’s son. When the mayor and his men attempt to arrest Tony, Regina shoots her son, knowing that true justice is unattainable. The second play, Panday-Sining and Bonifacio Ilagan’s Welga (Strike), dramatizes conflict between two workers’ unions—one supported by management, the other, militant. The management schemes to cripple the true union, while the workers rise to protect their rights and advance their interests. The play ends with a call to all workers: “Mga manggagawa ng buong daigdig, magkaisa at lumaban!” (Workers of all nations, unite and fight!).

The second section presents three plays on crucial institutions of social liberation, such as religion, the military, and education. Pagsambang Bayan (People’s Workship) by Bonifacio Ilagan adopts the structure of the Catholic Mass, utilizing familiar religious narratives and images to dramatize a priest’s integration with the people and recognition of his role as co-liberator of the oppressed. May Isang Sundalo (There Was a Soldier) by Rene O. Villanueva portrays a conversation between a prostitute and a soldier, where a discourse on militarization and poverty unfolds. The prostitute reveals that her father was killed in a military operation, while the soldier discloses that his sister joined the armed movement after the rebels occupied their land. Ang mga Unang Araw sa Buhay ng Bagong Iskolar ng Bayan (First Few Days in the Life of a New Scholar of the People), a tula-dula (poem-play) by Richie Valencia and Edgar Vencio, narrates a day in the life of a neophyte at the University of the Philippines (UP), Tibo Matiisin. Alongside his experiences, the play explores problems in the educational system rooted in the complexities of socioeconomic context. Toward the end, Tibo Matiisin witnesses a major student rally and call to action.

The plays in the third section show the festering of social conditions, as well as possible courses of action. Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major) by Chris Millado highlights the realities of various sectors as represented by a farmer, a laborer-organizer, a priest, an Itawes woman who was also a victim of gang rape, a socialite, the wife of a New People’s Army leader, a policeman, and a student-activist. The allusion to a child’s rhyme, “Buwan, buwan, hulugan mo ako ng sundang” (Moon, moon, drop me a bolo), is made meaningful by the buwan as a metaphor for hope, and the weapon as one for reality. Nukleyar II (Nuclear II) by Al Santos tells the story of the Bataan Nuclear Power Plant, disputing imperialist propaganda that links nuclear power to development, and reminding the audience of the horrors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The play calls for an end to the nuclear arms race for the peace and preservation of humanity. Radio Play para sa Boykot sa UP Diliman (Radio Play for the UP Diliman Boycott) features a family whose members have amusing but allegorical names: Daddy Admi Yupi-yupi, Madrasta Govierna vda de Vangkaroti, and children Onapudido, Faculda, and Estong Dante. The children complain to their father that he neglects them because he gives in to the caprices of his new wife. Peryante did the play as part of a call to the UP administration to grant more benefits to its constituents.

This is the first anthology of protest plays in the country. The works collected in this volume define the various themes and forms of protest in the field of theater during these turbulent years of Philippine history. This is also one of the first publications of a more people-oriented post-Marcos era CCP.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

May Isang Sundalo (There Was a Soldier) by Rene O. Villanueva portrays a conversation between a prostitute and a soldier, where a discourse on militarization and poverty unfolds. The prostitute reveals that her father was killed in a military operation, while the soldier discloses that his sister joined the armed movement after the rebels occupied their land. Ang mga Unang Araw sa Buhay ng Bagong Iskolar ng Bayan (First Few Days in the Life of a New Scholar of the People), a tula-dula (poem-play) by Richie Valencia and Edgar Vencio, narrates a day in the life of a neophyte at the University of the Philippines (UP), Tibo Matiisin. Alongside his experiences, the play explores problems in the educational system rooted in the complexities of socioeconomic context. Toward the end, Tibo Matiisin witnesses a major student rally and call to action.

The plays in the third section show the festering of social conditions, as well as possible courses of action. Buwan at Baril sa E-flat Major (Moon and Gun in E-flat Major) by Chris Millado highlights the realities of various sectors as represented by a farmer, a laborer-organizer, a priest, an Itawes woman who was also a victim of gang rape, a socialite, the wife of a New People’s Army leader, a policeman, and a student-activist. The allusion to a child’s rhyme, “Buwan, buwan, hulugan mo ako ng sundang” (Moon, moon, drop me a bolo), is made meaningful by the buwan as a metaphor for hope, and the weapon as one for reality. Nukleyar II (Nuclear II) by Al Santos tells the story of the Bataan Nuclear Power Plant, disputing imperialist propaganda that links nuclear power to development, and reminding the audience of the horrors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The play calls for an end to the nuclear arms race for the peace and preservation of humanity. Radio Play para sa Boykot sa UP Diliman (Radio Play for the UP Diliman Boycott) features a family whose members have amusing but allegorical names: Daddy Admi Yupi-yupi, Madrasta Govierna vda de Vangkaroti, and children Onapudido, Faculda, and Estong Dante. The children complain to their father that he neglects them because he gives in to the caprices of his new wife. Peryante did the play as part of a call to the UP administration to grant more benefits to its constituents.

This is the first anthology of protest plays in the country. The works collected in this volume define the various themes and forms of protest in the field of theater during these turbulent years of Philippine history. This is also one of the first publications of a more people-oriented post-Marcos era CCP.
Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Kasaysayan at Estetika Ng Sinakulo at Ibang Dulang Panrelihiyon Sa Malolos
text:
(History and Aesthetics of the Sinakulo and Other Religious Drama in Malolos). Published 1975. Author, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The first book written on religious drama in a Philippine context and the first in Filipino, this historico-critical work set a pattern for research in Philippine drama. It focuses on the sinakulo or dramatizations of the life and passion of Christ, and other religious dramas and playlets in 12 barrios of Malolos, Bulacan. These are classified first according to length: full-length (e.g., the sinakulo and the elena) and short (e.g., the osana, salubong, flores de Mayo, panunuluyan, via crucis, siete palabras, santakrusan, and pangangaluluwa). The latter are further divided according to whether they were part of the liturgy or were additions to it.

Each form is examined according to source. Sinakulo scripts, for example, are shown, in charts and by line count, to have come from written and oral sources—the different pasyon, the novel Martir sa Golgota (Martyr of Golgotha), the Bible, prayers, stories from metrical romances and magazines—and from the writer’s imagination. Each is then described in detail as performance, with each of the elements analyzed: the samahan or producing group, the stage, sets and props, lighting, sounds, special effects, director and crew, characters, costuming and makeup, music and musicians, and audience.

The appendices include the entire script of the Barrio Tikay sinakulo, including songs, chants, and marches; source information for the other sinakulo; and music for some of the short dramatizations like the panunuluyan. The illustrations consist of photographs of actual performances, sketches of stages and stage devices, and a page from a handwritten sinakulo script.

All the above are presented against the background of Malolos and its religious tradition, and then brought together in the concluding chapter, “Ang Estetika” (The Aesthetics). Tiongson points out the conditions favorable to the growth of religious theater: the agricultural cycle that gave the peasants space and time for the performances, and the religious culture that had unquestioning belief in the tenets of the Catholic faith. In the 1960s and 1970s, however, the change of lifestyle had an impact on community involvement in the acting, staging, directing, and financing of religious plays. More people were working at eight-to-five jobs, less on the soil. Many were employed outside their barrios, outside the town and in the city. Gradually the traditional religious culture of Malolos weakened, became “modern,” and was replaced by a more worldly culture, one with a “scientific” worldview, brought in by education and the popular media—film, radio, and television.

The aesthetics of folk religious theater, which had grown from poverty and a feudal worldview, Tiongson concludes, had produced a “palabas” (show) aesthetics—colorful and entertaining, full of “pakitang tao” (pretense), reaching outward, presentational without an inward view, without analysis. The entry of realism into the folk view and expectations, with its view of multidimensional truth, changed the practice and perspective of religious drama in the barrios of Malolos, Bulacan.

In this book the scholar went out into the field and returned with a load of raw data on performance, production, and community dynamics, which he then ordered and analyzed for the reader, in order to answer the questions one must ask—what? where? how? why? what now?—in order to understand the history, aesthetics, and future of religious theater in the Philippines. The book received the Gawad Balagtas from the Surian ng Wikang Pambansa in 1976.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article_title: Kasaysayan ng Komedya sa Pilipinas: 1766-1982
text:
(History of the Komedya in the Philippines: 1766-1982). Published 1982. Author, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Integrated Research Center, De La Salle University.

The first work to bring together historical documentation and field data in order to limn the history of a Philippine theater form, Kasaysayan ng Komedya traces the komedya from its Spanish sources—the comedia de santo, de capa y espada, a fantasia —and beginnings in the Spanish language, to the present. Its growth and development are divided into three periods: early growth in 1766-1820; first flowering in 1820-96; seasons of public attack in 1878-1920; and a second flowering in 1900-1982.

The period of first growth is fleshed out from the accounts of European travelers, priests, and scholars—de Morga, Colin, Delgado, Martinez de Zuñiga, Le Gentil and, of course, Retana—and from the work of Filipino writers on the period, such as Jose Ma. Rivera on Huseng Sisiw. The piecing together of information shows the form taking its Filipino shape: stories written in verse, imbued with magical elements, featuring royal battles and romances, with prince heroes and clowns as major characters.

The first flowering of the komedya is shown to have come about because of the confluence of cosmopolitanization, urbanization, and Christianization in the 19th century. The accounts of eyewitnesses and current scholars show that the stories are clearly traceable to Spanish metrical romances, and that the play had by then been well established in different regions: Manila, Pampanga, Bicol, Ilocos, Antique, Iloilo, and Cebu. It was most frequently staged at town fiestas; there were theaters dedicated to it; and it had built up a dramaturgy, staging conventions, and an audience.

In the third period, the komedya came under attack from writers influenced by the new liberalism, wafted from Spain by clashes between conservatives and liberals, and by the realism brought in by new plays and by education. The reform movement and the revolution against Spain made the educated attack the komedya even more, for being ignorant, unrealistic, and full of fantasy—and thus unable to purvey the truth expected of theater.

Tiongson sees a second flowering of the komedya in the 20th century. They were staged and revived in different regions—spreading where migration took their Ilocano and Cebuano writers/audiences (e.g., Mindanao); they confirmed and developed the form already set. The form waned, however, in some regions, like Manila, because of competition from more realistic forms, like the sarsuwela, and the impact of education and mass media.

Tiongson concludes that the komedya cannot be said to have died in Philippine theater. It is a traditional drama form that still flourishes in many regions at community level. It has been reshaped by modern perceptions and practices, and survives, and can well be called a de facto national form.

The book is illustrated with photographs and drawings old and new, and ends with an extensive bibliography and an appendix: the complete script of Comedia Famosa Vida de Atamante as written by Manuel Roque of Paete, Laguna, in 1910. Since few komedya were ever published and the Atamante story is so popular that it has versions in most regions, this is a treasure for the scholar.

The pioneering work does not only trace the history and development of the komedya but also shows the place taken by the komedya within community life, and its value as a theater form entrenched in Philippine folk perception and taste. It won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for literary criticism in 1983.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article_title: Komedya (Philippine Theatre: History and Anthology Volume II)
text:
Published 1999. Author, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Philippine Theatre: History and Anthology was originally planned as a five-volume series, introducing Philippine theater traditions to scholars, students, and academics in theater and performance studies, Philippine studies, literary studies, art studies, area studies, and other related disciplines. Of the five proposed volumes, the University of the Philippines Press published two in 1999: Volume II: Komedya and Volume III: Sinakulo.

The second volume is dedicated to the komedya, a theatrical form introduced by the Spaniards during the colonization of the islands and whose plots generally revolve around the sociocultural and religious conflicts of the Christians and the Muslims in medieval Europe. To date, this volume is the only academic reference providing a comprehensive historical account and descriptive information about this traditional theater form. The book is divided into three parts: the first part consisting of a general essay on the komedya and the next two parts devoted to the introduction and documentation of two present-day komedya performances in the regions: (1) a komedya de santo, or komedya on the life of a saint; and (2) a komedya/moro-moro, or komedya highlighting the conflict between Christians and Moors.

The general essay presents a comprehensive introduction to the form discussing the history, script, production, themes, and contemporary productions of the komedya. In the historical overview, Tiongson traces its origins to the Hispanic comedia, illustrates how the comedia was transformed or Filipinized into the Tagalog komedya, and how it eventually spread to the different regions. This section ends with a descriptive narration of the komedya’s survival throughout the archipelago despite the rise of the sarsuwela (a musical form also introduced by the Spaniards) and drama in the first decades of the 20th century and the coming of modernity in the islands.

Section 2 is a general overview of the orihinal, the script of the komedya. It discusses the main sources of the komedya—namely, the awit and korido or metrical romances, from which the komedya derived both its stories, verse forms, and colonial messages—and the staple characters of the komedya, which present a strict hierarchy on both the Christian and Muslim sides. It ends with a definition and illustration of the two types of komedya: the religious, which could focus on the life of a saint, an episode in the life of Christ, or a miracle wrought by a saint or holy figure; and the secular komedya, or moro-moro, which could narrate the search for the Santa Cruz by Elena and Constantino, the love and conflict between princes and princesses of warring kingdoms, and stories based on Philippine legends, history, or contemporary characters and events.

In section 3, Tiongson focuses on the production aspects of the komedya, beginning with the financing and management by individuals and groups who were key figures during a fiesta celebration. These include the hermano (or hermana if female) and the comite de festijos, who sponsor a komedya during a fiesta as the community’s offering to their patron saint. Important staging techniques peculiar to the komedya are introduced: single sets whose changes are decorated with specific props, costumes defining religion and hierarchy, magia (the magical effects), dicho (the delivery of lines), batalla (choreographed war dances), the grand marcha for Christians and Moors, the pasa doble for entrances, and torneo (duel fighting).

In section 4, Tiongson provides a preliminary close reading of persistent themes—the traditional conflict between the Christians and the Muslims, and the authoritarian and colonial messages of the komedya. Here, he also explains the reasons for the decline of the komedya’s popularity, particularly in relation to the sarsuwela.

Section 5 discusses the revitalization of the komedya with positive messages and effective staging techniques by Tanghalang Pilipino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the Komedya ng San Dionisio in Parañaque City. In concluding the general essay, Tiongson proposes that the komedya—with its 400-year-old history, wide distribution over the archipelago, continuous performances in the islands, and continued revitalization in content and form—is a pillar of Filipino national theater.

The second and third parts of the book are detailed expositions of current komedya performances in the regions, including introductory essays, performance photographs, details of the marcha and musical scores, and the orihinal in the original vernaculars supplemented by English translations.

Exemplifying the komedya de santo is the Comedia de San Miguel, popularly known as the yawa-yawa, performed annually in Iligan City in the Mindanao region during the community’s fiesta for San Miguel on Sep 29. The play, as stated in the introduction by Tiongson and Steven Patrick Fernandez, focuses on the story of San Miguel (Saint Michael)—specifically, on the conflict between Lusbel (loosely translated as Lucifer) and San Miguel. The introduction documents in detail its history, script, production techniques, and significance in the community. Supplementing the essay is a series of performance photographs from the 1992 and 1981 productions. Six performance scores are also presented, including the marcha for Lusbel and San Miguel, and the lively dance of the devils. The bulk of this part is the complete orihinal actually performed in 1992, with annotations by Tiongson. The Cebuano text is juxtaposed with an English translation by Fernandez.

The third and final part of the book presents the arakyo, a moro-moro type komedya performed in Peñaranda and other towns of Nueva Ecija. A reenactment of the search of Reyna Elena and her son Constantino for the Santa Cruz or Holy Cross upon which Christ was nailed and died, the arakyo is performed yearly during the month of May on a stage roofed with coconut fronds. The introductory essay by Tiongson explains the history, script, production techniques, and social and personal meaning of the arakyo. Thirty-six scores used for the marcha, pasadoble, and dances are also presented, including folk songs like “Bahay Kubo” and popular tunes like “Wooden Heart.” Supplementing the discussion of this komedya are 17 photographs, 16 of which are from the 1986 production and one from the 1984 production. The performance text of the arakyo documents the 1986 performance, with annotations by Tiongson and juxtaposed with English translation in verse by Edgardo Maranan.  Written by Sir Anril P. Tiatco

article_title: The Likhaan Book of Philippine Drama 1991-1996: From Page to Stage
text:
Published 2000. Editor, Anton Juan. Quezon City: The Likhaan Creative Writing Center and the University of the Philippines Press.

The book is a collection of five full-length plays staged from 1991 to 1996. The authors are not only established and multi-awarded playwrights but active participants in the whole theater process, from writing the text to staging the plays, either as actors, directors, “writer-in-stambay” (on standby), members of the production crew, staff, or a combination of these roles. The book reveals the collaborative practices between the authors and directors or among other theater practitioners in translating the text into corporeal stories and images. It also describes the cycle of the playwrights’ work when, after unfurling their pieces on stage, they return to the page and revise the script as mounted.

In his introductory essay “Take Five,” Anton Juan declares that the pieces are selected “for their significance as Philippine dramatic literature and for their impact on audiences as theatre realizations from a text,” thereby extending the scrutiny of the theater process up to the level of the audience. Play reviews attached at the end of each script validate the importance of the plays included in the collection as well as supplement and enrich the discussion from different perspectives.

The collection includes National Artist for literature (posthumous) Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Ulilang Tahanan (Forsaken House), written in 1939, about a family plagued by a succession of domestic problems stemming from the patriarch’s refusal to listen to his children; Floy Quintos’s … And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, a recreation and commentary of the historic Saint Louis Exposition in Missouri, where indigenous Filipinos were displayed as savages; Chris Millado’s Scenes from an Unfinished Country, structured as a play-within-a-play about Filipino-Americans discovering their identity in the process of restaging the classic play Hindi Aco Patay (I Am Not Dead) by Juan Matapang Cruz; Elsa Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House, set in wartime Dumaguete, about a respected and tightly knit family trying to preserve its code of honor during the Japanese occupation; and Arturo Calo’s (Auraeus Solito) Ang Maikling Buhay ng Apoy (The Short Life of Fire), a complicated merging of myth and indigenous ritual into mythopoetics, first performed outside of the conventional theater—among the ancient trees of University of the Philippines Diliman.

Juan evaluates the aesthetics of the plays vis-à-vis their sociohistorical contexts and the histories of the plays themselves. In treading these histories, Juan also traces the histories of the playwrights, highlighting the most significant parts of their lives and careers, their influences, inspirations, and poetics.

The book is a major contribution to Philippine theater for having documented the creative processes of five of its best playwrights, among them a National Artist for theater.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

In his introductory essay “Take Five,” Anton Juan declares that the pieces are selected “for their significance as Philippine dramatic literature and for their impact on audiences as theatre realizations from a text,” thereby extending the scrutiny of the theater process up to the level of the audience. Play reviews attached at the end of each script validate the importance of the plays included in the collection as well as supplement and enrich the discussion from different perspectives.

The collection includes National Artist for literature (posthumous) Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Ulilang Tahanan (Forsaken House), written in 1939, about a family plagued by a succession of domestic problems stemming from the patriarch’s refusal to listen to his children; Floy Quintos’s … And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, a recreation and commentary of the historic Saint Louis Exposition in Missouri, where indigenous Filipinos were displayed as savages; Chris Millado’s Scenes from an Unfinished Country, structured as a play-within-a-play about Filipino-Americans discovering their identity in the process of restaging the classic play Hindi Aco Patay (I Am Not Dead) by Juan Matapang Cruz; Elsa Coscolluela’s In My Father’s House, set in wartime Dumaguete, about a respected and tightly knit family trying to preserve its code of honor during the Japanese occupation; and Arturo Calo’s (Auraeus Solito) Ang Maikling Buhay ng Apoy (The Short Life of Fire), a complicated merging of myth and indigenous ritual into mythopoetics, first performed outside of the conventional theater—among the ancient trees of University of the Philippines Diliman.

Juan evaluates the aesthetics of the plays vis-à-vis their sociohistorical contexts and the histories of the plays themselves. In treading these histories, Juan also traces the histories of the playwrights, highlighting the most significant parts of their lives and careers, their influences, inspirations, and poetics.
The book is a major contribution to Philippine theater for having documented the creative processes of five of its best playwrights, among them a National Artist for theater.
Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: The Linambay of Linao: A Study of Theater as Ritual
text:
MA thesis. Author, Ma. Cristina J. Martinez. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

The thesis underscores the ritual characteristic and function of theater in society, particularly the linambay of Linao. The study hinges on two main assumptions: that there is a wealth of “indigenous modes of production to be tapped and documented,” and that there is a “need for a theoretical framework or synthesizing thread” that would tie the loose materials of the said literary modes into a coherent whole.” Martinez notes that Linao’s linambay tradition possesses the two essential traits of an ordinary ritual: that a myth serves as a justification of its performance; and that it is performed regularly using what Martinez calls “established patterns of tradition mandated by communal rule.”

The study is divided into six chapters, with each discussing and reflecting on what is ritualistic in Linao’s linambay tradition, theatrical performances, and literary texts in general. A chapter is also devoted to the discussion of the genesis of Linao’s linambay tradition. The study’s appendices contain sample texts and a translation of Francisco Tugonon’s play Altivo (1920, 1936, 1946).

Chapter 1 establishes the theoretical lens of the study. It argues that the study of theater as ritual should involve the use of tools from cultural anthropology, folk history, and folk religion in order to construct a supratext combining the linambay (text) and Linao (context). The use of such tools leads Martinez to the conclusion that the linambay tradition of Linao is indeed performed as a ritual. Chapter 2 serves both as an introduction to the moro-moro of Cebu and Leyte and an attempt to trace the origins of Linao’s linambay tradition. Here, Martinez describes the historical and societal contexts that served as catalysts for the emergence of linambay in Linao. These contexts also serve as the linambay’s links to the moro-moro tradition of Cebu and Leyte. Chapter 3 explains the evolution of Linao’s linambay as a village ritual, an activity that manifests a people’s solidarity. The chapter comprises four subsections, each focusing on a specific aspect of ritual production, mythmaking, and folk social organization.

Chapters 4 and 5 are both further expositions of Martinez’s claim that theater and literary texts can be read and experienced as rituals. Chapter 4 identifies what is ritualistic in the staging, directing, acting, and lighting of Linao’s linambay tradition. Martinez asserts that audience participation is also a crucial part of the ritual. She implies that the production of linambay is an endeavor where reception has more credence than artistic production itself. This, according to Martinez, explains the persistence of the tradition’s anachronistic and formulaic elements, which can be traced back to a privileging of function over form. Chapter 5, on the other hand, illustrates how literary conventions are themselves also rituals that are carried over via repetition of themes, motifs, characters, and plot structures.

Chapter 6 synthesizes the four perspectives brought forth in the course of the study. The chapter is divided into four subsections, each representing a specific perspective—namely, “Ritual versus Social Structure,” “The Power of Reception over Creation,” “The Power of Folk Assimilation,” and “An Ethno-religious Perception of a Folk Hero.”

Harnessing literary and anthropological tools of analysis, the study is significant for its attempt to establish the relationship between indigenous modes of literary production and the prevailing material conditions that circumscribe them.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: The Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela (1899-1977): History and Aesthetics
text:
Published 2007. Author, Clarita C. Filipinas. Tacloban City: Divine Word University Publications.

The book is a comprehensive historical survey of the Lineyte-Samarnon sarsuwela and an attempt to outline its structure and formal elements. Drawing from interviews with Leyte and Samar’s sarsuwela directors, producers, patrons, playwrights, actors and actresses, stage and production crew, and viewers, Filipinas was able to make full use of oral history to delineate the aesthetics of the Lineyte-Samarnon sarsuwela as a folk dramatic form and establish the significance of the tradition to both its participants and audience as a form of communal bonding.

The book has five chapters. Chapter 1, “The Cultural Context,” gives readers a historical backdrop of the region, its cultural history, linguistic situation, and literary scene. Filipinas identifies the historical and cultural factors, such as Spanish colonialism and local political upheavals, that served as catalysts for the emergence of the Lineyte-Samarnon sarsuwela.

Chapter 2, “A Historical Survey of the Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela,” explores the different aspects of the Lineyte-Samarnon traditions in its three sections. The first focuses on the representative playwrights of the Lineyte-Samarnon tradition: Norberto Romualdez, Iluminado Lucente, Francisco Alvarado, Emilio Andrada Sr, Jesus Ignacio, Margarita Nonato, Pedro Separa, Pedro Acerden, Eduardo Hilbano, Moning Fuentes, Generoso Nuevas, Augustin El. O’Mora, and Virginio Fuentes. The second section identifies the common themes tackled in the sarsuwela, such as domestic matters, romantic tropes, the role of women at home and in the community, and patriotic and political issues. The last section compiles additional notes and observations about the Lineyte-Samarnon tradition.

Chapter 3, “The Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela: Structure and Production,” also has three sections. The first is a description and a comparative analysis of the structure of Lineyte-Samarnon one-act plays, drama nga kinantahan (musical drama), sarsuwela, and songs. The second section focuses on the aspects of production of the Lineyte-Samarnon sarsuwela, such as financing, direction, rehearsals, the theater and stage, backstage personnel, music, props, special effects and lighting, costumes and makeup, intermission numbers, and publicity. The last section highlights the dialectical relationship between the sarsuwela’s structure and its mode of production.

Chapter 4, “The Aesthetics of the Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela,” is the author’s attempt to arrive at what she claims are the “folk aesthetics” of the Lineyte-Samarnon. The chapter has three sections, each discussing the points of view of the playwright, the actors, and the audience about the relevance of the sarsuwela.

Chapter 5, “The Lineyte-Samarnon Zarzuela World,” links the fiesta tradition in Leyte and Samar to dramatic presentations on open-air stages built in the town or church plazas. Filipinas argues that the Lineyte-Samarnon zarzuela is a “theatrical spectacle” that aims to entertain guests from neighboring barrios, towns, cities, and local residents as well.

The book has an appendix which contains the Filipino translation of the zarzuela Pipang, ca. 1918, by Alfonso Cinco, a love story that tackles the roles of women in their respective communities and how social institutions, like the family, shape them.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Moryon: Panata sa Likod ng Maskara
text:
(Moryon: The Oath Behind the Mask). 2002. MA thesis. Author, Danilo L. Mandia. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Danilo Mandia’s study traces the development of the pagmomoryon (the act of being a moryon) from the panata or solemn and secret oath of suffering to the Poong Maikapal (Lord Creator) to the “open offering” (“pakita sa tao”) and “show” (“pakitang-tao”), as practiced in the town of Boac, Marinduque. Modernization, commercialization, and the entry of political interests are key factors in the evolution of the traditional pagmomoryon.

Chapter 1 defines the moryon —from the Spanish morion, meaning “helmet”—and the cultural system it embodies. The moryon or pagmomoryon is a spiritual tradition in Marinduque characterized by an oath of penance, similar to that of Christ’s suffering—done as an act of thanksgiving for a good harvest, for deliverance from calamity, or for the granting of personal wishes. For seven days during Lent (except Good Friday), the moryon, usually the menfolk, take to the streets wearing colorful improvised costumes and the moryon mask, carved from the dapdap wood, playing the Roman soldiers who crucified Christ on Pilate’s orders. Central to the pagmomoryon is the character Longhino (Longinus), the Roman soldier who pierced Christ’s body and later converted to Christianity after the miraculous healing of his blind eye. Longhino’s martyrdom is dramatized in the spectacular pugutan (beheading).

In chapter 2, Mandia locates the pagmomoryon in its performance site, the island of Marinduque. Rituals done in consonance with the pagmomoryon are the tubong, singing to celebrate a child’s 7th or 18th birthday; the kalutang, playing the bamboo instruments used for the pugutan; the antipo, flagellation as a vow for wellness through penitence; and the habulan, the chase of Longhino by Roman soldiers.

Chapter 3 unravels the origin of Longhino through a survey of local materials that mention the character, such as souvenir programs, news articles, and the texts of the Pasiong Mahal, which Mandia asserts is the main source of the script of the pugutan. Mandia also details the traditional pugutan ritual of the 1960s and 1970s.

In chapter 4, Mandia traces the moryon’s development in Marinduque during the tenure of Fr Dionisio Santiago in 1870. Local narratives reveal changes in the tradition from the 1960s to the 1990s, indicating as major factors political interests, popular participation, the inclusion of non-Marinduqueños, and the commercialization of the moryon. Traditionally, the moryon’s identity was undisclosed until after the pugutan, when the community joined Longhino in his celebration. Nowadays, actors who portray Longhino and other known characters might be namedropped by townsfolk through word of mouth. The pugutan script has undergone treatment by well-known playwrights and rehearsed for big productions. Once done in front of houses or any open place, the pugutan is now enacted on a specific stage prepared by sponsors, with other spaces like the church set up for the chase. The pugutan is enhanced by technological innovation, such as elevated stages and sound systems. Rich political patrons even sponsor prizes for the best costume and accessories. Organizations have been put up by the local government to support the pagmomoryon. Commercial activity booms during festival season, and the once solemn and private panata has become a tourist attraction.

Chapter 5 compares the pagmomoryon to the ritual of theater, where an actor embodies his character and piously prepares to impart the message of the work. The moryon solemnly prepares for his oath by creating his own mask, designed according to his own personal predilection. He articulates his own being, and realizes his oath to suffering as within the sanctity of his pagkatawo (being). He is then able to create a world that is apart from the rest—leaving behind his earthly responsibilities to exclusively bear the physical suffering and social estrangement of becoming a moryon. After seven days, the moryon returns to the world as a bagong tawo (new person), marked by the pagtitikwas ng maskara (lifting of the mask) to the sky to face the Poong Maikapal.

Mandia’s study also includes short descriptions of the pagmomoryon as practiced in other parts of the island, photographs of the pagmomoryon showcasing the changes through time, as well as transcriptions of interviews with locals who have witnessed the evolution of the pagmomoryon.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

article_title: Mula sa Pakpak ng Entablado: Poetika ng Dulaang Kababaihan
text:
(From the Wings of the Stage: Poetics of Women’s Theater). Published 2006. Author, Joi Barrios. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book, based on Barrios’s doctoral dissertation, theorizes on the poetics of Filipino women’s theater using archival, empirical, and post-structuralist methodologies in feminist research. Analyzing approximately 100 stage plays produced by different theater groups across the country, written by both men and women in English, Filipino, and other regional languages since the early 1900s, the author traces the history of women’s theater in the Philippines, weaving it with the tapestry of popular cultural texts—among which are religious texts, conduct books, popular films, romance novels, cookbooks, and greeting cards—that discourse on the problematiques of Filipino womanhood.

Chapter 1, “Kung Bakit Kailangang Hanapin at Pag-aralan si Ginang Cruz o ang Mandudulang Babae” (Why It is Necessary to Search for and Study Mrs Cruz or the Woman Playwright-Dramatist), introduces Mrs Cruz, the playwright Juan Matapang Cruz’s wife who is speculated to be the real writer of the 1903 play Hindi Aco Patay (I Am Not Dead), as the allegorical figure of the female dramatist excluded from Philippine theater history. As such exclusion is maintained by the vast influence wielded by Aristotelian poetics on theatrical practice and, on a larger scale, by patriarchy in the Philippines, Barrios asserts the imperative of constructing the poetics of women’s theater in the Philippines. She then embarks on a discussion of talinghaga (metaphor) as the interpretive tool in analyzing social, political, and sexual discursive systems, which the women playwrights and their plays engage with, and interrogate. The chapter also features a survey of related researches on the field of feminist literature and Philippine theater, as well as the study’s scope, limitation, and organization.

Chapter 2, “Paglalandas sa Daang Tinahak ng Kababaihang Mandudula” (Traversing the Road Taken by Women Dramatists), chronicles the history of women’s multifarious involvements in Philippine theater. The author recovers this silenced history by tracing the roles women have variously assumed in different forms of theater practice that developed across Philippine history—from the indigenous shamans known as the babaylan who lead community rituals, the binukot who serve as the chroniclers of epic narratives, to the female dramatists of the 20th century who have been involved in various aspects of theater production like writing, acting, directing, and producing.

The next three chapters employ the talinghaga of space, character, and form, respectively, in analyzing the plays in relation to specific sociohistorical conditions, cultural texts, and practices that are implicated in and with the discursive regimes surrounding Filipino womanhood. Each critical discussion opens with the author’s reflections on her experiences as an actress, playwright, and director in various theatrical productions, like Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain) and Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Laban ng Basketball (A Basketball Match).

Chapter 3, “Entablado, Espasyo, at Heograpiya bilang Talinghaga” (Stage, Space, and Geography as Metaphor), foregrounds how the stage (re)presents metaphorical spaces that define and are defined by the discursive systems that frame the concept and experience of Filipino womanhood. Reading plays like Ritchie Valencia-Buenaventura’s June Bride, Glecy Atienza’s Lutong Bahay (Home-Cooked Meal), and Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsiyon (Anatomy of Corruption), the author demonstrates how the kitchen, the factory, the office, the forests, and the mountains (re)present spaces where women enact different responses to the oppressiveness of patriarchy—from the decision to escape the space of domestic confinement to the act of participating in larger sociopolitical struggles.

In chapter 4, “Ang Tauhan bilang Talinghaga, Ilang Tala ng Isang Artista” (The Character as Metaphor, Some Notes of an Artist), the author undertakes a close reading of plays, like Atang de la Rama’s Anak ni Eva/Ang Aking Ina (Daughter of Eva/My Mother), Lualhati Bautista’s Lorena, and Barrios’s own Damas de Noche (Women of the Night), to unravel the complex discourses on womanhood that are ushered in by female archetypes in theater. Her discussions on the metaphorical significance of the weeping mother as the Inangbayan (Motherland), the revolutionary woman, the silenced/silent woman in the family, the barren woman, the prostitute, and the phantom rape victim offer critical interventions on the problem and potential of female agency in the face of physical, linguistic, moral, and political violence.

Chapter 5, titled “Ang Anyo bilang Talinghaga, Ilang Tala ng Isang Mandudula” (The Form as Metaphor, Some Notes of a Dramatist), presents critical discussions of plays, like Kantada ng Babaing Mandirigma (Song of the Female Warrior) by Merlinda Bobis, Magdalena Jalandoni’s Ang Anak nga Malalison (The Wayward Daughter), Saturnina Rodil’s Datu Matu, and Luna Sicat’s Maternal, to foreground how form functions as metaphor. The author’s investigation of the plays’ appropriation and subversion of generic conventions derived from other forms, like the epic narrative, the horror story, and the historical play, emphasizes that feminist theater must be transformative to enable the woman dramatist to transcend mere exposition of the issues surrounding womanhood in the Philippines and actualize the emancipatory possibilities embedded in the poetics and practice of the craft.

The book’s significance primarily lies on the author’s discovery and recovery of the metaphorical Mrs Cruz by foregrounding the absent presence of the female in Philippine theater. The project’s imagination and articulation of the poetics of feminist theater present a significant revaluation of theater as an important discursive realm through and in which the complex struggles of womanhood in the Philippines are staged. This book was a finalist in the 2006 National Book Awards.  Written by L M Castillo, with notes from Lilia Quindoza-Santiago

The author recovers this silenced history by tracing the roles women have variously assumed in different forms of theater practice that developed across Philippine history—from the indigenous shamans known as the babaylan who lead community rituals, the binukot who serve as the chroniclers of epic narratives, to the female dramatists of the 20th century who have been involved in various aspects of theater production like writing, acting, directing, and producing.

The next three chapters employ the talinghaga of space, character, and form, respectively, in analyzing the plays in relation to specific sociohistorical conditions, cultural texts, and practices that are implicated in and with the discursive regimes surrounding Filipino womanhood. Each critical discussion opens with the author’s reflections on her experiences as an actress, playwright, and director in various theatrical productions, like Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Bundok (The Mountain) and Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s Laban ng Basketball (A Basketball Match).

Chapter 3, “Entablado, Espasyo, at Heograpiya bilang Talinghaga” (Stage, Space, and Geography as Metaphor), foregrounds how the stage (re)presents metaphorical spaces that define and are defined by the discursive systems that frame the concept and experience of Filipino womanhood. Reading plays like Ritchie Valencia-Buenaventura’s June Bride, Glecy Atienza’s Lutong Bahay (Home-Cooked Meal), and Malou Jacob’s Anatomiya ng Korupsiyon (Anatomy of Corruption), the author demonstrates how the kitchen, the factory, the office, the forests, and the mountains (re)present spaces where women enact different responses to the oppressiveness of patriarchy—from the decision to escape the space of domestic confinement to the act of participating in larger sociopolitical struggles.

In chapter 4, “Ang Tauhan bilang Talinghaga, Ilang Tala ng Isang Artista” (The Character as Metaphor, Some Notes of an Artist), the author undertakes a close reading of plays, like Atang de la Rama’s Anak ni Eva/Ang Aking Ina (Daughter of Eva/My Mother), Lualhati Bautista’s Lorena, and Barrios’s own Damas de Noche (Women of the Night), to unravel the complex discourses on womanhood that are ushered in by female archetypes in theater. Her discussions on the metaphorical significance of the weeping mother as the Inangbayan (Motherland), the revolutionary woman, the silenced/silent woman in the family, the barren woman, the prostitute, and the phantom rape victim offer critical interventions on the problem and potential of female agency in the face of physical, linguistic, moral, and political violence.

Chapter 5, titled “Ang Anyo bilang Talinghaga, Ilang Tala ng Isang Mandudula” (The Form as Metaphor, Some Notes of a Dramatist), presents critical discussions of plays, like Kantada ng Babaing Mandirigma (Song of the Female Warrior) by Merlinda Bobis, Magdalena Jalandoni’s Ang Anak nga Malalison (The Wayward Daughter), Saturnina Rodil’s Datu Matu, and Luna Sicat’s Maternal, to foreground how form functions as metaphor. The author’s investigation of the plays’ appropriation and subversion of generic conventions derived from other forms, like the epic narrative, the horror story, and the historical play, emphasizes that feminist theater must be transformative to enable the woman dramatist to transcend mere exposition of the issues surrounding womanhood in the Philippines and actualize the emancipatory possibilities embedded in the poetics and practice of the craft.

The book’s significance primarily lies on the author’s discovery and recovery of the metaphorical Mrs Cruz by foregrounding the absent presence of the female in Philippine theater. The project’s imagination and articulation of the poetics of feminist theater present a significant revaluation of theater as an important discursive realm through and in which the complex struggles of womanhood in the Philippines are staged. This book was a finalist in the 2006 National Book Awards.
Written by L M Castillo, with notes from Lilia Quindoza-Santiago

article_title: Negros Occidental 1970-1986: The Fall of the Sugar Industry and the Rise of People's Theater
text:
PhD diss. Author, Rosario Cruz-Lucero. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Framing theater as a cultural embodiment of the material structure of a community, the study traces the rise of the people’s theater during the collapse of the sugar industry, which maintained the hacienda cultural hegemony. After outlining the study in chapter 1, Lucero discusses its theoretical framework in chapter 2.

Chapter 3 contextualizes the Negros sugar industry in the colonial and neocolonial economic history of the Philippines. The hacienda culture ensures the position of the amo (plantation owner) as god, assuring him of the workers’ obedience and respect at all times. He makes sure that the plantation workers survive the lean months by, for instance, providing them a steady supply of rice called the consumo. But the collapse of the sugar industry forced the plantation owner to stop the consumo, thus removing himself from his position and forcing the plantation workers to provide for themselves. This economic disturbance resulted in the disturbance of the workers’ belief system itself. Thus, whatever was deemed right or just in the hacienda cultural system became untenable. The Catholic Church, through the Basic Christian Communities and the National Federation of Sugar Workers, provided alternative belief systems.

In chapter 4, Lucero traces the beginning of the people’s theater in Negros to the founder of Katilingban sa Katubuhan (Community Theater in Sugarland), Luisa Reyes, who taught speech and drama at La Consolacion College in Bacolod City. Fr Alan Abadeco, a former member of Reyes’s drama class, put up the Pagbutlak (Sunrise) theater group. When Bishop Antonio Fortich called for a more active diocesan youth movement, Abadesco organized Teatro Pangkatilingban (TP). TP succeeded in mobilizing the Negros youth within a year (1977-78), as attested by its 27 chapters, 591 members, and a total of 59 cultural productions. However, political and military repression pushed TP to later abolish most of its chapters. Teatro Obrero (TO) was then organized, involving the politicized youth of the organized hacienda. Within eight months, TO ballooned to 120 chapters with 3,000 members. Negros Theater League (NTL) was organized in 1983, with Joel R. Arbolario as chairman, at the end of a Philippine Educational Theater Association-conducted workshop attended by 34 representatives of 16 theater groups all over Negros.

Chapter 5 analyzes five plays. TP’s Hacienda de Premiero: Mga Obrero nga Wala Nagahugpong Magadugang sa Kapiguson (Hacienda de Premiero: Workers Who Do Not Unite Intensify Oppresion), 1978, is a 15-minute dramatic sketch detailing the friction between owners and the amo over idle lands occupied and utilized by the workers. Ang Gutom sang Negros (Hunger in Negros), 1979, similar to a one-act play in length but not in structure, analyzes the societal causes of hunger. Gutom sang Banwa (Hunger in the Country), 1982, is a revision of the former with a more national perspective. NTL’s Sang Matapungawan si Lito Estudiante (When Lito Estudiante Went Mad), 1985, a dula-tula (play-poem), chronicles the discovery of Lito, a boy from the barrio who goes to the city to study, that real learning comes not just from books but from the people’s experiences. Lito eventually returns to the barrio and joins the armed struggle as solution to the poverty of the people. The chapter ends with an analysis of Tiempos Muertos (The Dead Season), 1987, a docu-drama with an episodic structure that illustrates the different facets of the Negros workers’ life.

Chapter 6, the final chapter, offers a theory of a people’s theater, specifying its two tasks as (a) the unmasking of the means by which power is maintained in the society, and (b) the affirmation of an alternative culture. Lucero argues that the people’s theater is always necessary as it sustains the people’s struggle, with its continuing creation of symbolic forms articulating the solidarity of the working class.

The study includes scripts, transcriptions from tapes of theatrical productions, letters, statements, reports, resolutions and newsletters, and interviews with key persons. Among the appendices are letters, a brief description of the Makiisa-Negros Theater Festival, the list of theater group participants, the plays staged during the three-day festival, the titles and forms of the plays produced by NTL (1983-88), and the script of Arbolario’s Tiempos Muertos. The study provides the only existing account of the rise of the Negros people’s theater in Philippine literary history.  Written by Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza
