article_title: Noticias Historicobibliograficas De El Teatro En Filipinas Desde Sus Origenes Hasta 1898
text:
(Historical and Bibliographical Notes on the Philippine Theater from Its Origins to 1898). Published 1909. Author, Wenceslao E. Retana. Madrid: Libreria General de Victoriano Suarez.

Retana’s Noticias Historico - Bibliograficas de el Teatro en Filipinas des desus Origenes hasta 1898 is the earliest history of Philippine theater that is reliable, scholarly, and thoroughly researched. Retana begins his inquiry by seeking proofs of pre-Hispanic theater, and considering the two works that precede his: Vicente Barrantes’s El Teatro Tagalo, 1889, and the series of 16 articles by Juan Atayde in La Ilustracion Filipina , 1892-93. The former uses arguments rather than documents, he concludes; the latter are enumerations of theater spectacles rather than historical investigations. Drawing from concrete data, Retana comes to the conclusion that there is no proof that the Tagalog had “ representacion escenica ” (stage presentation) before 1571, not recognizing as theater “a type of farce and playlet in which local customs are criticized,” nor the rituals, ceremonies, songs, dances, and mimetic games mentioned in accounts.

From there he proceeds to examine just as thoroughly the evidence of Hispanic theater in the Philippines: verbal and written accounts, published or unpublished, of performances, feasts and feasting, theaters, religious and civic events, theater troupes, organizations, playwrights, artists, newspapers, criticism, and the like. He is a compleat bibliographer and examines painstakingly all printed material, providing footnotes that are themselves a rich source for research.

When the account moves into his own era, the last decades of the 19th century, Retana turns critic as well. His accounts of the early Spanish theater in the country—including writers, works, and theaters like Francisco de P. Entrala and his Cuadros Filipinos (Filipino Portraits), 1882; Ricardo Castro Ronderos, Manuel Lorenzo d’Ayot, Manuel Romero, Camilo Millan, Eduardo Saavedra, and Eduardo Castañer; the Teatro Zorrilla and Teatro de Colon; Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (Beside the Pasig), 1880; and the first zarzuela written in Manila by Emilio and Rafael del Val—are detailed, evaluative, and fair. He is able to so reconstruct a play—with cast lists, synopses, commentary, excerpts and, in the case of El Poder de Una Pasion (The Power of Passion), a script—that the contemporary reader is able to imagine the drama and the dramaturgy quite adequately. When he is not able to (not having been in the audience, or no program being available), he gives all data possible: author, title, date and time of performance, cast, synopsis, audience response.

In many cases, as in that of the famous cancan, “sin reservas, tan sin reservas, que no pocos señores graves cerraron los ojos” (so uninhibited, so unrestrained that not a few grave gentlemen closed their eyes), in Pascual Bailon, 1886, he conveys as well the atmosphere of the theater world—the leadership of the Church, which responded with a pastoral letter; the reactions of the community leaders and those of the general public who filled the house nightly.

Retana ends his book with a 26th chapter on Jose Felipe del Pan and La Oceania Española, the newspaper in which he published translations of Corneille, Goethe, Molière, Schiller, and Shakespeare, and plays by Calderon de la Barca, Lope de Vega, Agustin de Moreto, Francisco Rojas Zorrilla, and Tirso de Molina. He concludes that pre-Hispanic literature had been a “child of exoticism and fantasy” but was changing, since authors like Severino Reyes were now writing works based on reality. Allowing for the blinders of colonialism, Retana’s work is the most valuable source book extant on theater in the Philippines before 1909, the year of its publication.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

article_title: Onstage and Offstage
text:
Published 1983. Author, Jean G. Edades. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

Onstage and Offstage is Jean G. Edades’s theater memoir, which begins with her early childhood exposure to theater in Minnesota and her professional training in Chicago, and deals mainly with her many years of experience as drama teacher and director in the Philippines. She began teaching freshman English and world drama at the University of the Philippines (UP) in 1928, and was director of the UP Dramatic Club for 10 years, producing full-length Western drama and one-act Filipino plays in English, notably the annual Heroes Day plays on campus and at the Manila Grand Opera House. She established a dramatic club at Arellano University when she transferred there in the 1950s; she did the same at Silliman University in the 1960s. Her memoir includes productions with other drama groups in different venues, such as the new Ateneo Auditorium and the new Metropolitan Theater, and the movie houses during the Japanese occupation.

For part 2 of the book, Edades selected five one-act plays in the 1930s and 1940s from her previous anthologies, and one from the 1960s. Educating Josefina, a satire by Lilia A. Villa for Edades’s playwriting class, is about a daughter adopting modern city manners, to the dismay of her parents. At the Turn of the Road by Natividad O. Hizon Castro is about a father who chooses to support a son’s law studies in the city instead of the older son’s preference for agriculture. In Domingo F. Nolasco’s A Ranger Takes a Wife, the ranger’s proposal succeeds when his friend, posing as the forestry director, heaps praise on him to impress the girl’s father. The Best Way to Die, which Benjamin B. Wong wrote in Edades’s freshman English class, presents several characters’ opinions on dying. In Manuel E. Buenafe’s The Resignation, a teacher in conflict with his supervisor considers resigning and returning to his farm in the barrio. In Blast of the ‘Bugle, ’ A. Oliver Flores uses the account of a newspaper editor’s assassination in 1960 to dramatize the pressure on an editor to apologize and retract his news story on a congressman.

Edades’s “Pointers for the Teacher Director” is included as an appendix. Originally published in The Philippine Teacher’s Digest in Feb 1940, the article aims to guide teachers in directing plays and developing students’ oral skills.

Onstage and Offstage is not only a valuable record of the theater of the time. It also gives evidence of Edades’s efforts in teaching stagecraft within the limitations of venue and budget, and in encouraging the writing of plays with Filipino themes, thus contributing significantly to the development of Philippine theater in English.  Written by Pacita C. Gavino

article_title: Palabas: Essays on Philippine Theater History
text:
Published 1996. Author, Doreen G. Fernandez. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The book gathers together 15 of Fernandez’s essays written, read, or published between 1978 and 1995 on different “forms and times” of Philippine theater. The introductory essay,“From Ritual to Realism,” traces the development of Philippine drama from the songs and dances of the precolonial past, to the staged comedia and religious plays of the Spanish colonial period, tothe “seditious plays,” musicals, and prose plays in English and in the vernaculars of the American years, to the multitude of forms—epic theater,s ocial realism, and psychological realism—produced since World War II.

The essays under the heading “Stages of Development: Forms and Times,” the bulk of the book, explain in greater detail the forms mentioned in the introduction. In “Indigenous Drama,” Fernandez legitimates the “panoply of rituals, verbal play, songs and dances”—disqualified as drama by Barrantes and Retana—as “native forms of mimesis or mimetic action.” “The Jesuits and EarlyTheater” presents the special role of the religious order in propagating staged drama during the Spanish colonial period. “Tradition and Revitalization in the Komedya” and “Zarzuela to Sarswela” describe the two rival forms in all their quaintness and continuing relevance. Formal conventions (of staging, line delivery, writing) are explained in the light of the worldviews, or systems of values, that these forms uphold, such as the equation of manhood with heroism and the irresistible power of love. “The ‘Seditious’ Plays” is an account of the works of Aurelio Tolentino and other playwrights deemed “seditious” by the American colonial government. The last four essays in this section assess contemporary drama. Fernandez explores the ingenuity of Filipino artists in hurdling boundaries of economy (by communal support, tradition) andof political repression (by allegory, indirection, use of historical and folk figures).

The section “In Close Focus: Texts and Performances” discuss a salubong (meeting), a komedya, and a modern realist play. Fernandez shows that the creative text is intertwined with contexts, whether personal, literary, or sociopolitical.

The two essays in “Noteson Criticism” pose questions affecting the study of Philippine drama and point out the paramount problem in Philippine criticism: personalism. Drawing on Rodin and Henry James, Fernandez defines the role of the criticas that of an intermediary between playwright and audience.

The two appendices in the book are as valuable as the essays themselves. In the first, Fernandez lists events from 1598 to 1995 that bear on Philippine drama—the premieres of landmark productions, the construction of theaters, the publication of significant criticism, and political developments. The second is a list of some 250 plays, from A Modern Filipina to An Maimbud na Aqui (The Gentle Child), from Gran Comedia de la Toma del Pueblo de Corralat y Conquista del Cerro (Grand Play on the Capture of the Town of Corralat and the Conquest of the Hill) to D.H.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Languages
text:
Published 1987. With introductions, translations, and notes in English by Wilhelmina Q. Ramas, Filonila M. Tupas, Alejandro J. Casambre, Marcelo C. Zamora, Maria Lilia F. Realubit, and Consuelo M. Damaso. Foreword by Wilhelmina Q. Ramas. Quezon City: NSTA-Assisted UPS Integrated Research Program “A,” University of the Philippines.

Originally planned as an anthology of drama from seven Philippine ethnolinguistic groups, the project eventually featured two plays each from six ethnolinguistic groups: Iloko, Pangasinan, Tagalog, Hiligaynon, Bikol, and Sugbuanon. The anthology, focusing on prewar drama, includes a sarsuwela and a non-sarsuwela, and the corresponding English translations, from each of the six groups. Anthologized are the Iloko Dalusapi by Filemon M. Tupas and Dallot (anonymous); the Pangasinense Say Quieoya Angapoy Serom (A Tree without Shade) by Aurelio Celestino and Kar-na-na (Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow) by Juan D. Santos; the Tagalog Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden) by Hermogenes E. Ilagan and R.I.P. by Severino Reyes; the Bikol Pagkamoot asin Cayamanan (Love and Wealth) by Asisclo Jimenez and Anti-Cristo (Anti-Christ) by Justino Nuyda; the Hiligaynon Nalayag cag Manalingsing (It Withered and Revived) by Jimeno Damaso and Damogohanon Manginamatu-od (When Dreams Come True) by Pedro F. Checa; and the Sugbuanon Balaod sa Kinabuhi (The Law of Life) by Buenaventura Rodriguez and Marianito by Pio A. Kabahar.

Only the manuscript of Dalusapi survived among the many sarsuwela written by Filemon Palafox, care of Dominador Madamba who served as the town drama and musical director of San Nicolas, Ilocos Norte. The sarsuwela gathers its audience around the character of Captain Tinong, Tisay’s father, who prefers Ardo, a wealthy friend’s son, for his daughter. Tisay, however, prefers the poor but literate and wise Banong. Captain Tinong’s character elicits laughter and condemnation for his uncontrollable gambling and poor judgment of people. Town elder Urbano helps Captain Tinong several times in the play and in the end reminds the audience of the ill effects of gambling. Celestino’s Say Quieoya Angapoy Serom, more serious in tone, intersperses songs exchanged between characters, and emphasizes education, perseverance, loyalty, and parental responsibility. Ilagan’s Dalagang Bukid ridicules authoritarian figures in society—adults, parents, and politicians. The abusive parents of the eponymous Angelita are both addicted gamblers and exploit their children by making them work to finance their vice. Angelita, however, bravely weds her beloved Cipriano against their wishes. Nuyda’s Anti-Cristo is a satirical play that ends with the killing of a Spanish friar by Felixberta, a maiden who rejects the friar’s sexual advances. Damaso’s Nalaya cag Manalingsing also chronicles a young woman’s defiance of her parents. Leonor maintains her love for Carlos despite her father’s objection to his poverty and unknown parentage. In Rodriguez’s Balaod sa Kinabuhi, Peping, the son of the rich, greedy, and unforgiving Señor Simon, stands not only against parental authority but also against the capital’s exploitation of workers. He leaves all for Maring, a woman whose house has been foreclosed by his father, works as a laborer at a dock, and goes on strike with her fellow laborers against their employer. Though Peping dies, his father is moved to change his ways.

Ramas’s foreword and each of the introductions suggest that the anthology is a work propelled by nationalism, which rallied many Filipino scholars in the 1960s and the 1970s. Although the project was conceptualized in 1973, the work of the respective researchers started in the late 1960s. The notion of the nation here is already that which embraces the regions. Looking for the nation in the literature of the regions, the researchers find that it is the drama that bares the culture of the people from the regions, because it is the form most acceptable to them.

The introductions are marked with references to the nation as one’s own with categories such as “native” or “indigenous,” and for the Other, “foreign” or “received.” Other categories focus on the formalism of the texts with the terms “proto-plays,” “early forms,” and “beginnings.” Encompassing the availability of data at the time of research and the period itself covered by the project, the introductions discuss at length the form and the production of the comedia and the zarzuela, finding in them the expression of a communitarian character. Lastly, they provide invaluable information on some of the most important playwrights during this period in the respective regions, with Ramas affording a separate section each on Buenaventura Rodriguez and Pio A. Kabahar. The book won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for drama in 1987.  Written by Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza

article_title: The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience
text:
Published 1984. Editor, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Introduction by Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: Philippine Educational Theater Association.

The book compiles the proceedings, as well as essays, poems, skits, and plays read and performed during the MAKIISA I People’s Culture Festival held at Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila on 28-30 Dec 1983. The anthology, as Tiongson puts it, “sums up the results of the interaction workshops held during the festival, including those on mime, music, visual arts, southern ethnic dance, people’s theater and children’s theater, and then describes the gallery of people’s art.” More importantly, the book aims to inform national and international readers about the state of culture in the Philippines during the martial law era—in particular, on how culture was used by the Marcos regime as a tool of deception and control. To counter such culture, the works featured during the festival and anthologized in the book represent and espouse what Tiongson calls a “new type of people’s culture.”

The anthology is divided into five sections, with each section focusing on a specific artistic form(s). The first section consists of symposia lectures held during the festival. It is further divided into three subsections—namely, “Literature and Mass Media,” “Visual Arts and Film,” and “Music and Theater.” Some of the notable lectures included in this section are Rosario Torres-Yu’s “The State of Philippine Literature,” Alice Guillermo’s “The State of Visual Arts,” and Fe Mangahas’s “The State of Philippine Music.” Reactors for these lectures included writers like Teo Antonio and Lualhati Bautista, artists like Jim Paredes and Felipe de Leon Jr, and critics such as Teresita Maceda and Sylvia Mayuga.

The second section, “Workshop and Matinee Shows,” collects the poems, songs, and skits performed during the festival. Some of the songs featured in the section are Jess Santiago’s “Halina” (Come), Heber Bartolome’s “Almusal” (Breakfast) and “Militarisasyon” (Militarization), and Heber Bartolome and J. Baez’s “Tagulaylay” (Song of Mourning) and “Awit ng Bayan Ko” (Song of my Motherland). Poems included in the section are Fidel Rillo’s “Uyayi” (Lullaby), Epifanio San Juan Jr’s “Isang Pangkaraniwang Pangyayari” (An Ordinary Occurence), and a suite of poems by Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. Scripts of skits included in this section are the Correspondents’ Association’s Ang Mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan Peryodista (The Amazing Adventures of Juan the Journalist), an adaptation of Jose F. Lacaba’s famous poem “Ang mga Kagila-gilalas na Pakikipagsapalaran ni Juan de la Cruz” (The Amazing Adventures of Juan de la Cruz); and Teatrong Mulat’s Ang Paghuhukom (The Trial).

The third section consists of film scripts from two films shown during the festival—CAVS Productions’ The Arrogance of Power, and Mike de Leon, Jose Lacaba, Sylvia Mayuga, Ding Achacoso, Joe Cuaresma, Lito Tiongson, and Jovy Zarate’s Signos (Signs).

The fourth section, “Festival of Plays,” anthologizes plays staged by various theater and cultural groups during the festival. These are Muog ng Lahi’s Maikling Kuwento ng Titser ng Bayan (A Short Story of the People’s Teacher), UP Peryante’s Ilokula, Part II, Negros Theater League’s Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), PETA Kalinangan Ensemble’s Oratoryo ng Bayan: Makabayang Deklarasyon ng Makataong Karapatan (People’s Oratorio: Nationalist Declaration of Human Rights), and Barasoain Kalinangan’s Masaker (Massacre). The final section, “Exhibit and Visual Arts Interaction,” is an attempt to synthesize the aim of the festival to occasion a collaboration among literary, performance, and visual artists toward the creation of a truly nationalist and mass-oriented culture.

The book is the only documentation of the blossoming of the people’s culture after the Aquino assassination in 1983. It won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for documentation in 1985.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: A Reader in Philippine Theater: History and Criticism; Essays in Honor of Nicanor G. Tiongson
text:
Published 2014. Editors, Jonathan Chua and Rosario Cruz-Lucero. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Comprising 16 essays by prominent literary critics, the book primarily serves as “a basic reference tool for the study of Philippine theater history, research methodologies, critical approaches, and its sources and influences; and as a primary reader for faculty and students of Philippine theater courses,” according to Cruz-Lucero in the introduction. It is also a festschrift for eminent theater and film scholar Nicanor G. Tiongson. The essays in the anthology are geared toward identifying and discussing the sociohistorical and cultural contexts that influenced the development of Philippine theater studies and practices.

The book is divided into three sections, with each part underscoring a particular aspect of theater scholarship in the Philippines. The first section, “Defining a Philippine National Theater,” is a survey of theater movements and practices that Cruz-Lucero defines as “conscious attempts to define a national theater.” Most essays contained in the section chronicle the development of theater practice and studies during the martial law period. Among the notable essays are Apolonio B. Chua’s “Orihinales: Panimulang Pagtala ng Danas sa Paghulma ng mga Dulang Tradisyunal nang Panahon ng Batas Militar” (Orihinales: A Preliminary Documentation of Experiences in Shaping Traditional Theater during the Martial Law Period), Karl M. Gaspar’s “Mayukmok: Militant Theater from the Margins, Liberating Theater from the Marginalized,” and Joi Barrios-Leblanc’s “Redefining Theater Spaces: Notes on Street Theater (2000-10).”

The second section, “Traditional Theater, The Theater Tradition,” comprises essays that focus on traditional and folk forms, particularly religious rituals. While field and archival research are highlighted in this section, present also are critical readings of these rituals as deconstruction of past and present dominant discourses in society. Some of the essays included in this section are Sir Anril P. Tiatco’s “Ang Via Crucis at ang Pagpapako sa Krus sa Cutud: Pagtatanghal ng Sakit, Pasakit, at Pagtubos” (The Via Crucis and the Crucifixion in Cutud: Performance of Pain, Suffering, and Salvation), Jerry Respeto’s “Ang Pagtatanghal ng mga Banal na Gawain sa mga Topograpiya ng Bayan ng Pakil” (The Presentation of Religious Practices in the Topography of the Town of Pakil), and Steven Fernandez’s “The San Miguel Rituals of Iligan City.”

The third section, “And the Work Continues,” synthesizes the two main themes of the anthology: the mapping of the development of the poetics of Philippine theater and the influence of Nicanor G. Tiongson’s scholarship and critical practice on past, present, and future theater practice and studies. The three essays in this section include Glecy Atienza’s “Buhay (!) Ang Patuloy na Pagsisinop ng Konsepto ng Dulang Filipino” (Life [!] The Continuing Study on the Concept of Filipino Theater), Basilio Villaruz’s “Dancing Decentralization,” and Jonathan Chua’s “Nicanor G. Tiongson, An Appreciation.”

As a whole, the collection reflects Tiongson’s vision and ethics as a scholar and cultural worker—nationalist, inclusive, and mass-oriented.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Ritwal: Sayaw-awit sa Lumang Makati; Isang Panata para kina San Pedro, San Pablo, at Virgen De La Rosa
text:
(Ritual: Dance-Song in Old Makati; A Devotion to San Pedro, San Pablo, and the Virgin of the Rose). Published 1994. Author, Ruby Gamboa Alcantara. Manila: Rex Book Store.

The book focuses on the ritual sayaw-awit (dance-song) performed by devotees of San Pedro, San Pablo, and Nuestra Señora de la Rosa or Virgen de la Rosa held every 29th and 30th of June in Old Makati. The study is based on observation and documentation of actual performances of the sayaw-awit in the Plaza of Cristo Rey, located in front of the San Pedro–San Pablo Church in Barrio Poblacion, Makati, in 1985 and 1986, as well as interviews of eight dancers who performed in 1985, and a number of residents of Barrio Poblacion.

Chapter 1 defines the key concepts used in the study, such as mimesis, ritual, context, and theater, and presents the objectives of the study, review of related literature, and structure of the book.

Chapter 2 begins with a brief history of Makati—from the time of Captain Pedro de Brito’s purchase of a big tract of land in 1589, up to the period when Makati became the country’s center of commerce, trade, and finance. It distinguishes two sides of Makati: the area of Makati Avenue, where buildings of prominent corporations and banks are located, and Old Makati, also known as Barrio Poblacion, where traditional and religious rituals, feasts, celebrations, and ceremonies are still observed. Various rituals and celebrations are performed throughout the year in Old Makati, but the ritual of sayaw-awit is singled out as the most anticipated and spirited religious event. The chapter introduces the organizers of the panata (devotion), the Atilon family. Alcantara traces the roots of Emiliano V. Atilon, head organizer of the panata then and the oldest living member of the Atilon clan, to Lorenza Victor-Ventura, or Lelang Enzang. As Lelang Enzang was born in 1835 and was a dancer for the ritual when she was a young woman, Alcantara deduces the beginnings of the sayaw-awit as prior to 1835. Alcantara explains that the Atilons’ stewardship of the panata pertains to the safekeeping of the text, music, and dance movements used in the ritual, as well as the teaching and training of the participants. Several wealthy families in Barrio Poblacion and in nearby barrios provide financial support for various expenses, such as clothes for the dancers and the statues of the saints, food, stage construction, music, and props.

Chapter 3 describes the structure and content of the panata, which comprises five parts: novena, misa (mass), prusisyon (procession), sayaw-awit sa plasa (dance-song in the plaza), and sayaw-awit sa bahay-bahay (house-to-house dance-song). The structure of the panata text is as follows: “Dicho sa Mahal na Virgen” (Homage to the Blessed Virgin), “Dicho kay San Pedro at San Pablo” (Homage to San Pedro and San Pablo), “Trono” (Throne), “Awit sa Mahal na Virgen” (Song for the Blessed Virgin), and “Awit kay San Pedro at San Pablo” (Song for San Pedro and San Pablo). Alcantara then describes in detail the costumes of the nine young female dancers, as well as their routine of 36 unique and nonrepeating steps. The singing part of the panata begins with the chanting of the first part, which leads to the singing of the verses with accompanying music. Various preparations for the performance of the sayaw-awit also take place, such as choosing the mananayaw (dancer), teaching the mananayaw the movements and songs, rehearsals, constructing the stage, borrowing statues of the three saints, preparing food for the dancers and musicians, and making the props.

Chapter 4 expounds on the significance of the sayaw-awit, particularly to the community that nurtures it. The performance of the ritual of sayaw-awit has become a means of teaching and transmitting attitudes and values that are preserved and protected. It is also a way of extending and strengthening social bonds in the community. Upholding the practices and traditions in the performance of the sayaw-awit consolidates and enriches the community and society.

The last part of the book is the appendix, comprising the profile of the nine dancers who performed in 1985 and 1986, pictures of actual performances on different years, text of the panata, and notations of dance and music.

The book is the first documentation of the ritual of sayaw-awit in Old Makati and proves that even in highly urbanized areas, such as Makati, Filipino cultural traditions endure.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

Upholding the practices and traditions in the performance of the sayaw-awit consolidates and enriches the community and society.

The last part of the book is the appendix, comprising the profile of the nine dancers who performed in 1985 and 1986, pictures of actual performances on different years, text of the panata, and notations of dance and music.
The book is the first documentation of the ritual of sayaw-awit in Old Makati and proves that even in highly urbanized areas, such as Makati, Filipino cultural traditions endure.
Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Ang Ritwal ng Pagpapako sa Krus: Panata at Dulaan sa Bawat Turok ng Pako
text:
(The Ritual of Crucifixion: Devotion and Theater in Every Pierce of the Nail). 2006. MA thesis. Author, Sir Anril P. Tiatco. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Sir Anril P. Tiatco’s masteral thesis introspects on the meanings and valuations related to the popular ritual pagpapako sa krus (crucifixion) performed every Good Friday in Cutud, Pampanga. Using methodologies such as participant observation, pakikipagkuwentuhan (sharing of stories), and pakikisalamuha (community integration), a descriptive-historical study of the pagpapako sa krus was done. The ritual starts with the pamagdarame or self-flagellation and segues into the sinakulo, a reenactment of the passion of Christ done in the streets of Cutud. It reaches its climax in the actual crucifixion of the devotee/actor playing the role of Jesus Christ. Other devotees volunteer to join as penitents in the ritual as part of their pamamanata or panata —a form of devotion to the Supreme Being for an answered prayer or good graces bestowed upon one’s family.

Using Victor Turner’s concept of the ritual as a way of realizing the communitas or community, Tiatco presents the pagpapako sa krus as a means for the community (audience) to traverse the physical and the metaphysical world, using the performative elements of the space, the actor, and the text. The study draws from Apolonio B. Chua’s definition of dula (play), which identifies the actor, audience, space, and the text as vital dramatic components bound by a mission and a context.

Anchored on the panata, the pagpapako is enacted every year on Good Friday, the long waiting period before that being for the preparation of the devotee/actor. He then takes charge of engaging himself in the rituals of pamagdarame, believed to cleanse the soul through physical pain. Some of these are the plahelente (self-flagellation), mamusan krus (carrying the cross), pamamalaspas (flagellation which causes the back to bleed), pagsalibatbat (crawling on hot pavement), piercing the flesh with the panabad (whip), and flagellation by relatives of the magdarame (penitent). The actual pagpapako sa krus (crucifixion) marks the realization of the pamamanata, as the devotee/actor allows himself to be one with the Supreme Being through the performance of pain and suffering. Through the pamamanata, the members of the Catholic community of Cutud are able to create a pantayong identidad (community identity) from their common devotion to the passion and death of Christ as the embodiment of sacrifice for the salvation of the world.  Written by Glecy C. Atienza

article_title: Sa Sariling Bayan: Apat na Dulang May Musika
text:
(In One’s Own Motherland: Four Plays with Music). Published 2003. Author, Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Music, Ryan Cayabyab, Jim Paredes, Lucien Letaba, Jojo Atienza, and Alex Umali. Manila: De La Salle University Press Inc.

The book is an anthology of four plays written by National Artist for Literature Bienvenido L. Lumbera. In his introduction titled “Bukas-Tabing” (Open Curtain), Lumbera explains that the publication of this anthology is intended to offer his four plays to a broader audience. The first part of the title, “Sa Sariling Bayan,” was taken from the song of Maria Clara in Noli Me Tangere: The Musical to underscore the unifying theme and purpose of the plays—“tungkol sa bayan at para sa bayan” (about the nation and for the people).

The topics of the plays represent significant eras in Philippine history—the combined period of the Propaganda Movement and the Marcos dictatorship in Bayani (Hero); the period of Spanish colonialism in Noli Me Tangere: The Musical, the period of the Philippine-American War in Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plea and Revolt of Victoria Laktaw and Others), and the period of migration of Filipino farmers to the United States (US) in the 1930s in search of a better life in Nasa Puso ang Amerika (America Is in the Heart). It is evident from this selection of plays that history is the playwright’s primary means to educate and enlighten. Lumbera believes that theater is a form of “panunungaw” (looking through a window) that invites the audience to observe vignettes of life on stage, affording them a glimpse of realities perhaps otherwise ignored in real life; the anthology offers a chance to read and reflect on them.

Lumbera narrates his experience of mounting each play, highlighting the sociohistorical context of each production. Nasa Puso ang Amerika was staged in 1984 by the Philippine Educational Theater Association as a tribute to overseas Filipino workers, as the history of the “Manong” in California in Carlos Bulosan’s original novel America Is in the Heart was similar to the history of the play’s contract workers in Saudi Arabia. Bayani was also staged in 1984, a year after the assassination of Ninoy Aquino, amidst the worsening economic crisis and the escalation of protest actions seeking truth and justice. Noli Me Tangere: The Musical was staged on the eve of the centennial celebration of the 1896 Revolution by Tanghalang Pilipino. The Japanese audience, through the initiatives of Japan Foundation and NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation), also viewed the play on stage and on television. Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. was mounted in 1992 by Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas. The play’s insistence that the event regarded by the Americans as the “insurrection” was in fact a war, is juxtaposed with the issue of the joint US-Philippine military Balikatan (“shoulder-to-shoulder”) exercises.

Each of the four plays is presented as one section, composed of the “Pasakalye” (Introduction), “Dula” (Play), “Mga Tala” (Notes), and “Musika” (Music). In the “Pasakalye,” Lumbera narrates the personal and historical, as well as the literary and theater contexts of producing the plays on the page and on stage. Some photos from the actual staged performances are also included. The actual script written by Lumbera are presented in the “Dula” portion. In “Mga Tala/Mga Talang Pamproduksiyon,” the production details, such as the names of the producers, dates, and venues of production, as well as the names of the theater artists, are enumerated. Lastly, in “Musika,” the musical notations, together with Lumbera’s libretti, are printed.

This book is an important work that explores the various relationships of theater and history from the point of view of a foremost literary and theater figure. The book won the National Book Award for drama from the Manila Critics Circle in 2003 and the Gintong Aklat Award for literature from the Book Development Association of the Philippines in 2004.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Salvador F. Bernal: Designing the Stage
text:
Published 2007. Author, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

The book is a comprehensive review of Salvador F. Bernal’s work as designer for theater, with over 200 full-color photographs of his sketches, models, and actual costumes and sets complementing the text.

In chapter 1, Tiongson provides a biographical sketch of Bernal, focusing on his education as an artist. Bernal’s apprenticeship began in his mother’s dress shop, where he learned techniques of “cutting, sewing, and embroidery.” Later, when he was studying at Ateneo de Manila University, Bernal developed an interest in writing poetry. Rolando Tinio, his mentor, also introduced him to theater. Afterward, Bernal received formal training in the theater arts at Northwestern University.

The design process is the subject of chapter 2. As a designer, Bernal shied away from literalist renderings and preferred abstractions or stylization. Tiongson credits this orientation both to his teachers and to his appreciation for modern poetry. In example after example, Tiongson shows that Bernal’s sets and costumes are visual incarnations of the text, indices of character or feeling, not mere decorations or concessions to realism.

In chapters 3 and 4, Tiongson gives a further account of Bernal’s creative process and of his ingenuity in the face of limitations. Tiongson writes that Bernal turns to various sources for his design concepts, sometimes combining them to “stunning results.” To turn his design concepts into reality, Bernal has had to overcome such realities as less than adequate budgets, poor technology, or limiting acting or dancing spaces. Bernal finds solutions in the unlikeliest places. Evidence of Bernal’s creativity is his ability to transform inexpensive materials into impressive stage effects. The “crystal chandelier” in a production of La Traviata, Tiongson reveals, was merely an assemblage of plastic cases of ballpoint pens; the dreamy “enchanted forest” of Ballet Philippines’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream was cheap “gauze katsa [unbleached muslin], sprayed with blue, green, andhoney-yellowdyes”; and the native costumes of many a production were made of sinamay (abaca cloth), which under the right lights appear like the genuine article. In these and other instances, Bernal showed his ability to make virtue of necessity, as well as exploiting what technology could do.

The last chapter is Tiongson’s assessment of Bernal’s achievements as designer: Bernal is an artist with an amazing visual sense, a keen interpretative mind, and an uncompromising work ethic. Limitations are for him opportunities to stretch one’s creativity. Ultimately, Bernal proves that “the Filipino artist, who has vision and integrity, can overcome any limitation, to create works that express the native soul, with a consummate artistry that can compete with the very best anywhere in the world.” The book won the National Book Award for Best Design and the Alfonso T. Ongpin Prize for Best Book on Art from the Manila Critics Circle and the National Book Development Board in 2008.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: The San Miguel Fiesta Rituals of Iligan City: Correlations of Form, Function, and Value
text:
MA thesis. Author, Steven Patrick C. Fernandez. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

The thesis attempts to describe and analyze the theater activities during Iligan’s San Miguel fiesta, to show how the “external forms of the said activities manifest [Iligan’s] cultural values” and “fulfill important defensive and integrative functions.”

The thesis is divided into four chapters. Chapter 1, the introduction, provides readers the study’s overview, basic assumptions, and a general background of Iligan City. Here, Fernandez establishes his basic arguments and provides the definition of key concepts, such as ritual, form, and traditional art. Chapter 2, “The Iligan City Fiesta of Señor San Miguel,” centers on the San Miguel fiesta and the folk narratives about the life of San Miguel. The chapter is divided into three subsections, each focusing on a particular historical and practical aspect of the San Miguel fiesta—namely, “Señor San Miguel: The Folk Hero,” “The San Miguel Folk Narratives,” and “Events, Practices, and Other Beliefs.”

Chapter 3, “The Rituals and Folk Arts,” the core of the work, describes and analyzes the ritual artistic forms that Fernandez says reveal much about the Iliganon culture: the pagkanaug, the sinulog, the diandi, and the drama of San Miguel. Fernandez describes and comments on the “visual manifestation, material expression, dance and movements, music and song, chants, the texts of dialogues and the verses, and the overall formats during their performances.” In chapter 4, “Value Implications: Correlations to Forms and Function,” the author attempts to evaluate and discuss the correlations of form, function, and values of the ritual activities during the fiesta. Passed down from one generation to another as a repository of Iliganon thought and behavior, each ritual activity has its own particular ritual or communal function, which in turn articulates a specific set of values. The chapter’s five subsections discuss the implications of the ritual activities of the San Miguel fiesta to the Iliganon culture and community.

Utilizing a descriptive and analytical approach, the significance of the study lies in its attempt to establish a concrete relationship between the external manifestations of ritual artistic forms and the cultural values of the people that practice them.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Sarswelang Pangasinan
text:
(Pangasinan Zarzuela). Published 1996. Editor, Priscelina Patajo-Legasto. Translators, Ma. Crisanta Nelmida and Erlinda Andaya. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The book is the ninth in a 12-book Panitikang Pilipino Series by the university presses of Ateneo de Manila University, De La Salle University, and the University of the Philippines.

The book contains three original sarsuwela in Pangasinan translated into the Filipino language. Two of these sarsuwela, titled Panaun Aman (Once Upon a Time) and Basingkawel (Campaign), were written by Pablo Mejia. The other one, Pacayari’y Pilak (Money is Power), is by Catalino Palisoc. The book also includes the libretto of Mejia’s Panaun Aman.

Panaun Aman tells the story of Nanoy, an educated man who joined the revolutionaries against the Spaniards. In the tradition of Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), Nanoy is similar to Ibarra, who had good intentions for his native land but was considered subversive and dangerous by the Spanish cura (curate). Nanoy’s sweetheart Ilalo, like Maria Clara, is a mestiza who becomes the object of desire of the cura. The sarsuwela ends with the victory of the revolutionaries against the Spaniards under the leadership of Nanoy, who ushers in a new era of ilalo (hope) from the dark colonial past. Panaun Aman presents the abuses suffered by the Pangasinense people under the Spaniards. While there is no explicit reference to American abuses, Legasto believes that Mejia’s work subtly critiques as well the effects of Americanization on the Pangasinense people—in particular, the Flag Law and the Anti-Sedition Act.

Basingkawel is a lighthearted, humorous sarsuwela that pits Don Cenon and Don Marcos against each other in a battle to be electedpresidente(mayor). Each has a unique campaign strategy to win votes from the people. The play exposes the corrupt practices of politicians during elections. In the end, the two rivals end up renewing their ties as friends, for politics is addition rather than subtraction. The play shows how materialism, individualism, corruption, and moral degradation have characterized the Pangasinense folk under the new American dispensation.

Pacayari’y Pilak is the story of Armando, a poor man who loves Elisa. Elisa’s parents dislike Armando and prefer the rich Don Francisco. Her mother, Magdalena, is depicted as a social climber and a chronic gambler. Years after Armando returns from a foreign land as a rich man, he takes revenge on Elisa, who married the rich Don Francisco, by asking Angela, Elisa’s sister, for her own hand in marriage. Pacayari’y Pilac decries the change of attitude and values of the Pangasinense folk, who have been debased by the lure of money, the good life, and self-aggrandizement.

The book Sarswelang Pangasinan opens up the different voices from the province through the literary process of translation. These voices are framed by the context of American colonial period, since the works were written during the first three decades of the 20th century. Mejia and Palisoc are both anacbanua (political elite) writers educated in Manila. Both of them were highly influenced by the patriotism of Jose Rizal.   Written by Marot Nelmida-Flores

article_title: The 'Seditious' Tagalog Playwrights: Early American Occupation
text:
Published 1972. Author: Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio. Manila: Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines Inc.

The book serves both as a historical analysis of the “seditious” plays and playwrights during the early stages of the American occupation and an introduction to the popular and allied dramatic forms of Philippine theater. Drawing from books, news articles, reports from the Philippine Commission, military records, travel accounts, and memoirs published during the American period, Lapeña-Bonifacio’s work problematizes the term “seditious” ascribed to the plays of playwrights like Aurelio Tolentino, Manuel Xeres-Burgos, Juan Abad, Tomas Remigio, and Severino Reyes, which are characterized by anticolonial and nationalist sentiments, while attempting to map and trace the development of “seditious” plays from what Lapeña-Bonifacio calls an “admixture of political, religious, and literary hues.”

The book has four chapters. Chapter 1, titled “Historical Background,” gives readers an overview of the popular and allied dramatic forms of Philippine theater and argues that the seditious plays sprang from earlier dramatic forms that date back to the early years of Spanish conquest. Each of the chapter’s five subsections discusses a particular dramatic form which she claims contributed to the emergence of the “seditionary drama.” The forms constitute the titles of the section, thus: “The Panuluyan and the Salubong,” “The Pasion and the Cenaculo,” “The Moro-moro,” “The Carillo,” and “The Debates: Karagatan, Duplo and Balagtasan.”

Chapter 2, “Zarzuela,” discusses the development of the native sarsuwela, the dramatic form that, Lapeña-Bonifacio asserts, had the biggest influence on and was eventually utilized by playwrights like Aurelio Tolentino, Severino Reyes, Tomas Remigio, and Juan Abad. The author claims that historical events at the time the sarsuwela dominated the country’s theater scene paved the way for the radicalization of its content and elements. She cites two major periods: the decade that preceded the Battle of Manila Bay in 1898, which was characterized by native unrest and intense revolutionary fervor against the Spanish colonial rule, and the aftermath of the Battle of Manila Bay, a short period in which the American forces, led by Commodore Dewey, started consolidating their forces for the occupation of Manila. Chapter 2 has seven subsections. Four of these elaborate on the seditious traits incorporated by Tolentino and his contemporaries into the sarsuwela under the section headings “The Theatre as Sedition Breeder,” “Uses of Speeches and Eulogies,” “The Chameleon Plays,” and “The Use of Theatrical Machinery and Effects.” The last subsection discusses the fate suffered by the “seditious” playwrights at the hands of the Spanish and American colonial regimes and reflects on the role of theater, and of literature as a whole, in the project of national liberation and nation building.

Chapter 3, “Additional Notes,” features Lapeña-Bonifacio’s observations, comments, and recommendations on the Tagalog sarsuwela. Here, she mainly identifies problems faced by the sarsuwela as a distinct literary and dramatic form born under and influenced by specific historical conditions. She provides possible routes of inquiry from which new studies can emerge and materialize. Finally, she posits several recommendations toward the preservation of the Tagalog sarsuwela in the face of what she dubs the “frenzied Anglo-Saxonizing” of Philippine culture.

Juan Abad’s Tanikalang Guinto (Golden Chain), ca. 1902, is an indictment of American colonialism in the Philippines. Aurelio Tolentino’s Kahapon, Ngayon at Bukas (Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow), ca. 1903, is an allegorical play that exposes foreign and native agents and structures of power that continue to beset the project of nation building.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Simulain: Dulambayan ng Manggagawa sa Konteksto ng Militanteng Kilusang Unyonismo (1980-1994)
text:
(Guiding Principle: Workers’ Dulambayan in the Context of the Militant Unionism Movement, 1980-1994). Published 2009. Author, Apolonio Bayani Chua. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The book is based on the author’s dissertation submitted to the Philippine Studies Program of the College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman, in 1996. In seven chapters, it discusses the history, context, organization, and productions of cultural groups that are attached to workers’ trade unions in Metropolitan Manila. It highlights the dulambayan, one of several terms used by these groups to refer to their cultural productions, examining their audience, venue, actor, text, and context. Among these elements, Chua asserts that it is the context—the militant unionism, meaning “tunay, palaban, at makabayan” (legitimate, militant, and nationalist)—which defines and distinguishes the dulambayan.

Chapter 1 discusses the background of the study, the objectives, survey of related literature, theoretical framework and its application, and the structure of the book.

Chapter 2 focuses on the history of Tanghalang Silangan, a cultural group based in the Bisig-Pagkakaisa–National Federation of Labor Unions of Rubberworld Philippines Incorporated. Established in 1980, the group had the most extensive tradition of songs, plays, and visual arts of all cultural groups based in the trade unions in Metropolitan Manila in the period covered by the study. Both Tanghalang Silangan and Bisig-Pagkakaisa have become models for other groups and unions. By focusing on Tanghalang Silangan, the study shows the relationship between the cultural group and the militant workers’ union, and the dynamics of cultural production of the foremost workers’ cultural group.

Chapter 3 traces the path of Allison Opaon, who has the longest and most productive experience both as a musician and as a songwriter among the members of Teatro Pabrika, a network of workers’ cultural groups. A strong influence of unionism pervades Opaon’s journey as a laborer and a cultural worker, through the contexts of his musical productions. In the creative process, unionism inspires “katwiran, kabuuan, at katangian” (rationale, unity, and character) in the dulambayan.

Chapter 4 details the formation and development of Teatro Pabrika. The group started from disparate initiatives in Novaliches, Quezon City, and Valenzuela; progressed into the formation of the Quezon City Trade Unions Cultural Group, a merging of four local groups; and united as a network of 35 workers’ cultural groups and committees. Also mentioned in the chapter are several cultural initiatives from the middle class and the academic community that have connections with workers’ issues.

In chapter 5, Chua highlights three forms of dulambayan— haranang bayan (people’s serenade), akyat-bus (bus action), and pag-iingay (making noise)—shaped by the distinct culture of strikes and picket lines organized by militant unionism, representing the workers’ response to their oppression. The dulambayan is determined not only by unionism but also by the tradisyong bayan (people’s tradition) derived from the culture brought by the workers who fled to Manila from the various regions of the Philippines. Chua explains that the workers reprocessed the tradisyong bayan to adjust to the prevailing conditions of their struggle.

In chapter 6, Chua elaborates on the major aspects of the dulambayan, such as the audience, venue, actor, text, and context, as well as the forms and processes of the workers’ cultural productions. Chua uses specific dulambayan—from Jojo Atilano’s production of Katulad ni Itay (Like Father), 1981, an original play by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), to Teatro Pabrika’s Pista ng Dulambayan ng Manggagawa, which featured around 15 productions and numerous songs from 1992 to 1993, and several other productions in between—as bases of discussion of the various aspects and characteristics of the dulambayan.

In chapter 7, the author reiterates the main ideas developed about the history and nature of the workers’ dulambayan. Chua adopts Prospero Covar’s outline of theater tradition in the Philippines and positions the workers’ dulambayan alongside the theater tradition of farmers and the kilusang pangkalayaan (revolutionary movements). Finally, the author maps out these theater traditions based on the triangular structure of Philippine society, with the “theater” tradition constituting the upper segment, and the dulambayan of workers, farmers, and other minority groups comprising the base.

Interspersed in different chapters of the book are texts and notes relevant to the workers’ dulambayan: the songs of Tanghalang Silangan; songs by Allison Opaon and a narrative of his experience in Mindanao; scripts of Kabuhayang Tagpi-Tagpi (Patchwork Life) and Eksena ng Kulungan (Scene from Prison); a list of selected workers’ cultural groups; an excerpt from the journal of the Quezon City Trade Unions Cultural Groups; and a chronology of events related to the formation of the workers’ dulambayan, 1972-2005.

Chua’s position as a scholar, participant observer, and artist-teacher of PETA, which served the community and sectoral-based cultural groups, allowed him to view the meaning and significance of dulambayan from the perspective of the workers themselves. By highlighting the context of the workers’ dulambayan, the study transcended earlier stages of theater studies that focused on the drama aspect, which emphasizes the text, and the theater aspect, which takes into account the mounting of the play.   Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Sinakulo (Philippine Theatre: History and Anthology Volume III)
text:
Published 1999. Editor, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The third of the originally planned five-volume anthology on Philippine theater history, the book focuses on the sinakulo, the Lenten play on the life and sufferrings of Jesus Christ, first performed in the 18th century. The book features two essays by Tiongson on the definition and history of sinakulo and on the tanggal, Bicol’s version of the sinakulo. To further illustrate the form, the anthology documents a performance of the tanggal from Tambo, Buhi, Camarines Sur. An English translation of the tanggal performance text by Teresita Erestain and photographs of the performance are also provided.

Tiongson’s introductory essay on the sinakulo is divided into four subsections. The first subsection, “History,” provides a brief history of the form from its beginnings during the middle part of the 18th century up to the 1970s when, as Tiongson observes, “a new type of sinakulo has been evolved by socially conscious groups.” The second subsection, “The Traditional Sinakulo,” discusses the variety of sinakulo that flourished in various provinces in the country—Rizal, Bulacan, Laguna, Pampanga, Bataan, and Camarines Sur. Here, Tiongson uses the sinakulo documented in Malolos, Bulacan, to illustrate the genre, arguing that most traditional sinakulo scripts from Malolos were “carbon copies of each other” because the farmers who composed them “dare not depart from established beliefs for fear of heresy or hell.” The third subsection, “From Traditional to Modern,” details the historical factors, such as pop culture and rural modernization, that served as catalysts for the emergence of the modern sinakulo. The final subsection, “Conflict and Continuity,” focuses on the diametrically opposed worldviews espoused by the traditional sinakulo and the modern sinakulo. Tiongson posits that while “the traditional sinakulo endorses passivity in the face of aggressors, the modern sinakulo proposes action ranging from all-out rebellion to dismantle the whole structure of injustice to symbolic and quiet Pieta where the dead Christ is cradled by a united front of peasants, workers, students, and ethnic minorities.”

The essay on the tanggal of Buhi provides a brief definition and history of the tanggal, its script, and its order of performance. The tanggal performance text presented and annotated in the book is gathered from multiple sources, such as Casaysayan can Mahal na Pasion ni Jesucristo Cagurangnanta, na Sucat Ipaglaad nin Puso nin Siisay man na Magbasa (The Story of the Holy Passion of Our Lord Jesus Christ That Should Inflame the Heart of the Reader), loose sheets, and cassette tapes containing recorded tanggal performances.

The tanggal text featured in the anthology is the one used by the Eclarinal group, which is based on the pasyon Casaysayan can Mahal na Pasion ni Jesucristo Cagurangnanta, Tranquilino Hernandez’s Bikol translation of the Pasyong Genesis (Passion of the Genesis). Unlike its source text, the tanggal text does not narrate the life of Christ in full. In fact, there are instances wherein the tanggalista would add related scenes or expand particular episodes, examples being the rant of the tree, the grass, and the soil when Adam and Eve begin to work in the field with their bolo and hoe; the story of Mary and Joseph’s search for an inn in Bethlehem; and the story of how the corn originated from Eve’s hair. Examples of episodes that have been supplemented with extra dialogue include the condemnation of the snake that tempted Eve; the annunciation to Mary; John, Mary Magdelene, and Martha’s lament over the Virgin Mary’s body; the entry into Jerusalem; and the farewell scenes between Jesus and Mary.

The entire tanggal script is rendered in quintillas, or five-line octosyllabic verses with assonantal rhyme. Most of the verses are chanted in chorus or through dialogue by specific characters.

The location of the scenes varies depending on where the actors are situated. The majority of the scenes, however, take place on an elevated stage, most of the time located at the town plaza. Lighting is used for scenes performed during the night, with two fluorescent lamps to illuminate the altar. In the event of a power failure, coleman lamps and candles are brought in and placed squarely in different parts of the stage. To reach everyone in the entire barrio, a broadcast system is installed during the chanting of the tanggal, comprising microphones placed on a table or strung to elevated bamboo poles. Stage props are usually owned and brought by the group. According to Tiongson, these props are “used for various purposes and assume different meanings.” However, Tiongson adds, most props “function practically, but not historically or artistically.”

A pioneering work on the history of the sinakulo, the book is indispensable material for the breadth of its documentation, sources, and scholarship.  Written by Amado Anthony G. Mendoza III

article_title: Sining at Agham Ng Mga Dulang Iisahing Yugto: Mga Akda Ni J. C. Balmaseda
text:
(The Art and Technique of One-Act Plays: The Works of J. C. Balmaseda). Published 1947. Author, Julian Cruz Balmaseda. Manila: Libreria J. Martinez.

Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s pioneering book on Tagalog theater consists of a “Paliwanag ng May-akda” (Preface), “Ilang Paunang Kataga” (Foreword), one chapter on his titular paper in the Pedagogical Workshop on the National Language in 1941, another chapter on his six one-act plays, and an appendix called “Taladulaan” (Playlist).

In his “Paliwanag,” Balmaseda evaluates the situation of dulaan (theater) as a branch of Tagalog literature. He observes a dearth of critical works on theater among scholars of language. To address this, the book encourages the reader to identify the myriad uri (type), tabas (form), and layon (purpose) of the dula.

He laments, in the “Pauna,” an utter lack of recognition, appreciation, and study of the dulaan. Here, an allusion to Rizal’s novel informs his panaghoy(plea) to the youth, the hope of theater, crying “Magmamandudula kayo!” (Arise, Playwrights!)

The book’s main chapter delves, first, on a formalist discourse on the sining (art) and agham (technique) of the one-act play; second, a practicum on the one-act; and third, an advisory for mandudula (playwright) neophytes. In the first part, the author delimits his study’s coverage to a short period of dulaang Tagalog’s historical development. Foremost among the uri in the art of dula are the maaagting (tension-filled), masaya (joyous), and malungkot (sad), with or without music. Emphasis on the dula technique lies in playwright training or production preparation. Included are theme selection, outlining, characterization, and theme metamorphosis into three great requisites: paglalahad (exposition), buhol/kagusutan (conflict), and kalutasan/kakalasan (resolution). Dialogue is tahas (straightforward), talampak (frank), and tiyak/maliwanag (precise). Variety is offered in 11 forms from entremes to aproposito.

Balmaseda painstakingly outlines in the second part a module that engages budding mandudula to participate—for example, suggest a title to a patriotic allegory-in-the-works involving symbolic characters Kabesang Tales, Aling Teresa, and Plaridel when news broke on the Pearl Harbor bombing.

In the third part, he exhorts aspiring mandudula to a scholarly life of reading dula, watching dulaan, listening to radio plays, and critiquing plays.

For genre study, the last chapter offers his works: Sino Ba Kayo? (Who Are You All?), a comedy of errors; Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child), a drama on erroneous values; Ang Palabas ni Suwan (Juan’s Show), a parody of power relations; Higanti ng Patay (Revenge of the Dead), a horror tragedy with two mini-acts; Ang Libingan ng Bayani (The Hero’s Grave), an Ibsenian adaptation on Moro heroism with a mini-prologue; and Gregorio H. del Pilar, a historical play with three mini-acts.

“Taladulaan,” a golden harvest of 113 oeuvre of 22 mandudula topped by prolific Patricio Mariano, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, and Pedrito Reyes, is an homage to the lihim (secrets) of dulaan.

Though Sining at Agham initially reads like a manual, it is a testimony and ode to dulaan, informed by the undaunted, heroic, and continuing Filipinization movement represented in its constructs, codification, and critique of iisahing-yugto.  Written by Melecio Cervantes Fabros III

Balmaseda painstakingly outlines in the second part a module that engages budding mandudula to participate—for example, suggest a title to a patriotic allegory-in-the-works involving symbolic characters Kabesang Tales, Aling Teresa, and Plaridel when news broke on the Pearl Harbor bombing.
In the third part, he exhorts aspiring mandudula to a scholarly life of reading dula, watching dulaan, listening to radio plays, and critiquing plays.

For genre study, the last chapter offers his works: Sino Ba Kayo? (Who Are You All?), a comedy of errors; Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child), a drama on erroneous values; Ang Palabas ni Suwan (Juan’s Show), a parody of power relations; Higanti ng Patay (Revenge of the Dead), a horror tragedy with two mini-acts; Ang Libingan ng Bayani (The Hero’s Grave), an Ibsenian adaptation on Moro heroism with a mini-prologue; and Gregorio H. del Pilar, a historical play with three mini-acts.
“Taladulaan,” a golden harvest of 113 oeuvre of 22 mandudula topped by prolific Patricio Mariano, Julian Cruz Balmaseda, and Pedrito Reyes, is an homage to the lihim (secrets) of dulaan.

Though Sining at Agham initially reads like a manual, it is a testimony and ode to dulaan, informed by the undaunted, heroic, and continuing Filipinization movement represented in its constructs, codification, and critique of iisahing-yugto.
Written by Melecio Cervantes Fabros III

article_title: Studies of the Pre-war Sugbuanon Theater (the First Series)
text:
Published 2001. Author, Wilhemina Q. Ramas. Quezon City: Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research and Development, University of the Philippines.

The book is a follow-up exposition to the Sugbuanon Theater from Sotto to Rodriguez to Kabahar: An Introduction to an Anthology of Sugbuanon Drama, 1982. It is based on a study of transcripts of oral theatricals, play scripts, and other materials from the University of the Philippines’s Sugbuanon Collection.

The book comprises 11 monographs on Sugbuanon theater put together in three compilations. Part 1 compiles Ramas’s monographs on folk theater. In “Sugbuanon Folk Theatricals,” Ramas offers a thorough discussion of the characteristics of folk theatricals, describing them as “performances of long tradition, containing dramatic elements, presented before an audience of a rural village or town or urban street neighborhood or barrio …” They can be extemporaneous dialogues, such as the balitaw, duplo, balagtasan sa balitaw, drama-balitaw, kolasisi (kulasisi), and pamalaye; or written compositions like the pastores, the saint’s play, and linambay. The study further relates the place of the theatricals as well as the versifiers or the performers in history before and after the advent of Vicente Sotto’s dramang binisaya (Visayan drama) in 1902. In the subsections “Balitaw,” “Balagtasan sa Balitaw,” “Drama-Balitaw,” “Parody of Balitaw,” and “Kolasisi,” Ramas discusses each of these oral theatricals using samples from Sugbu’s leading versifiers, providing annotations on the performance of each form, and situating each in its social and historical contexts. The study concludes by relating how these theater forms contribute to the formation of a national identity. Also in part 1 are the studies on Osmundo T. Villagonzalo’s Rosita, a pamalaye or a marriage proposal and engagement ritual; and on Jose Perez Quirante’s theatrical “Autobiography,” a selective translation of “Akong Saloma sa Bantawan” (My Song of the Stage), a holograph manuscript written in the 1970s about his life from schoolboy years to his first year as an actor. Quirante was the celebrated clown “Botoy” of the drama-balitaw.

Part 2 compiles the studies on “Vernacular Drama on the Urban Stage,” which analyzes Vicente Sotto’s Elena, a three-act drama on love and patriotism during the last few days of Spanish rule in a Luzon town; Antonio Abad and Brigido Lakandazon’s Magda, another three-act about a mother whose past threatens to taint her only son’s happiness; and Buenaventura Rodriguez’s Lili, a one-act drama regarding freedom in love and marriage.

Part 3 features selected works of Pio A. Kabahar. This includes Nine Short Plays Rendered into Narrative:Apan (However), Bestidong Kibol (Miniskirt ), Black and White, Buang (Crazy), Empermera (Nurse), Hinagtang (Gambling), Inday Mating, Kinilkig sa Ginoo (God’s Medicine), and Listahan ni Manandis (List of Manandis); the short plays Seguro ang Pancit (We’ve Got Sure Takings), Eureana, and Si Adag si Eba (Adam and Eve); and the sarsuwela Fifi.

The book not only documents the oral and written drama of prewar Cebu and the leading playwrights of the period; in one volume, it is able to establish the vernacular’s contribution to the wealth of Philippine theater. It also sets the pace for the continuing study of Sugbuanon theater.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: A Study of Popular Drama in Bikol
text:
1961. MA thesis. Author, Maria Lilia F. Realubit. University of the Philippines Diliman.

Maria Lilia F. Realubit’s project on Bikolano theater tradition opens in chapter 1 with the origin and development of Filipino drama, before progressing to Bikol drama from its beginnings to the 1950s. Chapter 2 covers early dramatic forms, such as the anito and the dallot, up to the religious forms during the Spanish colonial period, protest plays immediately after the Revolution, English plays, plays during the Japanese occupation, and the dramas of the 1950s. Chapter 3 discusses the early Bikol songs that accompanied the rituals; religious dramatic activities such as the coloquio, dotok, and panharong-harong; and the Bikol popular dramatic games such as the tigsikan, the sorompongan, and the laban.

Chapter 4 traces the beginnings of the comedia in Bikol from 1880 to the 1950s, based on the chronicles of Feodor Jagor, Juan Alvarez Guerra, and Adolfo Puya Ruiz, who all visited the region in the latter half of the 19th century. The comedia in Bikol was first a community effort staged in Spanish, but a petition in the 1880s to enact the form in the Bikol language succeeded. Realubit tackles the form, the length of production, and text, with detail on the structure of verse, costumes, and props, as well as possible influences from the arguments of Isabelo de los Reyes, Wenceslao Retana, and Asuncion Siao. The chapter ends with an analytical study of Comedia ni Hadeng Grimaldo sa Reinong Yrlanda (Comedia of King Grimaldo in the Kingdom of Yrlanda), which includes a summary and a detailed analysis of the dramatic structure and composition of the comedia.

Chapter 5 tracks the beginning of the zarzuela in the region in 1892, when a zarzuela troupe from Manila arrived in Naga City. The zarzuela inspired the formation of two troupes, the Compania Zarzuela de la Torre in Legazpi and the Compania Zarzuela in Camalig, Albay. Bikolnon zarzuelista Asisclo Jimenez y Tarege authored 26 works, including his masterpiece Pagkamoot sa Banuang Tinoboan (Love of Motherland).

Chapter 6 introduces the carillo or cosmorama, first shown in Bikol in 1905 during the feast of the Peñafrancia, and the cine, from a silent picture in 1910 at the Cine Mabi in Naga. Short dramas, such as Bonifacio Baesa’s An Governadorcillo (The Mayor), underscored an emerging sense of independence, specifying Sorsogon as the “more vocal” among the provinces. Other playwrights were Valerio Zuñiga, Mariano Nicomedes, Antonio Salazar, A. P. Vidal, Fr Valentin Reamon, Fr Jose Rey, Fr Vicente Romano, and Justo Dellosa. During the war years, the Crusaders group in Sorsogon, led by Baesa, staged comedies and skits in Irosin and Juban, and sarsuwela still prospered in Albay, Camarines Norte, and Catanduanes. Hallmark plays were Vida nin Magcompade na si Roque asin Barbara (The Life of Roque and Barbara) and An Tolong Estudiante (The Three Students) by A. P. Vidal.

Chapter 7 documents productions in Bikol in the 1950s, mostly staged in schools, predominantly in English and sometimes in Tagalog or Spanish. Ateneo de Naga and Colegio de Santa Isabel awarded one-act plays in their literary contests. Founded in 1949, the Cathedral Players group translated plays into Bikolano, staged 36 productions, performed in the townships of Camarines Norte and Sorsogon, and aired them over DZRB in Naga City. Other works mentioned are Antonio Salazar’s one-act plays in Legazpi City, productions at the Arena Theater in Catanduanes, and plays produced and directed by Antonio Laurora. Realubit ends the chapter with a descriptive study of the plays by the Cathedral Players, covering the literary techniques, themes, stage properties, costumes, players, the rehearsals, direction, performance, and the script. The Bicol Dramatic Guild, organized in Naga City in 1960, presented Familia de Lubio (Lubio Family) over DZRB every Sunday.

Included in the study are the titles of 11 religious plays, 27 comedia, 40 sarsuwela, 13 plays on manners and customs, 21 plays of the Cathedral Players, and 11 plays from the 1950s plays, as well as a comprehensive list of names and short biographies of Bikol playwrights and the complete text of Pagkamoot sa Banuang Tinoboan (Love for the Native Land), with Realubit’s English translation. Letters of authors Mariano Goyena, Valerio Zuñiga, Alejo Arce, and Jose dela Torre are among the primary sources.

A shorter version of this thesis appeared in the Mar-Jun 1976 issue of the Philippines Social Science and Humanities Review as “The Bicol Dramatic Tradition.” Here, Realubit includes a discussion of Justino Nuyda's works especially his play Anti-Cristo (Anti-Christ) which she anthologized in Philippine Drama: Twelve Plays in Six Languages published in 1987.  Written by Peñafrancia Raniela E. Barbaza

article_title: Sugbuanon Theater from Sotto to Rodriguez and Kabahar: an Introduction to Pre-war Sugbuanon Drama
text:
Published 1982. Author, Wilhemina Q. Ramas. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press for the Asian Center.

The book defines Sugbuanon Theater as “the theater of the people in the provinces of Central Visayas and Mindanao where the native speech is the language of Sugbu (Cebu) province.” The book consists of three parts.

Part 1 surveys Sugbuanon theater from the 1900s to 1941, tracing the development of old forms like the linambay, to the rise of the dulang binisaya, which are classified as dulang hinonihan (plays with songs), dulang kataw-anan (comedy plays), and dulang mahinuklogon (reflection plays). In the survey, the theatrical career and major works of three giants of Sugbuanon theater in the prewar period are highlighted: Vicente Sotto (1877-1950), whose example of a completely Sugbuanon realistic drama started a tradition that held the stage for over three decades in Sugbu and the neighboring provinces; Buenaventura Rodriguez (1893-1940), who first gained distinction as an author and actor of Spanish plays but later shifted to writing sarsuwela and other plays in the vernacular; and Pio Kabahar (1892-1977), the entertainer, actor, composer, and playwright whose comical plays were known for their robust farces and laughing scenes.

Part 2 compiles the plays of Rodriguez and Kabahar: Rodriguez’s Bomba Nyor! (Bombs Away, Sir!), a three-act sarsuwela about a politician who tries to abandon his wife for his political ambitions; and Kabahar’s Babaye ug Lalake (Woman and Man), a one-act comedy on men and women whose heartbreaks caused them to decide to never fall in love again, and Miss Dolying, another one-act comedy regarding a woman deceived by her suitor to test whether she is the ideal woman to marry. The scripts are supplemented by English translations and notes by Ramas. Ramas selected the plays to introduce readers to the plays of Rodriguez and Kabahar. She also notes that these plays are of contemporary interest and have been warmly received by undergraduate and graduate students of literature.

Part 3 chronicles 1,426 play performances and other related events, and supplies the specific details of the survey and biographical accounts presented in part 1. What would have been more than 1,200 footnote entries are arranged in part 3 to serve as documentation section for part 1. This also includes a list of the plays and the playwrights in the chronicle.

Parts 1 and 3 are entirely based on information from the bound compilation of the news magazine Bag-ong Kusog (New Force) in the Vicente Rama Collection at the University of the Philippines. Bag-ong Kusog was Sugbu’s most valuable source of prewar theatrical information—performances, events, and personalities in the capital and other towns of Sugbu. It has recorded vital details in the survey of the local theater such as playwrights, actors, scene and costume designers, costume donors, audiences, notices, and ticket prices.

The book brings to the vast scholarship on Philippine theater the particularly rich history and development of Sugbuanon drama and the narratives of the people who helped define it.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa
