article_title: Theater for the Nation: a Prospectus for the National Theater in the Philippines
text:
Published 2003. Author, Cecile Guidote-Alvarez. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

Based on the author’s masteral thesis, “A Prospectus for the National Theater of the Philippines,” completed in 1967, this book is Guidote-Alvarez’s blueprint for the development of drama and theater in the Philippines in three parts: (1) “Historical Background of the Philippine Cultural Scene, Circa 1967,” (2) “Vision of a National Theater,” and (3) “Theater Architectural Guide for the Central Institute of Theater Arts in the Philippines (CITAP).”

In part 1, chapter 1 presents a broad assessment of the cultural scene in the Philippines in the early 1960s. The author singles out the contributions of popular, community, school and amateur theater groups in the country, concluding that Filipino theater was only regarded as a frivolity or a profit-oriented form of entertainment—a “national failure to develop a theater tradition”—and suggests the need for a national theater movement as a base for theater schools and professional repertory theaters in the country.

Chapter 2 highlights the importance of theater as a medium of cultural reform. Citing various examples in world drama, the author stresses the values of theater as an expression of the soul, a source of moral values and educational benefits, a historical asset, an impetus to other artistic activities, and a means to fulfill human needs and preserve human rights—a distinguished profession where excellence and productivity are pursued.

Part 2, in five chapters, details the vision for the establishment of a national theater. Chapter 3 enumerates the important characteristics of a national theater: presence of support and artistic policy, service to a vast majority of citizens, availability of necessary venues and facilities, and an uncompromising dedication to quality. The National Theater of the Philippines must be present across the country in different local organizations, devoted to the creation of a dramaturgy reflective of Filipino culture, production of the best of world and contemporary drama, and the development of excellent theater artists. To achieve these, the author proposes the creation of a professional repertory theater program, a service and information program, a coordinating program for group development, and a multifaceted training program.

Chapter 4 problematizes the lack of well-trained personnel and artists for professional theater, of a more responsive audience, of more suitable playhouses, and native playwriting. It stresses the importance of education, creation, and growth of professional theaters nationwide. These new creations must emerge throughout the land as a chain of resident theater companies inspired by international drama companies.

Chapter 5 identifies government and educational institutions as instrumental to the growth of Philippine theater, with schools as the main venue for theater education, and with government support for the creation of arts councils, inclusion of theater in the curriculum, a copyright law to protect artists’ rights, protection against financial hardships and illness, pensions to senior and aged artists, tours abroad, and honorific awards to deserving theater artists. At the same time, theater must be afforded freedom of creation.

Chapter 6 proposes the legislation of a National Theater Trust Fund to support the establishment of (1) a Diverse Professional Theater Program, to include production of world classics and contemporary drama, native theater, youth theater, workers’ and peasants’ theater, puppet theater, experimental theater, musical theater, mime and improvisational theater, touring theater, and theater for film, radio, and television; (2) a Service and Information Program, to include theater library collection, script information, theater information service/research and publications program, theater organization advisory service, job counseling and placement service, film/record/photographic loan service, guest artist program, playwrights’ program, and a Philippine center of the International Theater Institute (ITI); (3) a Coordinating and Unifying Program, which can organize conventions, festivals, awards systems, drama federations like the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), an alliance of theater amateurs, a national association of theater artists, and a nationwide network of regional chapters; and (4) a Training Program, which will develop specialized training in educational and repertory theater, as well as short-term courses. For the author, the most effective channel to implement the mission of a national theater would be the creation of the CITAP.

Chapter 7 lays down the plan for the establishment of CITAP, which would be the base and headquarters, communications center, and seat of operations of all the major programs described in the thesis. It includes an organizational chart and a special chart on the Dramatic Arts Center, home to three main programs: Educational Theater, Broadcast Film Art Division, and the National Repertory Theater Group.

Part 3 begins with chapter 8, which describes the then current state of theater architecture in the Philippines, deploring design and construction inadequacies while commending excellent models outside the Philippines, based on distinctive philosophies and design innovations in terms of audience communication and creative staging possibilities.

Chapter 9 provides a brief survey of theater architectural forms from which planners can derive ideas. Guidote-Alvarez reiterates designer Roger Steven’s main elements in theater design: communication as a factor of life and society, dramatic communication as a factor of the form of the play, and relationship of form to theater art. She finally recommends the use of the variable stage as the design foundation for CITAP’s Dramatic Arts Center.

Chapter 10 enumerates specific guidelines for the design for a national theater, explaining the importance of the chosen site, functional spaces reflecting different programs, facilities, audience spaces, considerations of tri-dimensionality (time, space, man), multiplicity of staging areas, and sound and light enrichments.

The ideas brought forth by the thesis inspired the birth of PETA’s programs and services. More importantly, the document successfully synthesized multiple contradictory forces at work during the specific historical juncture of the second half of the 20th century for Philippine theater, drawing strength from both global and Philippine indigenous traditions, as well as radical and elite movements, under the rubric of national theater. The book won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for literary criticism in 2003.  Written by Lutgardo L. Labad

These new creations must emerge throughout the land as a chain of resident theater companies inspired by international drama companies.

Chapter 5 identifies government and educational institutions as instrumental to the growth of Philippine theater, with schools as the main venue for theater education, and with government support for the creation of arts councils, inclusion of theater in the curriculum, a copyright law to protect artists’ rights, protection against financial hardships and illness, pensions to senior and aged artists, tours abroad, and honorific awards to deserving theater artists. At the same time, theater must be afforded freedom of creation.

Chapter 6 proposes the legislation of a National Theater Trust Fund to support the establishment of (1) a Diverse Professional Theater Program, to include production of world classics and contemporary drama, native theater, youth theater, workers’ and peasants’ theater, puppet theater, experimental theater, musical theater, mime and improvisational theater, touring theater, and theater for film, radio, and television; (2) a Service and Information Program, to include theater library collection, script information, theater information service/research and publications program, theater organization advisory service, job counseling and placement service, film/record/photographic loan service, guest artist program, playwrights’ program, and a Philippine center of the International Theater Institute (ITI); (3) a Coordinating and Unifying Program, which can organize conventions, festivals, awards systems, drama federations like the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), an alliance of theater amateurs, a national association of theater artists, and a nationwide network of regional chapters; and (4) a Training Program, which will develop specialized training in educational and repertory theater, as well as short-term courses. For the author, the most effective channel to implement the mission of a national theater would be the creation of the CITAP.

Chapter 7 lays down the plan for the establishment of CITAP, which would be the base and headquarters, communications center, and seat of operations of all the major programs described in the thesis. It includes an organizational chart and a special chart on the Dramatic Arts Center, home to three main programs: Educational Theater, Broadcast Film Art Division, and the National Repertory Theater Group.

Part 3 begins with chapter 8, which describes the then current state of theater architecture in the Philippines, deploring design and construction inadequacies while commending excellent models outside the Philippines, based on distinctive philosophies and design innovations in terms of audience communication and creative staging possibilities.

Chapter 9 provides a brief survey of theater architectural forms from which planners can derive ideas. Guidote-Alvarez reiterates designer Roger Steven’s main elements in theater design: communication as a factor of life and society, dramatic communication as a factor of the form of the play, and relationship of form to theater art. She finally recommends the use of the variable stage as the design foundation for CITAP’s Dramatic Arts Center.

Chapter 10 enumerates specific guidelines for the design for a national theater, explaining the importance of the chosen site, functional spaces reflecting different programs, facilities, audience spaces, considerations of tri-dimensionality (time, space, man), multiplicity of staging areas, and sound and light enrichments.

The ideas brought forth by the thesis inspired the birth of PETA’s programs and services. More importantly, the document successfully synthesized multiple contradictory forces at work during the specific historical juncture of the second half of the 20th century for Philippine theater, drawing strength from both global and Philippine indigenous traditions, as well as radical and elite movements, under the rubric of national theater. The book won the Manila Critics Circle National Book Award for literary criticism in 2003.
Written by Lutgardo L. Labad

article_title: The Theater in Manila 1846-1946
text:
Published 1994. Author, Cristina Laconico-Buenaventura. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

The book presents the theater structures in the Philippines from 1846 to 1946 and provides a narrative of the theater performances and events that took place in these structures at various periods in Philippine history.

The book has two main parts: Part 1, “The Theaters of Manila: 1846-1896,” on theaters of the Spanish period; and Part 2, “The Theaters of Manila: 1896-1946,” on theaters during the American regime. Laconico-Buenaventura’s narrative begins in 1846, this being the year the first formal theater in the archipelago, Teatro de Binondo, was constructed. It ends with the inauguration of the Metropolitan Theater in 1931, which was heavily damaged during the Battle of Manila in 1945, and inaugurated once again in 1978 after restoration efforts done by then First Lady Imelda Romualdez-Marcos.

Part 1, chapter 1, focuses on the formal theater structures of the Spanish period, presenting Teatro Español, Spanish and/or European productions such as Italian opera, symphonies, and concerts for the Spanish elite and the upper classes; Teatro Tagalo, mainly moro-moro or komedya written by Filipinos for a Filipino audience; comedia chinica or Chinese opera; and bullfights. Chapter 2 pertains to theater societies for the aficionados as well as theater and musical groups of the period. Visiting troupes influenced local actors and raised their level of professionalism and sophistication. Laconico-Buenaventura notes that Filipino playwrights wrote, aside from romantic dramas, plays to commemorate events. Chapter 3 discusses government involvement through regulations and proclamations ensuring public safety, monitoring of the types of shows presented, and supervision of personnel and audience decorum. Chapter 4 reviews theater in Manila during the period.

Part 2, section 1, is titled “The Early Decades of the American Occupation.” Chapter 1 of this section continues with accounts on the theater activities. Teatro Tagalo provided popular entertainment and featured nationalist or “seditious” theater plays. Teatro Español continued presenting Spanish plays, zarzuela, and musical comedies while welcoming, on occasion, the English drama and musical plays of foreign companies. A number of Manila’s theaters also offered short films and live shows. Chapter 2 discusses the operations of the theaters as well as the shows and events at Teatro Zorrilla, the Manila Grand Opera House, various school auditoriums, and other theaters. Chapter 3 discusses the stage artists of Teatro Tagalo, among them Maria Carpena and Atang de la Rama, as well as social groups dedicated to theater, professional theater companies, and theater publications. Chapter 4 follows the decline of Teatro Tagalo and Teatro Español. Though the growing popularity of cinema and legitimate English language theater played their roles in the decline, so did some theater aspects and practices at this time.

Part 2, section 2, is titled “The Metropolitan Theater.” Chapter 1 records how Mayor Tomas Earnshaw initiated the development of the theater: the city donated the land and the people, through a private corporation headed by Horace Pond, raised funds to build it. Architect Juan Arellano was chosen to design the building. It was envisioned to be a venue for concerts, operas, ballet, and stage plays, as well as vaudeville, musical comedies, and revues, but it was also to be used for motion picture projections in between. It was inaugurated on 10 Dec 1931. Chapter 2 describes the first 10 years of the Metropolitan Theater, welcoming foreign artists and serving as a launching pad for young local artists. Chapter 3 covers the years 1942-44, the Japanese occupation. Held at the theater were concerts with the New Philippines Symphony Orchestra; presentations of Musical Philippines and its sister organization, Dramatic Philippines; and shows and films sponsored by the Japanese. It was also used as a venue for civic events. Chapter 4 details the fate of the Metropolitan Theater after the war and its restoration in 1978.

The book, while focusing on theater as structure, also provides a detailed and valuable reconstruction of events, activities, and personalities related to theater in Manila at various periods in Philippine history.  Written by Ludendorffo T. Decenteceo

article_title: Theater in Society, Society in Theater: Social History of a Cebuano Village, 1840-1940
text:
Published 1985. Author, Resil B. Mojares. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

A hundred years in the history of a barrio are studied in this critical work to show how a theater form embodies the moral order of the village of Valladolid. In this town of Carcar in southern Cebu, the theater form is the linambay or the Cebuano komedya, and the approach is unique in the annals of Philippine local history and theater history. It is also eminently successful, illuminating town and drama in an unprecedented way.

The book has three parts. The first traces the history of the village of Valladolid from the early 16th century when it was an important settlement, to its demotion as a barrio of Carcar in the 19th century, to its rise and decline in the early 20th century, and to its less than progressive present. This historical narration highlights, among others, the way the villagers came together or apart as they adjusted to their changing economic and social conditions.

The second part focuses on the linambay tradition of Valladolid. It discusses the themes and plots of the komedya, which revolves around the love and war between Christians and Moors in Europe in the Middle Ages, and describes in detail the people involved in production behind and in front of the stage (especially the Gantuangcos and Regises), the stages of production, the kind of audience that watched the plays, and the circumstances surrounding the linambay performances.

The third part presents the social and economic conditions in Valladolid and their relationship to the linambay. From 1900 to 1925 the linambay flourished, supported by the material and social conditions of the village. From 1925 to 1940, the play declined and eventually disintegrated with the erosion of the very same material and social conditions on which it had depended.

The study paints a lucid picture of barrio life, of structures and linkages in society reflected in its theater. The play about kings and queens, Christians and infidels, monsters and clowns presented a world of fantasy, but one that the barrio folk recognized and in which they were symbolic participants. The hierarchical, feudal society on stage reflected the existing power relations in society and its elite vision of the world. And yet the linambay was a true tradition, a truly popular form of theater, which shows that the barrio peasantry accepted the elite vision of the linambay as their own. In it there was a symbolic representation of peasant society, thus a convergence of elite and non-elite interests, an “overlapping of moral universes,” an integration. All this Mojares shows through the external and internal changes in both barrio and play, using as viewing lenses the methods of literary criticism, cultural anthropology, and history. As the book unfolds, the reader grows in insight, understanding how theater is embedded in society, and society in theater.

This unique and interdisciplinary study, a model for similar explorations, triumphs over the lack of predecessors and the thinness of historical record. Through research and interviews, and by literally walking the village, Resil Mojares enters into its universe, revealing to us its unique integration, its particular wholeness, its identity. The book won the Book Development Association of the Philippines’ Gintong Aklat Award for nonfiction in 1987.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

article_title: Ang Tradisyon Ng Luwa Sa Kapistahan Ng Taal, Batangas, 1952-2004
text:
(The Luwa Tradition in the Fiesta of Taal, Batangas, 1952-2004). 2005. MA thesis. Author, Gloria T. Gamo. College of Arts and Letters, University of the Philippines Diliman.

Gloria T. Gamo’s five-chapter thesis focuses on the luwa, a long poem declaimed on stage in praise of patron saints San Martin and the Birhen ng Caysasay held in Taal, Batangas. “Luwa” is the local term for loa, from the Spanish loar, “to praise.” The loa was an old Spanish form revering the patron saints in whose honor the comedia was performed. Later, it was also used to welcome visitors.

Chapter 1 discusses the objectives, research problem, scope and delimitation, review of related literature, significance, method, and organization of the thesis.

Chapter 2 introduces the origins of the luwa tradition based on oral accounts of the people of Taal. The two most prominent writers of the luwa are Anselmo E. Garduce and Jose A. Badillo. The study examines 50 sample luwa texts written by the two using the conventions of traditional poetry, such as tugma (rhyme), taludtod (poetic lines), saknungan (poetic stanza), and talinghaga (metaphor) as frames of analysis. Although both sets of text contain elements of papuri (praise) and pasasalamat (gratitude), panalangin (prayer), and kahilingan (request), social issues feature more in the works of Garduce.

Chapter 3 focuses on the luwante, or presenters of luwa. Data were gathered from interviews and surveys of 62 luwante, who explained the process from committing to present the form to staging actual performances of the luwa, their reasons for participation, their views on the relevance of the tradition, and their observations on changing trends in the practice of the luwa in Taal. Gamo emphasizes that the luwante communicates not only his or her personal intentions to the santo but also the collective aspirations of the people.

Chapter 4 covers the performance of the luwa, centering on San Martin and the Birhen ng Caysasay. The study chronicles the oral histories and the miracles attributed to these saints based on the testimonies of informants from Taal. The narratives form the basis of the people’s devotion and reasons for commemorating their feasts through the luwa. Gamo locates the actual staging of the luwa within the procession and the feast for the patron saints. The luwa as a dramatic form is identified by its key elements—the image of the patron and the luwante as characters, the kubol (overhead covering shelter) as the performance space, the people of the town of Taal as the audience, the luwa as text, and the feast for the patron saints as the context.

Chapter 5, the last chapter, illustrates various ways in which the dalumat ng bayan (concept of town, community, or nation) is entwined with the luwa tradition. First, the hermano or hermana mayor (principal sponsor), in leading the community, mobilizes it toward the goal of a fruitful celebration. Second, the textual analysis of sample luwa texts shows the representation of the town of Taal, the community, and the nation. Third, the continuance of the traditional feast day, procession, and luwa consolidates the legacy of the bayan.

The study contains six appendices, the most significant of which are 47 luwa texts written from 1952 to 2002 and other writings of Badillo, including a poem distinguishing the ordinary form from the luwa.

This is the first extensive study of the luwa of Taal. Through the ethnographic method, it provides documentation of the form and a thorough analysis of its significance to the people who participate in its performance.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Tropical Baroque: Four ManileÃ±o Theatricals
text:
Published 1979. Author, Nick Joaquin. Manila: National Bookstore Inc.

The anthology, originally published as the 19th volume of the Asian and Pacific Writing series of Queensland University Press, a series dedicated to making literature and contemporary writing from Asia and the Pacific available to a wider readership, is the second volume devoted to the works of Nick Joaquin, the first being Tropical Gothic: Selected Stories. Tropical Baroque is an anthology of four of Joaquin’s most representative plays.

The most famous of these, A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino: An Elegy in Three Scenes, tackles the difficulties faced by Filipino artists during the years following the shift from Spanish rule to American colonization. Set in 1941, sisters Candida and Paula, of the once-affluent Marasigan family, struggle to make ends meet, but refuse to sell the painting that their father, the famous Lorenzo Marasigan, painted for them and gave them as their passport out of poverty. The painting continues to attract a number of unpleasant personalities to the Marasigan residence who view the portrait, play critic, or conspire to buy it. Tony Javier, a boarder who is taken in by the Marasigan family as an additional source of income, seduces Paula to convince her to sell the portrait. Realizing Tony’s real intentions, Paula destroys the painting instead. This leads to the reconciliation of Candida, Paula, and their father.

The second play, Tatarin: A Witch’s Sabbath in Three Acts, is a dramatization of one of Joaquin’s short stories, The Summer Solstice. In the 1850s on St. John’s Day, Doña Lupeng learns that her cook, Amada, took part in the Tatarin, a pagan fertility ritual for women. Scornful yet intrigued by Amada’s belief in old rituals, Doña Lupeng goes to see the Tatarin at the plaza, defying her husband who thinks that women should be under men’s control. Doña Lupeng takes part in the ceremony. Failing to take his wife away from the ceremony, Don Paeng and Doña Lupeng have a confrontation afterward back at their home, where Doña Lupeng manages to compel her husband to say he adores her, and to kiss her feet out of submission.

Fathers and Sons: A Melodrama in Three Reels, is also an adaptation of another short story by Nick Joaquin, Three Generations. The play centers on the wheelchair-bound Zacarias Monzon, an ill-natured old man living in a mansion along with his daughter, Nena, and his mistress, a prostitute named Bessie. He reminisces about his past, his glory days as the “Carretela King.” He is forced out of his reverie by a visit from his son, Celo, and his family. Celo resents his father because of his abusive behavior in the past. Celo also disapproves of Bessie and drives her out of the house. Outraged, Zacarias lashes out at Celo, only to find that he no longer has the strength to fight his son. Zacarias’s illness worsens and Celo soon finds himself whipping his own son, Chitong, to release his anger at having to take care of the man who once abused him. But Chitong defies his father and brings Bessie back to the mansion, in time for Zacarias to die in her arms.

The Beatas: A Hymn in Three Stanzas narrates the events that lead to the formation of the Beaterio de Santa Catalina de Manila. The play begins with a masquerade hosted by Doña Antonia Ezguerra, a widow, where a mysterious man uncovers the true reason behind the masquerade—a guise to veil the intentions of different women to establish their own religious community. Eight years later, the beaterio (religious house) finally gets permission to operate under the leadership of Hermana Francisca del Espiritu Santo, on the property left behind by the deceased Hermana Antonia Ezguerra. The beaterio faces many difficulties brought about by the government and the church in the following years, and is dissolved by the Dominican authorities, with the archbishop ruling that women should always be governed by men. The community of the beaterio decide to go into exile. The hermanas shed their scapulars and live out their exile at the Santa Potenciana. Two years later, they are granted permission by the archbishop to return to their beaterio.

This is an important anthology of Joaquin’s most significant plays.  Written by Athena Angela Aquino

This is an important anthology of Joaquin’s most significant plays.
Written by Athena Angela Aquino

article_title: Unang Tagpo: Kalipunan ng mga Dulang Rehyunal sa Pambansang Pistang Pandulaan
text:
(First Scene: Anthology of Regional Plays from the National Theater Festival). Published 1992. Editor, Apolonio B. Chua. Introduction by Apolonio B. Chua and Fernando Josef. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

This is an anthology of plays staged at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) during the Unang Pambansang Pistang Panteatro (First National Theater Festival) held from 9 to 17 Feb 1992.

Chua’s introduction discusses highlights of the scripts as well as the staging of the plays on the CCP stage. He stresses that the plays from the regions reflect CCP’s policy of decentralizing theater productions from Metro Manila. For his part, Josef relates how his visits to the regions, as the director of the CCP Coordinating Center for the Dramatic Arts, led to the conceptualization and realization of the national theater project.

Eight plays out of the nine staged from Luzon, the Visayas, and Mindanao are anthologized. Representing Luzon are Panagsubli, an original Iloko play about a people’s return to their village after being displaced by militarization, and Tatlong Maria (Three Marys) of Bulacan, which dramatizes the love, dreams, and losses of three women of three different generations. The komedya Ang Bagong Prinsipe Rodante (The New Prince Rodante) of Parañaque would have been the third from Luzon, but it was not included for sheer length. From the Visayas come three productions—namely, the Negros sugarcane plantation workers’ Matam-is Man Gali ang Kalamay (Oh, Sugar Is Also Sweet) in Hiligaynon, about the landlord-worker relation in an hacienda system; two university-based theater companies’ stage adaptation of a Cebuano legend, Maria Cacao (Marie Cocoa); and Iloilo National High School’s dance production of Panay’s epic tale Hinilawod in Old Kinaray-a. From Mindanao are Bungkatol ha Bulawan (Golden Law), which discusses the Higaonon tribe’s defense of their land, and Siak sa Duha ka Damgo (Crack in Two Dreams), about two families’ quest for wealth, both in Cebuano and both by Davao-based theater companies; and Buhay, Pag-ibig at Kamatayan: Mga Kwentong Mindanao (Life, Love, and Death: Stories from Mindanao), about the aspirations of the southern peoples, written in Filipino.

Each of the plays is given a section, which contains an introduction either by the playwrights themselves or a fellow from the theater industry highlighting the plays’ production history as well as their social contexts and motivations; director’s notes; playwright’s notes for some of the plays; and other production notes, including the list of cast and production crew. A Filipino translation is provided for the plays written in regional languages.

The book documents the first of a series of National Theater Festivals organized by the CCP, where plays are created by regional artists who interpret the culture and issues of their regions. Such plays help define the national theater from below.  Written by Ma. Cecilia C. de la Rosa

article_title: Union Catalog on Philippine Culture: Theater Volume
text:
Published 1990. Pasay City: Cultural Center of the Philippines Library. Two volumes.

This union catalog comprises two volumes—namely, volume 1: Monographs, and volume 2: Periodical Articles. It is a comprehensive listing of all printed holdings or works on Philippine theater available in more than 50 participating libraries and cultural repositories in the Philippines as of 1990. Among these libraries and cultural repositories are the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Library, National Library of the Philippines, and various public, academic, and research libraries such as the Pangasinan Provincial Library, Davao City Library, University of the Philippines Diliman Main Library, Ateneo de Manila University Library, Far Eastern University Library, Carlos Palanca Foundation Library, and University of San Carlos Cebuano Studies Center. This catalog consists of 4,199 entries covering the period from 1769 to 1989. These works are categorized as Filipiniana materials—writings about the Philippines, produced in or outside the Philippines, by Filipinos or non-Filipinos, in any of the Philippine languages or dialects or in a foreign language.

This union catalog is the third of a series of research guides published by the CCP Library, spearheaded by its then director Carolina L. Afan. This series aims to support bibliographic and cataloging operations through the provision of reliable and standardized bibliographic data, and to provide complete and detailed coverage of the location of imprints needed by researchers and scholars. It was prepared through the collaborative efforts of the participating libraries and cultural institutions, as well as the technical support of the CCP Library staff.

This union catalog is organized into two main sections: the Booklist or Main Sequence of Entries, and the Indexes. The Booklist is further subdivided into five parts: Books/Monographs, Analytics, Theses and Dissertations, Unpublished Scripts, and Periodical Articles. It is arranged alphabetically by main entries following the Library of Congress Rules for Filing. Most of the entries have complete bibliographic descriptions, which include the following elements: author, title, place of publication, publisher, year of publication or submission (for theses) or volume and date (for periodical articles), pages, contents, notes, tracings, location symbol, and entry number. For the Periodical Articles and Analytics, an entry has a name of periodical, and title of source, respectively. For Analytics, the location symbol is not given in the main entry since it is already indicated in the book where the title analytic is found. The Indexes—author, title, series, and subject indexes—are provided to facilitate the use of the union catalog. The entry number after each record will direct the user to the main entry in the Booklist, which gives the complete bibliographic information. Lists of abbreviations are provided in the preliminary pages of the catalog, for general terms used, degrees/courses, participating libraries, and periodicals used. In the back pages of volume 2, an appendix lists additional manuscripts on Philippine theater that are available at the CCP Library. Included in this list is the Ruben Vega Zarzuela Collection.

Before the advent of electronic databases and/or online public access catalogs in libraries and information centers, this union catalog was the first and the most comprehensive listing of printed literature on Philippine theater ever undertaken and published. This union catalog is indeed significant in the study and research of Philippine theater, as it serves as a tool in locating published and unpublished printed works in the genre in various institutions in the country. Further, this union catalog allows researchers to search through collections that they would not otherwise have access to, such as those of the manuscripts.  Written by Martin Julius V. Perez

article_title: [Virgin Labfest Anthologies]
text:
Mga Piling Dula mula sa Virgin Labfest 2005-2008: Unang Antolohiya (Selected Plays from the Virgin Labfest 2005-2008: First Anthology). Published 2009. Editor, Rody Vera. Pasay City: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Mga Piling Dula mula sa Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Ikalawang Antolohiya (Selected Plays from the Virgin Labfest 2009-2012: Second Anthology). Published 2013. Editor, Rody Vera. Pasay City: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

These anthologies collect selected plays first performed in the annual Virgin Labfest at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

In his introductory essay in the first anthology, Romulo P. Baquiran Jr notes that in publishing new and untested scripts, the Virgin Labfest anthologies reflect the direction of contemporary theater as defined by the minds of emergent writers. The plays portray the clash of traditional and nascent ideas as well as the way modern Filipinos negotiate their identity in society. The scripts cover a variety of narratives—the ill-fated romance between monsters and men, the coming-of-age rituals of children in the city and country, or speculative tales of superheroes juggling their obligation to save the world and the expectations of their families. While the stories are varied, experimental, and highly imaginative, many scripts revolve around common and uniquely Filipino themes, such as the importance of community and the push toward a more progressive nation. The scripts range from satire and absurd comedy to social realistic and representational drama.

The first anthology was launched alongside the opening of the fifth Virgin Labfest in 2009. It contains 15 plays: Glenn Sevilla Mas’s Rite of Passage and J. Dennis Teodosio’s Gee-gee at Waterina (Gee-gee and Waterina), staged in 2005; Rody Vera’s Ang Unang Aswang (The First Monster), Job Pagsibigan’s The Palanca in My Mind, which won first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2006 Carlos Palanca Awards for Literature, Nicolas Pichay’s Tres Ataques de Corazon (Three Heart Attacks), and Liza Magtoto and Rody Vera’s Hubad (Naked), staged in 2006; Njel de Mesa’s Obra ni Maestra (Teacher’s Masterpiece), Yoji Sakate’s Three Sisters: Isang Noh (Three Sisters: A Noh Play), Debbie Ann Tan’s Teroristang Labandera (Terrorist Laundrywoman), second prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2008 Palanca Awards, and Layeta Bucoy’s Ellas Inocentes (The Innocents), third prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2007 Palanca Awards, staged in 2007; Tim Dacanay’s Pamantasang Hirang (Alma Mater), Allan Lopez’s Masaganang Ekonomiya (Healthy Economy), third prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2008 Palanca Awards, F. Sionil Jose’s Dong-Ao, Rogelio Braga’sAng Bayot, ang Meranao, ang Habal-habal sa Isang Nakababagot na Paghihintay sa Kanto ng Lanao del Norte (The Gay Man, the Meranao, the Motorcycle Taxi during a Tedious Wait at a Corner of Lanao del Norte), and Floy Quintos’s Ang Kalungkutan ng mga Reyna (The Despair of Queens), first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2008 Palanca Awards, staged in 2008.

The second anthology was launched alongside the opening of the ninth festival in 2013. It contains 16 plays: Bucoy’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan (Doc Resureccion: Will Heal the Nation), first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2009 Palanca Awards, Pichay’s Isang Araw sa Karnabal (A Day in the Carnival), first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2012 Palanca Awards, and Dacanay’s Ang Huling Lektyur ni Misis Reyes (Mrs Reyes’s Final Lecture), staged in 2009; Lopez’s Higit Pa Dito (More Than This), Tan’s Balunbalunan, Bingibingihan (Chicken Gizzards, Playing Deaf), RemiKaren Velasco’s Ondoy: Ang Buhay sa Bubong (Ondoy: Life on a Rooftop), first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, of the 2011 Palanca Awards, and U. Z. Eliserio, Maynard Manansala, and Chuckberry Pascual’s Matyag (Surveillance), staged in 2010; Quintos’s Evening at the Opera, first prize in the one-act play category, English division, of the 2011 Palanca Awards, Dingdong Novenario’s Kafatiran (Brotherhood), Mixkaela Villalon’s Streetlight Manifesto, and Rae Red’s Kawala (Escape), staged in 2011; Rachelle Rodriguez and Wennielyn Fajilan’s Kinaumagahan (The Next Morning), Aizel Cabanlit-Cabilan’s Pagsubli (The Return), Em Mendez’s Ang Unang Regla ni John (John’s First Period), Guelan Varela Luarca’s Mga Kuneho (Rabbits), first prize in the one-act play category, Filipino division, in the 2013 Palanca Awards, and Reuel Aguila’s Isa Pang Soap Opera (Another Soap Opera), staged in 2012.  Written by Mixkaela Z. Villalon

article_title: What Is Philippine Drama?
text:
Published 1983. Author, Nicanor G. Tiongson. Quezon City: Documentation, Research and Publication Division, Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA).

This is a revised edition of the original essay written in Filipino in 1976, and translated into Cebuano and Japanese after 1976. This 1983 version was read by the author on 12 Aug 1983 as the official country report at the Asian Theater Festival held in Manila. It retained the framework of the original essay and incorporated research and production data existing at that time.

The essay is an exposition of the various forms of Philippine drama through different periods of the nation’s history. Tiongson begins his essay by clarifying the terms “drama” and “Philippine.” Departing from Western concepts, Tiongson foregrounds the concept of mimesis or “the imitation by an actor of actions that happen in real life” as the defining element of drama. The Philippine-ness of drama is determined by the following criteria: reflecting Filipino society, history, and culture; answering the need of the Filipino at a given time; and working for the good of many.

Tiongson surveys various Philippine dramatic forms unique to their historical periods. The indigenous period nurtured rituals, dances, and customs held or performed on various occasions of a person’s life cycle or for the celebration of tribal activities. The Spanish colonial period yielded various types of secular and religious dramas; among the former, the komedya, also known as the moro-moro or linambay, was the most important and popular. Numerous religious playlets and dramas were staged in the form of panunuluyan, pastores, tatlong hari, osana, via crucis, siete palabras, salubong, and moriones, as well as the full-blown religious plays like the tibag and komedya de santo. Tiongson singles out the sinakulo as the most outstanding and enduring among the Philippine religious dramas.

The first two decades of the early American occupation witnessed the rise of the drama and sarsuwela. Of the dramas, two types are highlighted: the drama simboliko or revolutionary dramas of 1902-6, also labelled “seditious” by the Americans, and the romantic dramas. The later American period produced the bodabil, or stage show, and the so-called legitimate plays; the former began as intermission numbers and evolved into the stage show during the Japanese occupation, when the romantic drama was added to the bodabil as one of its highlights. Tiongson traces the introduction of “legitimate” theater in the Philippines through the Westernized educational system, and outlines several developments in this form: production by exclusive schools of Shakespearean and other Western classics in the original English or in English translation, staging of Broadway plays by Repertory Philippines, mounting of Filipino translations of Western classics by Teatro Pilipino, and production of adaptations of politically relevant foreign plays by PETA.

In the contemporary period, Tiongson underscores the rise of a Filipino consciousness as the most significant context that shaped Philippine theater and culture. Some of the characteristics and tendencies of theater during this time were the adoption of Western styles such as realism (both the psychological and the social) and expressionism; the experimentation with traditional Filipino dramatic forms such as the panunuluyan, duplo, “seditious” drama, and the mass; and the exploration of Asian theater styles like the Noh and kyogen. In concluding the survey, Tiongson acknowledges that the plays of the contemporary period have succeeded in faithfully portraying Philippine reality through the use of local and foreign theater traditions; still, he also emphasizes the need for a committed theater—one that provides a more thorough scientific analysis of society, believes in the power of organized movements to instigate change, and reaffirms hope in the liberation of the people.

Each section of Tiongson’s narrative ends in a systematic analysis of the theater forms of the period by applying the threefold criteria for Philippine-ness set forth at the beginning. As a result, he is able to provide an objective evaluation of a theater form. The revolutionary drama or “seditious” plays, for instance, are hailed as “Philippine drama at its meaningful best,” since they presented, albeit in allegorical form, all the principal economic forces at work in Philippine society during the early part of the American period; answered the urgent need of the majority of Filipinos to be aware of the implications of American presence and be impelled to act; and worked for the desire of the masses to liberate themselves from colonialism. In addition, each theater form or type discussed was clearly explained, with key features identified and illustrated through specific and authentic examples of plays or productions.

This essay is a succinct yet comprehensive exposition of the development of Philippine theater using a clearly articulated set of criteria rooted in a Marxist perspective. It has proven to be a valuable resource for scholars who have studied and analyzed various theater and cultural forms otherwise ignored in the academe. The Filipino phrase “repleksiyon ng pangangailangan ng nakararami” (reflection of the needs of the majority), or “RPN,” a conflation of the essay’s three criteria of Philippine-ness, became a catchphrase in the 1970s and 1980s for a number of activist and nationalist theater groups and artists, as they developed their aesthetics, and articulated their vision of what their theater should be.  Written by Galileo S. Zafra

article_title: Women Playwrights and Their Noh Adaptations /Touzai No Joryu Gekisakka Ni Yoru Noh No Saisei
text:
PhD diss. Author, Amparo Adelina C. Umali III. Graduate School of Letters, Department of Japanese Literature, Doshisha University.

This dissertation, written in the Japanese language, is a comparative study of three plays written by female playwrights (Filipino, American, and Japanese) who adapted the Japanese Noh theater form. It analyzes the feminist and intercultural elements of their new Noh plays.

Umali’s work includes the chapter “Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio’s Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna ” (Sisa’s Journey: A Noh in Laguna). Umali describes the theatrical elements and dramatic structure of the Noh that Lapeña-Bonifacio incorporates in her play, discusses the importance of Filipino elements incorporated in this play, and analyzes the resulting adaptation of one story from a classic Filipino novel into theatrical performance.

Umali cites the following Noh elements both found and transformed in Lapeña-Bonifacio’s play: two main characters, chorus, live mini-orchestral music, empty stage, mask, costume, and lights. While Sisa and Padre Salvi are supporting characters in Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), they are made the shite (principal character) and the waki (traveling secondary character), respectively, thereby making their narratives the focus of the play. Additionally, the conscious use of Noh elements with a few changes can be found in the minimalist stage with the hashigakari bridgeway, the masks worn by the Sisa character, simple lighting, and the jo-ha-kyu dramatic structure divided into different shodan but without the Japanese poetic conventions. The incorporation of Filipino elements is most evident in costume, stage, and music through the wearing of native traditional clothing such as the baro’t saya and camisa de chino, the replacement of the pine tree with the mango tree, and the use of the banduria and percussion sticks in lieu of the shamisen and other Japanese musical instruments.

Feminist and nationalist discourses inform Umali’s reading of the play. In this chapter of her dissertation, she underscores three observations: first, the transformation of Sisa’s character from the suffering mother archetype to an empowered woman who fights for justice; second, the possibility of looking at the characters of Padre Salvi and Sisa as symbols and binary opposites—the colonizer and the colonized, the oppressor and the oppressed—and as such, metaphors in narrating colonization, struggle, and liberation; third, the privileging of both Filipino and Asian aesthetics as counterdiscourse to the hegemony of Western artistic standards in the practice and study of Philippine theater. The significance of Umali’s research thus lies in its contributions to feminist art practice and the sources and influences of contemporary Philippine theater.  Written by Joi Barrios

article_title: Zarzuelang Iloko
text:
(Iloko Zarzuela). Published 1993. Editor, Mario G. R. Rosal. Translators, Mario G. R. Rosal, Benita R. Rosal, and Nerissa R. Rosal. Introduction by Mario G. R. Rosal; translation into Filipino by Noemi M. Ulep. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The introduction gives a historical-critical analysis of the major types of Iloko folk drama: the sarsuwela and komedya. For each type, there is a discussion of the dramatists and their production staff, sponsors, and patrons; the staging process of the plays; their popularity and decline; and the social role of these plays on the lives of Ilocanos.

The book anthologizes four-selected Iloko sarsuwela by four major sarsuwelista representing inner Ilocandia, the original Ilocos provinces, and outer Ilocandia, the Ilocanized provinces and countries where Ilocanos have migrated. The texts were chosen based on their popularity; their subject matter, theme, and artistry in dramatic presentation; their influence on their contemporaries and succeeding dramatists; and the place of origin of their writers and location of performances. The book includes the musical score of Barbaro Paat’s Nanangco! (Mother!).

In the choice of dramatists, the author considered their contribution to the development of the genre, their popularity and length of theatrical involvement, the artistic qualities of their work, their influence on succeeding dramatists, and their place of origin and the places where their plays were presented.

Mena Pecson Crisologo of Vigan, Ilocos Sur, is popularly known as the “Father of Iloko Zarzuela.” Neneng stands out as Crisologo’s best sarsuwela due to its well-constructed plot, as well as its use of historical and nationalistic themes. The story is set in a town in Central Luzon at the start of the 1896 Revolution. The young Neneng is almost raped by a Spanish parish priest but is rescued by Iloko revolutionaries who stab him to death 11 times and drag his body around the town. Neneng accepts the love of Valentin, one of the revolutionaries, and the play ends with all singing “Viva Pilipinas! Viva America!”

Pascual Guerrero Agcaoili of Piddig, Ilocos Norte, embodies the sarsuwela tradition in Ilocos, especially the transition from the traditional to the modern style. He is the only Iloko sarsuwelista known to have written in verse. Daguiti Agpaspasucmon ti Basi (The Basi Vendors), his most popular work, is a satire on society using burlesque and comedy. In the play, rival basi vendors Bastiana and Alejo appear in court, each one complaining of the other’s disorderliness and other bad habits, only to end up marrying each other. The play highlights social issues such as students’ aversion to manual/farm work, wives’ infidelity to migrant husbands working in Hawaii, a gradual dislike for traditional Iloko customs, and government officials’ negligence in performing their duties.

Isaias R. Lazo of San Vicente, Ilocos Sur, was a playwright and sarsuwela mentor for four decades. His most famous play, Siak ti Anakmo (I Am Your Daughter), is a satire against the evils of the American educational system, interspersed with the comic love story of male and female servants. It is also a dramatization of the Ilocanos’ pragmatism and respect for parents, as shown in the decision of Norma, the protagonist, to follow her parents’ will to marry Socing, a man she does not love but who turns out to be a good provider.

The works of Barbaro Paat of Bantay, Ilocos Sur, are not really “artistic,” but he is still considered the most popular and productive Ilocano sarsuwelista since 1933. He was mentor to younger Ilocano sarsuwelista and directors who were part of his troupe, traveling across Ilocos Sur and the Ilocanized provinces. Nanangco! was continually watched by huge crowds that did not tire of sentimental love stories. The play focuses on the relationship between Andoy and his wife, Adela, whose children Rustico and Erlinda are forced to separate due to their father’s cruelty and the outbreak of the war.

While the characteristics of the Spanish zarzuela were imbibed in different ways in the regions, the sarsuwela in Iloko remained folk drama in its basic form, serving as an instrument for social integration and welfare as well as strengthening the cultural, social, and religious aspects of the lives of Ilocanos. It also served as an effective tool for social criticism, at the same time reinforcing traditional Ilocano values such as gasat (fatalism), love for education, strong family ties, love for adventure, and pragmatism.  Written by Noemi U. Rosal
